Speaker: Mrs BAILEY
Title: COMMITTEES
text: MCEwen) (12.31 p.m.}-On behalf of the parliamentary Standing Committee on Primary Industries, Resources and Rural and Regional Affairs, I present the committee's report entitled Managing Commonwealth fisheries: The last frontier, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee. Ordered that the report be printed.

Speaker: Mrs BAILEY
Title: COMMITTEES
text: The report that I table today represents more than eight months of inquiry by the Standing Committee on Primary Industries, Resources and Rural and Regional Affairs into the management of Commonwealth fisheries following the referral by the House of audit report No. 32 1995-96 Commonwealth fisheries management: Australian Fisheries Management Authority. The committee not only examined the issues raised by the ANAO but also took the opportunity to examine broader issues such as the recreational sector, surveillance and monitoring, accountability and the need for effective national leadership. The committee took this decision in order to provide a confident future direction for a valuable industry that has subjected to intensive review and changing policy in the past decade. The largely unexplored, underresearched, dynamic and complex marine environment of the nine million square kilometres of the AFZ makes managing fisheries a daunting task. In fact, it is the last frontier. AFMA has developed a partnership model for management of fisheries, and the committee believes that the management advisory committees, MACs, are pivotal to this management process and can be improved. The partnership approach means involving all legitimate stakeholders, including the recreational sector where appropriate. The committee believes it is necessary to protect key stocks for recreational fishers as well as provide access to commercial species for commercial fishers where this is ecologically sustainable. The majority of the committee has therefore recommended a ban on the take and possession of blue and black marlin by the commercial sector in the AFZ, a tag and release program for blue and black marlin caught by Report recreational fishers and the non-issuing of area E permits to the commercial sector. The majority of the committee believes those recreational fishers defined as commercial operators who realise significant financial benefit from managed fisheries should contribute to the management costs. The high level of by-catch and dumping is a real threat to sustainability and assessment of fish stocks. The government has allocated almost half a million dollars towards research and policy development to reduce by-catch. The committee has further recommended the trialling of cluster quotas and the introduction of surrender provisions to reduce the high level of dumping at sea by commercial fishers. In order to achieve ecologically sustainable development of fisheries, controls on the level of harvesting stocks, research into assessment of stock levels and knowledge of marine biology and habitat are critical. The committee has recommended that research needs to be better coordinated and that the FRDC receive its funding on the same basis as other industry R&D corporations. The aim of the been committee in making its recommendations has been to ensure the interests of all participants are fairly represented and that the resource on which they depend is effectively managed and protected for future generations. In conclusion, in the brief time allocated this afternoon I would like to thank all those who made submissions to this inquiry, committee members, the secretary of the committee, Ian Dundas, and Justin Winton. I commend the report to the House.

Speaker: Mr ADAMS
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I am very disappointed that so little time has been allocated for members of the Standing Committee on Primary Industries, Resources and Rural and Regional Affairs to speak on this report. I believe their work has been extremely well done in starting to deal with the complex issues that face fisheries management. Eight months work needs more time to be heard. I thank our chairman, the member for MCEwen (Mrs Bailey), for allowing me some of her precious five minutes to speak on the report on behalf of the opposition. I would also like to thank other members of the committee and the committee secretariat, which has done a good job putting the report together. There are a number of major recommendations in the report that go beyond the examination of the audit report on AFMA. These include seeking to discourage by-catch dumping through recommending surrender provisions so that those fishing have to declare their by-catch. We have also sought to include recreational fishing, in particular game fishing and charter boat operators, as making up an important sector of the industry in terms of revenue generation. Up to now they have not been seen as part of the industry and really need to be considered as part of the overall industry because of the tourism and recreational potential of this area. The committee has sought recommendations to protect key stocks for recreational users while providing access to commercial species for the commercial sector where this is ecologically sustain- tions. able. All industries have their cowboys-the ones who are in this industry are totally without regard for any other aspect of the industrywho are not prepared to cooperate with any management. This makes it very difficult for those who wish to do the right thing and want to improve their fisheries. We also have had a very fragmented management structure across the states. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr LIEBERMAN
Title: COMMITTEES
text: On behalf of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, I present the committee's report entitled Review of Auditor-GeneraL's audit report No. 26, 199697-Community Development EmpLoyment Projects Scheme-Phase 11 of audit: AboriginaL and Torres Strait Islander Commission, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee. Ordered that the report be printed.

Speaker: Mr LIEBERMAN
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I present the committee's report on its review of the Australian National Audit Office's phase 2 audit of the efficiency and effectiveness of the administration of ATSIC's community development employment projects. The committee tabled its report on the ANAO's phase 1 audit in December 1996. The committee was pleased to learn that the government has in effect agreed with the committee's recommendaThe CDEP is a very important scheme. It has contributed significantly to the economic and social well-being of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples over the 20 years of its existence. Indeed, in many remote areas CDEP projects are the main source of employment for indigenous people. Given that large amounts of moneys are expended under the scheme, reviews and audits such as that carried out by the ANAO have an important role in ensuring a well-managed scheme. The committee found that the ANAO's recommendations are fair and appropriate. ATSIC has endorsed all the ANAO recommendations. The committee was pleased to find in the course of its inquiry that ATSIC has already taken a number of steps to address the issues raised in the recommendations. In addition, the committee was pleased to find that ATSIC has worked closely with the ANAO, as well as with the Department of Finance, in progressing its operational planning mechanisms and in developing its performance indicators and performance information. The committee has put forward a number of recommendations of its own with a view to bringing about further improvements. The ANAO's audit encompassed the administration of the CDEP scheme. It did not extend to a fundamental questioning of whether the scheme's organisation and form remain as appropriate today as in earlier years when it was far more modest in size. The committee is interested in some of these broader issues. It notes an independent review of the CDEP scheme recently requested by the Expenditure Review Committee of cabinet. This review is expected to make recommendations to enhance the scheme's outcomes and make sure it remains relevant to the needs of indigenous people and their communities. The committee looks forward to the results of that review. The committee considers that ATSIC should undertake a number of pilot schemes involving the contracting out of administrative tasks and responsibilities as part of its assessment of its current model of administration. The committee was concerned to learn that on occasion serious management failures in CDEP funded organisations may not be getting the attention from the responsible regulatory agency that they deserve. We have therefore recommended that ATSIC bring such failures to the attention of the relevant Attorney-General as well as to the regulatory agency. I note that the Queensland Public Accounts Committee and the Commonwealth Joint Committee of Public Accounts are presently reviewing the financial accountability requireable ments for Queensland Aboriginal councils and Torres Strait Island councils in their dealings with Commonwealth and state funding agencies. We wish the committee well in their endeavours. I would like to thank all committee members for their valuable contribution to the inquiry, the committee secretariat and particularly the inquiry secretary, Mr Robert Walters.

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I would like to focus my comments on just two areas: firstly, the administration of the CDEP scheme and, secondly, the outcomes generated by the scheme. Both areas have a bearing on the effectiveness of the me. Whilst this is almost universally held to be a very valuable scheme, I agree that periodic reviews of the effectiveness of its administration are warranted, given the scheme's growth over the years and its current size. Similarly, the effectiveness of the scheme in terms of outcomes generated needs to be reviewed periodically. It is clear that ATSIC has made great strides in its administration of the scheme over recent years. ATSIC has taken serious account of the ANAO's performance audit as well as various other reviews of the scheme undertaken in recent years. I was pleased to hear that ATSIC is similarly committed to addressing the matters raised in the ANAO's phase 2 audit. I would like to bring to the attention of the House an interim report of 3 April 1997 by ATSIC's office of evaluation and audit on an evaluation of the CDEP scheme. This evaluation has established that program participants have derived considerable employment, income, training, and social and cultural benefits from the CDEP program. CDEP participants were found less likely to be problem drinkers or to have been arrested in the last five years. In addition, they were more likely to have a stronger sense of cultural identity. I expect the recently announced independent review of the scheme will confirm its contribution to the economic and social well-being of indigenous peoples. In carrying forward the findings of the office of evaluation and audit's interim report, I trust it will also be to identify ways to enhance the scheme's outcomes still further. I acknowledge the work done by Mr Robert Walters from the committee secretariat and the whole of the secretariat in preparing the report. I commend the report to the House.

Speaker: Mr NEHL
Title: COMMITTEES
text: On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories, I present the committee's report entitled A right to protest, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee. Ordered that the report be printed.

Speaker: Mr NEHL
Title: COMMITTEES
text: The purpose of this inquiry was to review the arrangements which apply when people wish to protest at Parliament House and other areas of national land. That includes the Lodge, the Australian jWar Memorial, Canberra airport, the embassy area, Commonwealth offices and Defence facilities. The committee has adopted a minimalist approach to ensure that the right to protest is not diminished in Canberra. While some people proposed a more structured approach to dealing with public demonstrations, through permits or a formal notificasary tion system, the committee considers that such options would be overly complex and unnecessarily restrictive. Instead, we have put our faith in the Australian people that they will exercise their right to protest in an orderly and peaceful manner and will shun the violence we witnessed last year. The clear message we received from many contributors to the inquiry was that Australians do not want or need a system which unnecessarily increases the controls or limits on their right to protest. The committee agrees. Our recommendations focus on encouraging cooperation between protesters and relevant authorities to ensure the proper planning and conduct of public demonstrations at Parliament House and on other parts of national land. Nevertheless, in adopting this minimalist approach, the committee agreed that there is a need to tidy up some of the rules which apply to protest structures. During the inquiry, we heard about many problems which have arisen when people have sought to erect structures in support of their protest. The structures have included tents, sheds and even a Trojan Horse. It is important to recognise that there already is a requirement for people Report to seek approval before they can erect a structure on national land, but the law is unclear and open to testing in the courts. As acknowledged by the committee, unclear law does not make for good law. To make it fair for all, and to ensure public safety, the committee has recommended the introduction of a permit system for protest structures on national land. This is not an attempt to restrict protesters who want to use structures as part of their protest. The system we have proposed clarifies and simplifies the process by which protest structures can be authorised. Other committee recommendations include identifying a contact officer in the Australian Federal Police to coordinate protests on national land and to liaise with protesters and other relevant authorities on the arrangements for protests; producing a public information booklet with advice about protesting on national land; repealing outdated and unneceslegislation limiting protests; and revising existing laws applying to protests to ensure that they are written in plain English and outline clearly the powers available to relevant authorities. I finish by saying that, while bad demonstrations, as we witnessed in front of the parliament last year, are few and far between, it is through these bad experiences that the absolute and cherished right to protest may well be etched away. So it is incumbent on all demonstrators to keep this in mind when taking up the banner and marching. The committee is very grateful for the work and support provided by its secretariat. I commend the report to the parliament.

Speaker: Mr DARGA VEL
Title: COMMITTEES
text: Fraser) (12.46 p.m.)Firstly, I would like thank the committee secretariat for the fine work that has been carried out in this report. The secretariat is burdened with a very large workload, but it has indeed managed to carry out a very professional approach to the work at hand. Also, I would like to thank my parliamentary colleagues for the constructive work that they undertook in dealing with the report. It was a very constructive committee process, in my view and experience. Also, thanks to the committee chair, Senator MCGauran, the deputy chair, Senator Lundy, and my Labor colleagues. Also, I would like to particularly thank the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville), who took a very constructive approach to the committee's deliberations. The committee has gone for a minimalist approach and we have done so for a number of reasons. Essentially, a crackdown, as sought by some small minority entities, would be impractical according to the evidence that the committee heard. We looked at experiences in the United States, where a whole raft of regulations imposed for demonstrations on national land were essentially regularly ignored, consequently making the conduct of demonstrations problematic indeed. Instead, we are seeking to facilitate peaceful demonstrations by enabling things like public address systems and so on. I have attached an addendum, in my name, to the report. The addendum goes to the question of the Aboriginal tent embassy. Whilst the majority of the committee felt that it was unnecessary to comment on anyone particular protest, there is a particular protest ings. on national land, which is the tent embassy, the continued presence of which, in my view, should not be interfered with. The report does not recommend the removal of the Aboriginal tent embassy. The report does suggest the abolition of things like the Unlawful Assemblies Ordinance 1937 and other restrictive instruments which are designed to restrict demonstrations on national land. The committee proposes that some discretion be provided to the NCA over the question of fixed structures-the NCA being the National Capital Authority, not the National Crime Authority. If such discretion is provided, the NCA should not interpret the recommendations of this committee as encouraging the removal of the tent embassy. Quite the contrary view should be taken, as the committee has actively considered and rejected proposals aimed at limiting the rights of protesters and has instead opted for minimalist intervention.

Financial Institutions and Public Administration Committee Report

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: Wannon) (12.50 p.m.)On behalf of the Standing Committee on Financial Institutions and Public Administration, I present the committee's report of the inquiry into aspects of the national competition policy reform package, incorporating a dissenting report, entitled Cultivating competition, together with the minutes of proceedOrdered that the report be printed.

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: This is the first report of the committee in this new parliament and I am pleased to say that the committee reached unanimous conclusions and recommendations. Competition policy is a critical area of reform for the public sector. This policy is about ensuring that, where public ownership exists, competition should apply. The inquiry spanned two parliaments, and our report comes two years after the signing of the COAG agreement on the reforms by the Commonwealth and all state and territory governments. That agreement represents a major step forward in intergovernmental relations, as well as bringing the potential large and lasting economic benefits to the Australian community. The significant benefits arising from competition reform have been recognised by all levels of government and all major political parties. The expected benefits for ordinary Australians are price reductions, lower inflation, more growth, more jobs and uniform protection of consumer and business rights across the whole country. More specifically, the Industry Commission has estimated that the long-run annual gain in real gross domestic product is of the order of 5.5 per cent, or $23 billion a year, as a result of the cumulative effect of the Hilmer and related reforms. In this report, the committee focuses on making a constructive contribution to the debate on how the policy is being implemented. It has not sought to redefine the policy and it is too early for the committee to conduct a detailed evaluation of outcomes. Nor have we looked at the specific impact of the reforms in particular sectors. After two years of implementation, the reform policies of most jurisdictions are now firmly in place. Overall, the committee was impressed by the amount of effort parties have put into meeting their obligations under the competition principles agreement. The committee also notes the progress that has been made to date. Much, of course, remains to be done. In this report the committee has addressed three crucial aspects of implementing the reforms: first, the public interest test, which is a pivotal element of the policy. The committee has outlined its interpretation of the test and it believes there should be some consistency of approach throughout jurisdictions. Accordingly, it has outlined what it are the basic principles that should guide the application of the test in alI jurisdictions. Second, community service obligations which are an integral part of the system of all levels of government in this country. Competition policy has reinforced and encouraged a greater awareness and systematic evaluation of CSOs. In the committee's view, the delivery and funding of CSOs should be assessed on a case by case basis. Attention should for more strongly focus on their ongoing transparency and relevance, with appropriate reporting and monitoring systems for CSOs being implemented. Thirdly, at the commencement of the inquiry in mid-1995, local government held significant concerns about the reforms. Whilst many of these have been allayed, some remain. An area of critical concern to local government is the taxation of local government businesses. The committee shares that concern. We have recommended that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) address that issue as a matter of priority in COAG, as, under the current regime, there is a powerful incentive for local government not to corporatise. The committee has also addressed concerns about the application of the reforms to local government in rural and remote localities and has put forward suggestions to meet these. Shortly the Treasurer will be making his assessment of how the state and territory governments have met their obligations under the agreements and he will be determining the funds they will receive as their share in the benefits arising from implementing the reforms. Significant funds are at stake. Total national competition policy payments to state and local government over the next nine years will be $16.1 billion. Of that amount, competition payments account for $215.1 million in 199798. Payments are conditional on the state and territory governments meeting certain targets in implementation. To encourage transparency, the committee has recommended that the Treasurer ensure that the assessment is performance based and that he make details of the outcomes and process publicly available following assesssees ment of each tranche. Local government's quest to share in the competition payments, as well as the financial assistance grants, is a matter for each state and territory government to decide. The committee has also recommended that COAG look at the more general issue of the dual role of the National Competition Council of both advising on implementation and assessing implementation of the reforms. Given the scope of the reforms, their potential to substantially impact on the lives of all , Australians, and the relative newness of the policy, it is critical that there is adequate public education and consultation about the reforms and their progress. The committee has recommended such public education arrangements be put in place early by all agencies involved in implementing the reforms. There are many people to be thanked for their hard work on the inquiry and report, in particular: the members of the committee and its predecessor; the Commonwealth and all state and territory governments for their cooperation and contributions; the many industry, local government and community organisations and individuals who provided evidence; our adviser in both parliaments, Jim Dick; and all the secretariat staff, particularly Chris Paterson and Bev Forbes, who worked on the inquiry in both this parliament and the last. I commend the report to the House.

Speaker: Mr WILTON
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I would like to commence by enlightening the House of the fact that the secretariat of the Standing Committee on Financial Institutions and Public Administration was a most professional body and that committee members conducted themselves in a most august and professional manner. The member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) detailed the fact that the report states, at paragraph 5.20, that from 1997-98 to 2005-2006 national competition policy payments, incorporating both financial assistance grants and competition payments, will total some $16.1 billion. It is on this point and this point only that a dissenting report has been issued going specifically to the matter in paragraph 5.20. The national competition policy implementation agreement specifies that benefits to state and local government arising from competition reforms will be achieved by implementing the real per capita guarantee of financial assistance grants on a rolling three year basis and also through three instalments of general purpose payments in the form of a series of competition payments. These are essentially the two legs from which local and state governments may benefit by participation in these reforms. The only reference to local government in the agreement is specifically to financial assistance grants pools. The agreement also states that local government will benefit from the link between state and local government financial assistance grants pools which make up some 70 per cent of the package agreed to by COAG. Members of the opposition dissented to paragraph 5.20 of the committee's report, which states, in part: The total National Competition Policy Payments to state and local government from 1997-98 to 20052006 will be $16.1 billion (or $12.5 billion in 1994-95 prices). FAGs will account for $10.8 billion and Competition Payments $5.3 billion. Opposition members of the committee dissent because these amounts are not the amounts which state and local government will receive and it is absolute fiction to suggest that they are. It is fiction because the coalition government has required the states to make fiscal contributions to the Commonwealth of $1,559 million over three years-l 996-97 through to 1998-99-the net effect of which is to reduce the Commonwealth's national competition payments by that amount. The upshot of this is that $14.6 billion is the most that the states and local government may receive from NCP payments. So even if these two levels of government both bend over backwards to implement competition policy, they will stand to gain only $14.6 billion, not $16.1 billion as detailed in the report. I alluded to the two legs of competition payments, that is, financial assistance incentives to the states. The first of those is that provision of financial assistance by the Commonwealth be conditional on the states making satisfactory progress in the area of reforming limitation and the second is straight out competition policy payments. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: On behalf of the parliamentary Standing Committee on Financial Institutions and Public Administration, I present the committee's report entitled Review of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission 1995-96 annual report, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee. Ordered that the report be printed.

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: The committee decided to examine the ACCC's annual report following concerns raised about the processes and procedures used by the ACCC in relation to mergers and section 87B undertakings. We took the opportunity to raise and discuss a number of issues with the ACCC at a public hearing in April this year. The ACCC, during the first year of its operation, has been at the forefront of major and, at times, controversial decisions affecting Australian business and industry. Also, the newly formed ACCC has a vital role in competition reforms being implemented across all sectors of the Australian community. The intention of these competition reforms is to achieve fair competition in all markets throughout Australia, with uniform rules and rights for all consumers and businesses applying throughout the economy. This is where the ACCC comes in. Its main role is that of competition regulator. Its to ensure that the laws, as embodied in the Trade Practices Act and designed to promote and preserve competition, are observed. In the case of mergers considered by the ACCC, there are a number of options-and I will briefly outline one of these. If the merger is judged likely to be anticompetitive, the ACCC notifies the parties of its view and the reasons for it. The parties can then offer to amend the proposal so that it overcomes the anti-competitive concerns. This occurred, for example, in the Mobil-Amgas merger where Mobil undertook to provide independents, wholesalers and retailers with access to terminal facilities. It is the ACCC's use of this undertakings process that has drawn criticism from some segments of business and industry. In particular, the question Report arises about public accountability and the transparency of these procedures. The concerns are: that the Trade Practices Act provides the ACCC with unfettered power to make and impose enforceable undertakings; and that this power is widely used by the ACCC to restructure industries, without any requirement that the process be open to public scrutiny or third party involvement. The CaJtex-Ampol merger is cited as an example of where the ACCC has shaped an industry into its preferred model-in that case, to reshape the petrol retailing market. The Australian Petroleum Agents & Distributors Association has raised two further points about this: that there are no statutory guidelines to limit the ACCC's discretion in accepting undertakings; and that the Trade Practices Act provides no mechanism for making the ACCC accountable for its actions in the acceptance of undertakings. Moreover, third parties are not required to be consulted, nor can third parties seek a review of undertakings. The committee, while seeing undertakings as a useful tool, does however question the extent to which the undertakings process is open to public scrutiny. The committee favours a more transparent approach job is than is currently the case. Thus, we are recommending, as a first step, that the ACCC investigate mechanisms whereby the process of accepting undertakings in merger cases can be made more transparent. We will be seeking a report from the ACCC on this matter later in the year when the committee reviews the ACCC's 1996-97 annual report. If the committee continues to have concerns, it may seek a reference to conduct a more comprehensive inquiry. The committee also raised with the ACCC: to what extent the benefits of competition, in particular, consumer benefits, are occurring in rural and regional Australia? It would appear that the benefits of competition, in particular consumer benefits, are not being realised as strongly in rural areas as in the city. In my electorate, and in the electorates of some of the members of the committee-and I see the member for Page (Mr Causley) in the chamber-petrol prices are an example of where this certainly appears to be the case. The committee plans to pursue the issue of competition and consumer benefits when it reviews the ACCC's 1996-97 annual report later this year. The pursuit of competition is not an end in itself, but is intended to contribute to the public good, to create more efficient markets, to improve the provision of goods and services and bring about lower prices. With these objectives it is crucial that government, business, industry and the general public can measure the extent to which these benefits are being realised and whether the approaches being undertaken are working. The committee supports the role played by the ACCC, but it believes there would be some benefit in a more systematic review of the general impact of the ACCC's decisions in the mergers area on competition and benefits to the community. To this end, the committee is recommending that the ACCC give a higher priority to monitoring outcomes. We are also interested to explore what mechanisms might be set up for external review, and have recommendations to this effect in our report. I would like to thank everyone involved and commend this report to the House. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr MCCLELLAND
Title: COMMITTEES
text: Barton) 0.06 p.m.)On behalf of the parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, I present the committee's eighth report, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee. Ordered that the report be printed.

Speaker: Mr MCCLELLAND
Title: COMMITTEES
text: In the absence of the hard working member for Groom (Mr Taylor), I have the honour of presenting this tabling speech. The report I have just tabled includes two chapters on treaties tabled on 18 March and 13 May 1997 together with a progress report of the United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification. This is the eighth report the committee has tabled since September of last year. The treaties considered in the first two chapters are routine, but mention should be made of the agreement with New Zealand about the joint accreditation system which we have with that country. This agreement deals with a body which was established to meet the demand for an accreditation system for providers of quality management systems and product certification services. The objective behind this accreditation system is the attainment of national and international recognition of Australian and New Zealand producers, auditors, consultants and trainers functioning within conformity assessment structures. We were concerned that the system does not include a formal review mechanism to evaluate the success of its efforts to enhance exports. We have therefore recommended that such a formal mechanism be established. Since beginning the inquiry into the desertification convention, we have held three public hearings and one inspection. Honourable members will perhaps recall that this convention has been the subject of some controversy, and that Australia has not yet ratified it. The government has not yet tabled the national interest analysis on this convention. We understand that further consultation is required with the states and territories and with other interested organisations before such an NIA can be finalised. We believe that, in this situation, there is no alternative for us other than to keep the situation under review and to reopen the inquiry when and if an NIA becomes available. I would also like to mention another matter briefly on behalf of the committee. In a recent speech, the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) referred to last year's reforms ensuring parliament had a 'well-defined and effective role' in the treaty making process. He was also kind enough to refer to the 'proactive manner' in which this committee has carried out its role in the new process. Our first report was tabled on 9 September 1996 and the government response was tabled on 14 May 1997. To date, the government has not responded to the remaining six reports, although we understand that two other responses will be tabled tomorrow. Nevertheless, the committee is disappointed at this relatively slow rate of response. In the absence of the member for Groom, lest I embarrass him if he was present, I must take this opportunity to commend the member for Groom for the tremendous work that he has done as chair of the committee and I commend other members of the committee likewise under his leadership. To date, just over a year since the committee was established, we have considered over 70 treaties. The committee itself has provided a valuable role in consultation with members of the public, government and non-government organisations alike. Those treaties which we have considered have ranged from matters relating to the environment, trade, defence and to internal defence in terms of policing and law enforcement measures. It performs a very valuable role in addressing these, consulting and education, as I have indicated and, in conclusion, again in his absence and at the risk of embarrassing him, I would like to commend the member for Groom for the tremendous hard work undertaken by him.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: COMMITTEES
text: As the person charged with the chairmanship of the subcommittee on the United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification, I thank the House for the opportunity to make this contribution. The desertification treaty is one of that list of treaties which have substantial impact, much wider than the simple intent of the convention. It was this type of treaty that originated in the Senate inquiry and, of course, the formation of this committee. Might I join with the member for Barton (Mr MCClelland) in pointing out how well the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties works and the degree of cooperation between people of the various parties. We all totally support the current situation where the parliament now has a substantial involvement in the implementation of these treaties, compared to the circumstances of the past, where the Crown was defined as the maker of treaties in our constitution and the Crown was perceived to be the executive council. In other words, and I think quite frequently, not even the cabinet of the day saw these particular treaties. Treaties come in two categories-desertification, rights of the child, racial discrimination et cetera, which one can see as ground breaking areas-and the rest make up the more mundane aspect, with treaties on double taxation and airline agreements and all those things which are very important and where the committee is finding that there is an opportunity to make a contribution. My particular reason in rising is that, very early in the piece, most committee members had a grave concern that this desertification treaty, dealing as it would with land management throughout Australia, would open up another Commonwealth power and one that, whilst the government of the day might not want to use it, could be forced upon it by other interest groups literally taking the government to court and demanding that it meet its obligations, having promised the world that it would address desertification both at home and abroad. This problem is aggravated by the fact that the treaty as written does not allow for vations. In other words, there is no basic opportunity for a federal clause-because land management in Australia is very much a federal matter and the responsibility of state governments under our constitution-to address this problem. Consequently, the committee quite properly decided that we should not only advertise our intention to have an inquiry but also invite state governments in particular to make submissions. I wish to put on the record that only one state, New South Wales, has bothered to respond to our invitation. Whilst the committee received something like 28 submissions, which is a surprisingly low number on such a sensitive issue, the realities are that state governments-which have campaigned vigorously over the years to have a more expanded role in the treaty making process-when invited to make contributions on an area which has a direct effect on them have failed to do so. I hope some of them bother to read these words; I am not going to hold my breath. The other aspect of all this is that, whilst we have had some legal advice that says that particular action may not occur, personally I cannot see how it would not occur once the Commonwealth has made the promise. As I point out, by European standards I represent about 12,000 desert farmers. Outside me, in areas such as Kalgoorlie and western New South Wales, we also have our pastoral properties.

Speaker: Mr NEHL
Title: PRIVATE MEMBERS BUSINESS
text: by leave-'We shared the unspeakable grandeur of it all.' I am referring to Antarctica and I am quoting an Antarctic expeditioner, Syd Kirkby. I will come back to him in a little while. The point I want to make is that 1997 is the 50th anniversary, the jubilee, of Australia establishing permanent bases in Antarctica. Of course, in 1947 Dr Phillip Law and a band of intrepid expeditioners established our first base on Heard Island. We now have permanent bases on Macquarie Island and at Davis, Casey and Mawson on the Antarctic mainland which have been there for decades. While this motion is dedicated to the science of Antarctica, I want to expand it beyond that because of the fact that we are celebrating 50 years of incredible Australian endeavour in Antarctica. I want to not only take in the expeditioners we have now but those amazing men like Sir Douglas Mawson and the incredible photographer of Antarctica, Frank Hurley. It is not just the scientists; there are the cooks and the plumbers; the carpenters and the doctors; the diesos-the diesel mechanics that keep the machinery and the bulldozers running; and the weather people-all of whom at this moment are involved in 24-hour darkness in incredible isolation. I also want to pay tribute to the families of those expeditioners who over the decades have been at home here in Australia while their husbands and, in some cases in recent years, their wives have been there for a year or 18 months in total isolation. After all, the last ship has to leave by 16 March or it does not leave at all, and the next ship cannot get back in until mid to late October. Those people in the ultimate wilderness are doing a wonderful job for Australia. I would also like to mention the ships' crews, and in particular I want to make mention of the 17 expeditioners and three members of ships' crews who gave their lives in the service of Australia in Antarctica. It is a beautiful place-I know; I have been there twice-but a very demanding and very dangerous place. It is a place that, once seen, gets into your blood. There are four great lessons for the world from Antarctica. One is that there has never been a war there. It is the only continent where there has never been a war. Apart from one Russian going mad and killing one of his colleagues, there has never been a major crime. There has never been a shot fired in anger. All scientific information and knowledge is shared freely between all nations. The wildlife are not afraid of you. Totally wild animals have no fear of you as a human being. I spoke of isolation. In 1963 at Davis Station there were only nine people; a total community of nine. Des Lugg told me at the Antarctic jubilee dinner on Saturday in Hobart, attended by 400 people and chaired by Tim Bowden, of the devastating impact it had when they learnt that one of their colleagues at Mawson, Bob White, had died at the age of 21. That same year, 1963, when they learnt of the assassination of President Kennedy, the impact on those nine Australians living in total isolation was enormous. I do not have time to speak on that at greater length. I mentioned Sydney Kirkby. He was a surveyor who led parties through the Prince Charles Mountains. I want to quote briefly from an article he has written for Aurora, the magazine of the AN ARE club. He wrote: Even more, the spirit is there because we each know that fellow expeditioners like oneself have been where the spirit is born, that they have and done the same sort of things and must have many of the some values. We are fortunate enough to have had opportunities to step outside mere personal interest and by contributing to a bigger undertaking to reap a bigger reward. We have had the chance to transcend our ideas of our normal capabilities and be a bit more committed, a bit less selfish, a bit more diligent and capable and stalwart and inventive and compassionate and versatile and determined . . . And because we committed ourselves to the dream we share in the realisation of the dream ... We shared the wondrous glory of it all. I salute all Antarctic expeditioners, of all nations, past and present.

Speaker: Mr KELVIN THOMSON
Title: PRIVATE MEMBERS BUSINESS
text: I have great pleasure in being able to support the motion on Antarctic scientific programs moved by the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl). Antarctica is a special place which has a special magic. It has a stunning diversity of wildlife. It is a place of extraordinary beauty and splendour. It is vast. It is dangerous. It is a place of extremes. And it tells us something about our own limitations in an era when we are inclined to regard ourselves as supreme and to think that we, the human race, can do whatever we like. We have this opportunity to pay tribute to some 50 years of official Australian endeavour in Antarctica and to reflect on some of the important steps that we have taken and the important role that Australia has played in the protection of Antarctica. In particular, it is worth taking the House back to August 1989 when the then Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, and his French counterpart, Michel Rocard, took the lead in preventing mining and oil drilling in Antarctica, seeking to tum this magnificent, fragile, irreplaceable wilderness into an internationally protected reserve. At that time, there were strong arguments that it was possible to reconcile mining and oil drilling in Antarctica with environmental protection and that controls offered more realistic protection than an outright ban. But the very clear judgment was made by the Australian government at that time that it was simply not possible to have mining or oil drilling in an environment such as Antarctica's without the risk of extensive environmental damage of the kind of, or even worse seen than that which occurred with, the Exxon Valdez spill off the cost of Alaska in 1989. At the time, people were saying that this was an environmentally risky step. They said, 'If the federal government is not able to achieve the Antarctic wilderness park, then we will not have any regulation or controls whatsoever.' In the couple of years following that, the Australian and, indeed, French governments were able to persuade the nations of the world and, in 1991, they ultimately adopted the Protocol on Environmental Protection to the Antarctic Treaty, which has banned mining and oil drilling in the Antarctic for at least the next 50 years and, hopefully, in perpetuity. The environment movement-groups such as the Australian Conservation Foundation, the Worldwide Fund for Nature and Greenpeace and the like--encouraged and supported the Australian government through that diplomatic journey in negotiating that protocol. That is something that I believe we can all be proud of. Certainly, it had the support of all parties in the federal parliament as well as support from the wider community. In recent times there have been continuing efforts to protect Antarctica. For exatnple, we have had announcements that the subantarctic islands of Heard, MCDonald and Macquarie islands are to be fast-tracked for world heritage listing. That is a most important step. Heard and MCDonald islands have been described as having superlative phenomena, features and processes. Macquarie Island is some 1,500 kilometres south of Tasmaniaindeed, I think it is represented by the member for Franklin (Mr Quick)-and is nicknamed 'the great green sponge' because its sodden, densely vegetated landscape is regarded as one of the world's best exc.mples of oceanic crust which has risen to tre surface. This island contains extraordinary wildlife. It has 100,000 elephant seals and millions of penguins; it is a breeding site for many albatross species; it has kilkr whales and seals and penguins-a whole variety of wildlife which warrant special attention to its protection. I also would like to refer to the report recently prepared by the United Nations General Assembly entitled State of the environment in Antarctica: report of the Secretary-General. In the report he observes that there are a number of threats to Antarctica. He notes: Antarctic tourism is a growing industry, with the number of sites being visited, as well as the range of types of activity, increasing dramatically. He notes that, while current fishing levels are below the total allowable catch levels, many fisheries, including krill, are still attracting commercial interest and that problems have been experienced with bird by-catch in longline fisheries. He also notes: Pollutants originating in the industrial and populated areas of the world are transported to Antarctica by atmospheric and oceanic circulations. Additionally: Antarctica is ... an ideal stage on which to base monitoring activities for long-range pollutants, due to minimal, localised human activity. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: PRIVATE MEMBERS BUSINESS
text: Mr Jenkins)Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting. Vaccine Trials

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: PRIVATE MEMBERS BUSINESS
text: I move: That this House calls on the Government to establish an independent inquiry into vaccine trials on children, including whether: (1) Commonwealth agencies, including the (a) Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, (b) National Health and Medical Research Council and (c) Department of Health and Family Services, complied with Commonwealth and State laws and appropriate research guidelines; (2) the trials led to any injury or increased the risk of injury to the recipients; and (3) appropriate safeguards are in place to prevent any repetition. Before I tum to the detail of the motion, I would like to make one thing clear at the start-that is, this debate is not an attack on immunisation. The Labor Party offered bipartisan support to the federal government's plans to seek to increase the level of immunisation in the Australian community, and we continue to do so. For the record, let me remind the House of a statement on immunisation made by Australian of the Year, Professor Peter Doherty, who has also received a Nobel prize. He said: From the scientific point of view you just don't want to see kids getting sick and dying from completely preventable diseases, or becoming deaf from measles, or getting infections that are completely controllable. He went on to say that there were no 100 per cent guarantees about the practice but the benefits of immunisation and vaccination far outweigh the risks. Peter Doherty has the knowledge to be able to put those statements on the public record. They are statements that the Labor Party opposition strongly support. Any risk from immunisation is infinitesimally smaller than the benefits that flow to the children who are fully immunised. What this is about is government agencies which have carried out trials or experiments without parents or guardians being properly informed, or without parents or guardians giving their consent, and whether such activities are worthy of an open, public investigation. It is also about whether government agencies have carried out trials or experiments without the interests of children being protected. Some people have said that worthy organisations such as the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories and some of the medical research institutes that were involved in these trials do not deserve to have their reputations damaged by a public inquiry. These organisations do have a good reputation in the Australian community, which is well deserved. But the point I would make is that I do not think that we would be doing the right thing by those organisations if we try to argue that they are to be immune, or protected, from proper public discussion and proper public examination of any mistakes that have been made in the past. What are the issues that we are concerned about? Perhaps I could begin with a few quotes from the Age, which has been doing an excellent job in trying to get to the bottom of a number of concerns about the treatment of young children in institutions in Victoria. One article, in the Insight section, is headlined 'Babies used in experiments', with the subheading 'Medical research in Melbourne orphanages revealed'. It reads: Children in orphanages and babies' homes in Victoria were used in post-World War II medical experiments and research that continued until 1970. Babies less than 12 months old were injected with large doses of an experimental vaccine against herpes. Other experiments included giving children a test vaccine against whooping cough which was never put into production. Those carrying out the experiments included researchers from the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories and the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research. In the largest experiment, which was still running in 1970, 350 infants between the ages of three months and 36 months in unnamed institutions were injected with full adult doses of trial influenza vaccines to test for toxic reactions. Researchers from the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories admitted at the time that they approached the test with "some trepidation" because influenza vaccines had "long been known to produce more severe toxic reactions in children than in adults". The Age has learnt that two previous tests of influenza vaccines on children produced severe toxic reactions. It is believed that the results of the tests were never published. There are a whole series of cases that were published in the Age that explain in more detail the concerns in the particular cases. Last week, we had another article in the Age under the headline 'Death sparks new fears on vaccine tests'. That article states: The State and Federal Governments will investigate circumstances surrounding the death of a child referred to at an international conference by a Commonwealth Serum Laboratories vaccine researcher. It goes on to say: The London conference proceedings show the researcher was questioned about the death, to which he did not refer in his main paper. The article goes on to say: When asked about the findings of the autopsy on the dead child, the researcher replied: "That actually was the work of another colleague of mine and I do not know whether I can comment on it." The researcher told the conference he had approached the trial on babies as young as three months with "some trepidation" because of the toxic reactions in some infants to existing vaccines. In addition to the crucial question, which is whether or not children suffered in the trials, there is a second issue, that is, whether there was proper consent given for this medical research. One of the doctors involved in the trials appeared on radio recently. I will not name the doctor, but I will read an excerpt from an interview on Radio National. It reads: REPORTER: Who made that choice? DOCTOR: I don't honestly know. Well, when I way I don't honestly know, it was presumably by arrangement with Stan Williams or the CSL. REPORTER: And do you know whether they got consent? DOCTOR: Well, they'd have to. They'd have to have consent. But who they got it from, I don't know. REPORTER: Were you aware of that at the time? DOCTOR: Of what? REPORTER: Of who gave the consent. DOCTOR: I didn't inquire. I presumeI mean, you went to a babies home, and the nursing staff or the matron or someone expected you. So, I didn't query any more ... Our concern is that it appears that there are questions remaining as to whether proper consent was given by the guardians of these children. The response of the Victorian state government through the Minister fo- Youth and Community Services, Dr Napthme, has been to initiate an internal departmental inquiry. Premier Kennett has rejected a public inquiry and the federal Minister. for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldndge) made this comment in a radio interview: REPORTER: Isn't it time for the establishment of an independent national inquiry? WOOLDRIDGE: Well, it's not essentially a Commonwealth issue. The care of children is the responsibility of the states. If th- Vi-torian ment wishes to set up such an inqUIry, I would be happy to cooperate with it. But I can't see what good would come out of a Commonwealth inquiry at this time. My concern is that this is an issue that involves Commonwealth agencies. Commonwealth Serum Laboratories were involved, the National Health and Medical Research Council approved grants for the organisations involved in the trials and the federal department of health was responsible for the medical research policy at that time. So three Commonwealth organisations were involved, and for that reason alone the revelations to date justify some form of external investigation. The message the House can send to Minister Wooldridge and the message the House can send everyone in government is that governments should not be able to do things to people without making sure that people are properly informed and give proper consent for trials such as this. For that reason, the Labor Party strongly supports some form of an open, public, independent examinatio? of these issues. We want to make sure that It is thoroughly examined, not ignored. We want to make sure that it is independent, not some tame-cat departmental review. We also want to make sure that it is open, not carried out behind closed doors. The worse possible thing that can happen is for these serious allegations to be investigated by the people who might be at risk - f an adverse finding. It would also be hIghly undesirable if the Victorian and the federal departments of health and community services were to carry out some cursory and inadequate examination of these issues and to produce some departmental report that gets placed in a pigeon hole and gathers dust for years to come. An open and independent .inquiry can make sure that everyone can fmd out what actually happened. It can protect the medical records of individuals concerned. We can try to make sure that these issues are exposed to the light of day and we can find out what actually went on. To those people such as Jeff Kennett who say, 'This happened more than 40 years ago governand is not worthy of proper investigation,' I say that these tests were going on as late as 1970. These tests raise very serious issues that should be investigated by an independent and open inquiry. That is what the federal opposition will continue to seek from Dr Wooldridge.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: PRIVATE MEMBERS BUSINESS
text: Mr Nehl}-Is the motion seconded? Mr O'Keefe-1 second the motion.

Speaker: Dr SOUTHCOTT
Title: PRIVATE MEMBERS BUSINESS
text: Boothby) (1.36 p.m.)The clinical trials undertaken in postwar Melbourne on infants and children seem shocking by today's standards. The issues raised are complex and it is important to separate the distress of former wards of the state from whether any harm was done and whether the Commonwealth or state laws were complied with at the time. There are some problems in investigating this issue. The length of time that has expired, the fact that some of the people conducting the research are now deceased and the lack of documentation given on things like the consent procedures mean that we have to now rely on oral evidence. However, I do not believe that what is required is for the government to establish an independent inquiry. The Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) has already asked for a report from the Department of Health which should be available this week. Preliminary analysis of the case studies in the Age suggests that the studies were conducted carefully with no significant injury to the study participants, although there is that case that was mentioned at an international conference in 1972 and I will get on to that later. It is wrong to ascribe the standards of 1990s to research carried out in an earlier time. Vaccination is, after all, the result of an experiment. If we thought today how we would judge the inoculation of an 8 year-old child with a potentially fatal injection, we would say that that was unacceptable. But yet, without that injection back in the 18th century, we would never have seen the eradication of smallpox. After all, it was Edward Jenner who made the observation that milkmaids were not infected by smallpox: he decided to give an injection, firstly of cowpox, to an 8 year-old boy and then later to inject him with smallpox, an infection that was usually fatal. In 1796 he performed the first vaccination intentionally inoculating an 8 year-old boy, James Phipps, with material from the cowpox lesions of a dairymaid, Sarah Nelmes. When he variolated Phipps on 1 July-that is giving him the smallpox-he had no response at all. Mr Lee--I hope he got his parents' permission.

Speaker: Dr SOUTHCOTT
Title: PRIVATE MEMBERS BUSINESS
text: The member for Dobell raises an interesting point, because I cannot recall whether he did seek consent from the parents. He certainly did not go to an ethics committee and it is very unlikely that he would have been able to have obtained anything like informed consent, given that that was the first procedure. Thinking about smallpox, it is interesting to remember that smallpox is an example of the successful eradication of an infectious disease. The last case outside a laboratory was in Somalia in 1977 and, tragically, the last couple of people to die of smallpox were people who were accidentally exposed to laboratory specimens. The World Health Organisation actually announced the eradication of smallpox from the world in 1980. When I was studying paediatrics in the late 1980s, the bible of paediatrics had actually eliminated the entry for smallpox. They just had, 'Smallpox, see previous editions.' It was thought that there was no need to know the clinical features of smallpox. To say that we should not ascribe the standards of the 1950s to the 1990s is not to condone earlier practices which were unacceptable at that time. In looking at the trials in post-war Melbourne, you cannot compare them with some of notorious trials that we have read about recently in medical history. Recently President Clinton gave an apology to African Americans who were infected with syphilis to observe its clinical effects. That is an horrific example of a trial that is unacceptable and inhumane, given that, at the time, there were simple treatments available for syphilis. Other examples include children with Down Syndrome who were infected with hepatitis, the exposure of service personnel to radiation or the withholding of treatment in clinical studies for people with things like cervical cancer and so on. When you look at the time, it was possible for people to have better treatment. It was possible for these things to be done better. Looking at trials of vaccines and drugs, they are a lot more difficult to judge. It was a different era, when you think back. People like Alan Marshall could write about their experiences of childhood polio. The longest serving US president was someone who was also afflicted by childhood polio. How many statesmen and authors today have been struck down by those childhood diseases? None. School sporting events were being cancelled in the 1940s and early 1950s due to polio epidemics. Children were still dying of things like diphtheria and whooping cough. In my time working in paediatrics I only ever saw one case of Whooping cough, which had come from Ernabella, one of Aboriginal communities. Children were being born to mothers who were infected by rubella in their first term. Children were born with problems like mental retardation, cataracts and deafness. It is not widely known that it was an Australian ophthalmologist who drew the connectionthat it was congenital rubella that these infants were contracting that actually led to that syndrome. When you think back to the 1950s, there were some landmark improvements and advances. Firstly there was the development by Salk of the first polio vaccine, which was in an injectable form, and three or four years' later there was the development by Sabine of the oral polio vaccine. We owe a lot to those pioneering researchers who gave us safe and accessible vaccines today. The studies that were carried out in Melbourne were not secret. They were published in academic journals at the time. As the chairman of the National Health and Medical Research Council, Richard Larkins, has said: There is no evidence that the procedures were improper. It appears that the legal guardians of the children gave their consent, although the concept of 1950s informed consent is different to what it is today. Unfortunately, there is no explicit detail in the research on how the informed consent was obtained. I will quote from the Bulletin of 24 June 1997 which states: Walter and Eliza Hall spokesman David Vaux insists vaccine trials conducted by the institute not experiments, but potentially lifesaving treatments. 'At the time, consent was given by the sisters in charge who brought in medical professionals because children at the orphanages were dying,' he argues. 'In the '50s, people were more terrified of these infectious diseases than we are today of AIDS.' There is no evidence that anyone was harmed or that any state or Commonwealth laws were breached. While it is a sad indictment of the era that many of the children were from orphanages, there were other children who were also involved in the trials-presumably with the consent of their parents.

Speaker: Mr SERCOMBE
Title: STATEMENTS BY MEMBERS
text: My electorate of Maribyrnong has a very large Italian community. It is a community that is ageing and, sadly, in recent days three very distinguished members of the community have passed away. Mr Sam di Pasquale of Avondale Heights was honoured by the Italian Republic with the honour of CavalIere. He was a man of very substantial cultural achievements. The requiem mass for him today will feature the Banda Bellini, with which he was associated, playing Verdi's 'Va Pensiero' from the opera Nabucco. It will be a very moving experience and he will be sorely missed. Mr Joe Prato also passed away in recent  had a large family in the area. He played a very extensive role in the local Italian community. Also, within a day of the other deaths, Mr Luigi Guerra passed away. Mr Guerra of Airport West was the president of were the Airport West senior citizens Italian club. He made a distinguished contribution to the life of the Italian community in that multicultural part of Melbourne. All three of these gentlemen had also been distinguished members of the Australian Labor Party and they will be sadly missed by the party as well as by the local community, particularly the local Italian community. It is with great sadness that I bid them farewell. Journalistic Standards

Speaker: Mr BROADBENT
Title: STATEMENTS BY MEMBERS
text: My community has been sorely disappointed with recent events in Gippsland. We have lost a little boy and the community of Gippsland is heartbroken. Newspaper journalists, allegedly covering the tragedy concerning a missing child near Moe, have been guilty of some of the worse journalist negligence I have ever had the misfortune to be aware of. Sunday's Herald-Sun did not even know which town it was reporting on. The editorial on page 44 has a photograph of the town of Morwell, captioned 'Moe struggles for a future'. But Paul Heinrich's article published in Saturday's Age was a classic of misinformation coupled with gross journalistic negligence. He alleges that the region lost 18,000 jobs due to restructuring. Whilst unemployment is bad-ministers and I have discussed the issue-I believe that 8,000 jobs lost would be nearer the mark. Even the tabloids have rounded the figure off to 10,000 while the DSS in Morwell, the main centre for Gippsland, has fewer than 6,000 on social security benefits. Heinrich's article talks about lost services and how the old Town Hall has had to close due to lack of maintenance. More than 750,000 was spent last year bringing the Town Hall up to a spectacular standard-and it was re-opened months ago. The article claims the DSS office in Moe has closed. Not one person in the management of the DSS in Morwell can recall there having been a DSS office in Moe to close down. The Age claims that Melbourne's single parent mothers are being dumped in Moe but this is not supported by a single fact. It claims that battles to collect drug debts are not uncommon. If they are not uncommon then it must be suggesting that they are common. But that is not so, according to the Moe police and the community. Emotive language, false and misleading information, and kicking a community while it is down would be about as un-Australian and anti-Gippsland as one can get. The most accurate part of this report was its first line, 'Something is rotten in the town of Moe.' What is rotten are the ethics and standards of some of the visiting journalists. For a newspaper that once had a reputation for journalism, I would suggest that the Age is now in more trouble than Moe will ever be. Like any backbencher, I am always seeking more for my electorate. I have to concede that while we have been given more than $380,000 to help with a pilot program to assist homeless youth, we have $30,000 to help youth in Trafalgar and we have a new DSS telespike centre, with construction starting next Monday and with more than 100 jobs to come from that. (Time expired) Tait, Mr Norm

Speaker: Mr MOSSFIELD
Title: STATEMENTS BY MEMBERS
text: I rise to congratulate Mr Norm Tait for his service to the New South Wales education system. Norm will soon retire as the principal of a major high school in Greenway, Grantham High. In his 42 years in the New South Wales education system, he has spent 13 years at Grantham, the last seven as principal. Norm's achievements as an educator and educational leader stand out. Norm was one of the pioneers in teaching engineering science as Asquith while, at Macksville, Norm started an Aboriginal night-time study school at Nambucca Heads. Also at Macksville, while head teacher, Norm introduced courses with community involvement, in automotive technology and photography. During Norm's time at Grantham, he was instrumental in beginning links with the local TAFE. These links were later developed into the existing state-wide JSST program. Norm had the foresight to develop Grantham's technology courses to a high standard as well as maintaining a broad curriculum. Students there have access to the study of two languages, German and Indonesian; a four-elective line structure in years 9 and 10; and a wide range of senior courses including one unit courses. Norm's ability to manage resources is evident in a well maintained school. He achieved a sensitive balance between financing educational programs and administration needs, while enhancing the physical environment of the school.

Speaker: Ms WORTH
Title: STATEMENTS BY MEMBERS
text: From 9 to 13 July, under the auspices of the UN General Secretary, Mr Kofi Annan, the President of the Republic of Cyprus, Mr Clerides, will meet with the Turkish Cypriot leader, Mr Denktash. This is a new start for direct negotiations on a solution of the Cyprus question. It is my hope that this new process will provide the appropriate results leading to a just solution and also safeguard the independence and sovereignty of the Republic of Cyprus. I hope that the fundamental freedoms and human rights of all Cypriots will be high on the agenda in these discussions and that Turkey will be able to compromise to ensure a speedy solution to the Cyprus question. After 23 years of foreign occupation of more than one-third of Cyprus, the international community should apply the necessary pressure upon Turkey to withdraw its troops from Cyprus and accept the proposition of President Clerides for a re-united and demilitarised Cyprus. The whereabouts of the 1,619 Greek Cypriots missing since the invasion of Cyprus in 1974 remains an important issue for resolution, as does allowing the 200,000 refugees to return to their homes and to enjoy the freedoms and human rights which should be accorded to all of us. Comerford, Mr Jim: Coal and coloninls

Speaker: Mr ROBERT BROWN
Title: STATEMENTS BY MEMBERS
text: I want to pay tribute today to Mr Jim Comerford of Weston in New South Wales. On Saturday, at Fort Scratchley in Newcastle, Bob Hawke, a former Prime Minister, launched a book that has just been written by Jim Comerford called Coal and Colonials. Jim Comerford arrived in Australia from Scotland with his parents at the age of eight. In a few weeks time he will tum 84. He left school at the age of 13 and went into employment at the Richmond main colliery, the largest coalmine in the coal mining empire in Australia of John 'Baron' Brown. He became a lodge officer and became, as well, the northern president of the miners federation and the general secretary of the miners federation. He became a union and local historian. He has published books. He contributed towards Cyprus Mines, Wines and People. Coal and Colonials is his most recent book. He is the holder of an Order of Australia award and he also holds an honorary Master of Arts degree from the University of Newcastle. Jim Comerford is and has been a remarkable person. Bob Hawke maintained that, given other opportunities, Jim Comerford was one of those working class people who would have risen to even greater heights. He is a man of great courage, of intellectual substance and depth, of personal achievement, with leadership qualities and capacity. He is a great inherited son of the northern coalfields and a great leader of men and communities. People's Convention

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: STATEMENTS BY MEMBERS
text: I want to take this opportunity of condemning the action of the opposition parties in the Senate in rejecting the government's bill to facilitate a voluntary postal vote for the People's Convention. Prior to the last election we decided that we would give the Australian people the form of government they want, rather than seek to impose a form of government upon them in the way that the former government sought to do. We believe that it is inappropriate that there should be a compulsory ballot for election of the delegates to the People's Convention because the convention itself will not decide whether Australia is going to be a republic, and any proposals brought forward at the People's Convention would have to be put to the people at a referendum. The vote at such a referendum would be a compulsory ballot. The other point that ought to be noted is that we will save some $15 to $20 million through a voluntary postal ballot. It is a matter of shame that at successive elections a number of Australians have actually been gaoled for failing to vote. We believe that, given the nature of the constitutional convention, it would be entirely undemocratic and inappropriate for Australians to be gaoled for choosing not to vote for the People's Convention. It ought to be noted also that in elections conducted by postal ballot a very high turnout has occurred. The opposition is to be condemned. I would ask at this late stage that they change their minds so that we are able to deliver on a core election promise. (Time expired) Australian Taxation Office

Speaker: Mr DARGA VEL
Title: STATEMENTS BY MEMBERS
text: I ri?e to talk about a disturbing circumstance affecting one of my constituents, Mrs Margaret Hayden. She is an old age pensioner and she has been given the royal runaround by the Australian Taxation Office. She has yet to receive a determination for a 1996 tax return. This has caused her some distress in not knowing about her tax liability. Her file was sent to Sydney. She has been asked to supply details about her file that have already been submitted, leading me to believe that the tax office has lost that file. I wrote to the tax commissioner in the ACT on 7 May, whose office contacted me and assured me that the matter would be resolved very quickly and apologised for the delay. It is now 23 June, some six weeks later. The matter is still unresolved. She received a Tax pack last week for this financial year. We would like the ATO to resolve her tax return from previous years. 'Stolen children' inquiry

Speaker: Mr RANDALL
Title: STATEMENTS BY MEMBERS
text: I, like many other good Australians, am sick of seeing the Labor members of this House stand up and read largely unnamed and anonymous extracts from the so-called 'stolen children' inquiry. I will put on the record two local letters to the editor which give an honest balance to the largely secretive reports that the Labor sycophants are reading into Hansard. The first letter states: We are hearing a lot about the stolen generation Aborigines and also in respect to orphans and homeless children brought out to Australia from Liverpool and other parts of England after the war. Some of these had very unfortunate experiences; others had a successful life. Kind, considerate well-meaning people of this generation are adopting orphans and homeless children from Vietnam and other parts of South East Asia. What is going to be said of these kind people in 30 years? Are they going to be accused of depriving these children of their own culture? The letter was written by F. Edwin Dick of Quindalup, Western Australia. The second letter states: My parents were not wealthy. In fact, when dad's smaIl business went down the tube, we were quite poor. Mum managed though, managed very well. She loved her Methodist church and belonged to the women's guild. Each month she would scrimp and save to buy sweeties, to buy ingredients to make cookies, to buy wool to knit jumpers and socks. We kids were furious. No, they were not for us. Each month she and her guild would go the Mogumber mission and take the goodies to give the kids there; to give to the 'stolen kids' to make their lives a bit better. Rest easy up there, mum, you thought you were doing the right thing. That letter was written by Marian Halse from Waterford in Western Australia. (Time expired) Industrial relations

Speaker: Mr FITZGIBBON
Title: STATEMENTS BY MEMBERS
text: I warned in my first speech in this place that the government's then proposed Workplace Relations Act would wreak havoc in the coal mining industry and would undermine investment opportunities. Unfortunately, my fears have become reality. On Saturday I visited those holding the picket line outside Coal and Allied's Hunter Valley No. I mine. Four hundred and forty men, mainly members of the United Mine Workers, but also members of the Electrical Trades Union and the Australian Workers Union, have now been on strike for almost two weeks. And why, Mr Speaker? The easiest way to explain might be to say that Coal and Allied is a subsidiary of Rio Tinto. Who is Rio Tinto? It should come as no surprise to members-CRNRTZ, ala Weipa. For two years the CFMEU has been trying of to finalise an enterprise agreement with the company. But the company is not interested in finalising an agreement with the union. It wants to break the back of the union and go and to individual contracts. It is individual agreements the company seeks and it is the demise of the CFMEU's strength it desires. On Saturday I took some pretty simple messages to those men manning that picket line, and they were these: that they enjoy my support, that they enjoy the support of the Australian Labor Party but, more importantly, that they enjoy the support of the communities from which they come.
