Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. Minister, could you inform the House of the details of the Hawk lead-in fighter trainer contract to be signed tomorrow and of the benefits which will flow through to the Hunter, in particular my electorate of Paterson, and other regions throughout Australia?

Speaker: Mr MCLACHLAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Mr SPEAKER

Speaker: Unknown
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Opposition members interjecting

Speaker: Mr MCLACHLAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I will tell you in a minute, if you would like to listen. I can inform the House that tomorrow the Department of Defence and the British Aerospace Australia officials will sign a contract in Canberra for a lead-in fighter and support package for the Royal Australian Air Force. Mr Bevis-That is the one you announced in November last?

Speaker: Mr MCLACHLAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Yes, and I will tell you about how it has improved a bit since then. The signing will conclude the contract negotiation phase and will provide for 33 Hawk aircraft under unique arrangements, which include a support package and Australian industry involvement for in-country support for the aircraft and the systems over the whole 25-year life of the aircraft. Total value of the contract is around $850 million. But there is a new contractual approach requiring tenderers to assess the number of aircraft to meet the RAAF's training needs and to develop a support package and an Australian industry program. The final contract guarantees the provision of logistic and maintenance support for 75 months, with renewal options throughout the whole 25-year life of the aircraft as well as through-life maintenance guarantee for the Rolls-Royce Adour engine. What is important about this unique contract is that it provides known cost and guaranteed aircraft availability for a predetermined number of aircraft on line daily throughout the life of the contract. There will be, of course, very obviously significant benefits to the Hunter and other regions. The work in Australia related to the contract is now up to 35 per cent of the total contractup from the 27 per cent announced in November, which should interest the member for Brisbane, when I announced the preferred tenderer. In the maintenance and support phase of the contract, there is a target of just under 80 per cent for Australian industry. A major new facility will be built on leased land at Newcastle. That will be to assemble 21 of the 33 aircraft and to provide ongoing maintenance. Some 150 jobs will be created in constructing those facilities and between 80 and 100 jobs ongoing in aircraft assembly. In fact $60 million will be expended in the Newcastle region directly during construction and in the seven-year support phase. More than $400 million will be spent on maintenance support in Australia from 2007 until 2025. Other states-Dbviously SA, Victoria and Western Australia-will gain additional jobs throughout the contract. As a flow on, and importantly, British Aerospace Australia, Qantas and Hawker de Havilland will be able to expect to competitively bid for support and maintenance of aircraft to be supplied to other Hawk operators in the Asia-Pacific. The contract will be signed tomorrow. It represents a new and advanced approach to defence acquisition and support. It brings with it very substantial benefits to the ADF, to the Hunter and to other regions of Australia which will benefit directly from the construction, the assembly and the through-life support and maintenance of this new lead-in fighter project. Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: No, I do not agree with the observations that were made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. I made it clear in the parliament last week and I make it clear again that the government is interested in broad based tax reform. What a broad based tax reform would obviously look at would be the indirect tax base and the income tax base. I made the point that a narrow indirect tax base means that, on those classes of goods within the net, the comparative taxation burden falls heavily and it is a declining base. I do not think there is any doubt about that. I also made the point that one of the corollaries of that is that, in relation to income tax, people in Australia are kicked into high marginal tax rates at low multiples of average weekly earnings. If you were going to design a better tax system, you would want a broader base in relation to indirect taxes and a broader base in relation to income taxes. The important point about that second observation I make is to ensure that everybody pays their fair share of income taxes. It is one of the reasons why our government ended R&D syndication. The Labor Party knew very well what R&D syndication was. It was available to rich people to minimise or walk away from their tax liabilities. Who stood with them? The Labor Party. The Labor Party should just think about this for a moment: one of the reasons why ordinary PAYE taxpayers have high marginal income tax rates is that you wanted to make it optional for high income earners to pay income tax. If you were above $185,000 on superannuation, you reduced your marginal tax rate from 47 to 15. From 47, you could bring it down to 15-a 32 per cent tax reduction. Speaker: Mr BARTLETT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government representing the Minister for the Environment. What is the government's reaction to recent international developments on the issue of greenhouse gas emissions? What position will the government be putting to the United Nations General Assembly when it next meets?

Speaker: Mr WARWICK SMITH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Macquarie for his question on an obviously very important issue. Senator Hill is in New York at present to put Australia's position on the climate change negotiations. I am pleased to report that there has been some progress that is positive to Australia's position. By way of background, Australia is very keen to play an active and constructive role in these negotiations on climate change as we search for a global solution to a very complex environmental problem. Our approach at the UN General Assembly meeting will be based on a need to deliver a response to climate change that is fair and equitable. We want to achieve this through a differentiation of developed country commitments which would ensure that international efforts to reduce emissions of greenhouse gasses result in similar economic impacts on countries. Other countries, however, have called for the adoption of legally binding emission reduction targets by developed countries. However, we have argued that it is premature to consider legally binding targets at a time when the level, time frame and costs associated with them are unknown. Over the last several days, in Denver, the Summit of Eight signifies that Australia is making encouraging progress in these negotiations. The Summit of Eight's communique refers to the new climate change agreement as needing to contain 'meaningful, realistic and equitable targets', of thus giving recognition to the key tenet of Australia's negotiating position, that is, the need for the equitable differentiation of country targets so that each country has a target that takes into account the economic realities of individual country's circumstances. This position of course is absolutely vital for Australia. We believe that the differentiation can deliver greater environmental effectiveness and equity. This is because the commitments that take into account national circumstances will be fairer, more realistic and, therefore, achievable. Greater achievability of commitments will strengthen the participation and contribution of countries to an effective environmental outcome. The final decisions will be taken in Kyoto, in Japan, in December. There is still some time to go until we get to that position. The Prime Minister's own discussions, while he is talking with Prime Minister Blair and President Clinton, will focus on some of these issues. Senator Hill, in his departing remarks about the position and the views that he would be taking in these vital discussions, said: We want to see a better global outcome, but we don't want to see Australia accept an unfair share of the burden. We don't want to see literally thousands of Australian jobs lost. That is the government's position. It is going well. Company Tax

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Treasurer. Given the enthusiasm of the Treasurer for broad based tax reform, will he direct his department to make available to members how much multinational companies actually pay in tax and detail the known strategies for minimising tax? Will he also have it make available a synopsis of the impact of a universal application of a debit tax and compare the effects to the application of a GST?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Under the Income Tax Act, it is forbidden, by law, to disclose the affairs of any individual taxpayer, for obvious reasons. In relation to known techniques for multinational companies to reduce their tax, there are numbers, of which transfer pricing is probably one of the most prevalent. In relation to transfer pricing, at my initiative the APEC and OECD sponsored a joint forum in Sydney last year. We are pursuing, through the APEC forum, ways to improve antiavoidance measures against transfer pricing. In relation to transfer pricing, you obviously need the cooperation of foreign countries as well as your own to get to the bottom of whether or not transfer pricing is occurring. Further, in the budget of May of this year, I announced measures to considerably tighten the rules in relation to foreign source income, essentially to narrow the list of countries to the G7 that are on the list of comparable tax jurisdictions and other changes in relation to accruals taxation measures. I can assure the honourable member that this government has been very active in ensuring that a fair share of income is paid in Australia by multinational companies trading in and outside this country. Having said all that, it is also important that Australia attracts foreign investment. Foreign investment is good for Australia. Foreign investment creates jobs. As far as this government is concerned, we are not going to walk down the isolationist path which tries to throw out foreign investment and job creation in this country . We know that there are other incipient political parties which have that view, but that is not a policy of this government. We welcome foreign investment in this country where it creates jobs. We are taking active measures to ensure that fair taxation is paid by those countries and, in accordance with the budget announcement, we will be having further legislation forthcoming in relation to that during the course of the year. Youth Allowance

Speaker: Mr ROSS CAMERON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Can the minister inform the House and constituents in my electorate of Parramatta of the opportunities available to young people to undertake education and training in preparation for real jobs? Is the minister aware of false and misleading claims by the Labor opposition that Commonwealth funding to schools is being reduced?

Speaker: Dr KEMP
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Parramatta for his question. I am quite sure he would have heard, as would many members of this House have heard over the weekend, the very wide support in his community for the youth allowance provisions which the government announced last week. The important thing about the youth allowance is that it sends the right message to young people. Up until now, the system which has been supported by the Labor Party has given young people a very damaging message: that it is all right to be trying to live on the dole and not preparing for their future through extended education and training. The youth allowance gets those incentives right. The Leader of the Opposition, I notice, has made some very bold statements about the youth allowance. We may as well have them on the record. It was reported in the Courier Mail on Friday that the Labor Party would throw the youth allowance out lock, stock, and barrel. He said that there were some issues on which it was 'too important to compromise.' Then later on he went on to say, 'This looks like something that we just reject outright.' This shows again exactly how out of touch the Labor Party is with the basic values of the Australian community. The Leader of the Opposition has a very short memory because, of course, we remember his statements to this House that the Labor Party would introduce a whole raft of amendments to the work for the dole legislation which they opposed and did not like. We know that the Leader of the Opposition is not the person who decides this in the Labor Party in the end. It is Senator Faulkner and Senator Sherry and, when it came to the crunch in the Senate this afternoon, that whole raft of amendments just disappeared because the senators were not prepared to go along with the views put by the Leader of the Opposition here in the House. Do we take your comments on the youth allowance as having exactly the same level of credibility? The member for Parramatta raised the question of statements that the government is planning to reduce funding for schooling. Speaker: Mrs ELSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Will the Treasurer advise the House of the number of Australian families the who will benefit from the government's family tax initiative introduced on 1 January and 1997? How can Australian families access these benefits?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Forde for her question. The introduction of the family tax initiative was an introduction of the government's tax commitment before the last election on time, in full, on budget on 1 January 1997. As far as the coalition government is concerned, it took great pleasure in being able to deliver from 1 January 1997 benefits to two million Australian families-two million Australian families benefited under the coalition's family tax initiative. About one million of those families that are low income families are able to access the family tax initiative through a payment made through the Department of Social Security. Most of those families have already been accessing that family benefit from 1 January 1997. For a family with at least one dependent child under five years of age who qualifies under the income means test-that is, their taxable income is less than $65,000-the benefits that are provided to them are: $19.20 for a family with at least one child under five years of age and going up to $34 per fortnight for a family with two children. These are direct benefits to families, which came into effect on 1 January 1997. But I raise it for another reason. For the other one million who can claim it through the income tax system, a number of them will have already filed PA YE instalment reductions to be receiving it as a bonus in reduced tax from their payments from 1 January 1997. But it is important for those families who did not lodge the instalment deductions that, when they come to complete their income tax return for the end of the financial year on 30 June 1997, they fill in that area applying to family tax initiative. For all of those families that have not received the benefit through their income tax instalment deductions who file their tax returns after 30 June 1997 will receive large refunds on their tax as a result of this government's family tax initiative. The good news for nearly one million Australian families, those who have not already claimed it, is that they will be receivArafat ing, in relation to their tax returns, large income tax refunds if they have dependent children and they qualify for the income test which, on average, starts at $70,000 per family. This is a government that can stand up to the Australian people and say that it is has now implemented or will shortly implement all of the income tax and tax undertakings that we made before the last election. We promised to reduce income taxes for families. It started on 1 January 1997. We promised small business capital gains tax rollover relief. It will start on 1 July. We promised to reduce the taxes on savings in this country and when we get that legislation through the parliament, if we can overcome Labor opposition, again in relation to tax reductions, that will be in place by 1 July of next year. This is a government that took its tax commitments seriously; which delivered on budget, in full and on time. This is a government which deliberately made sure that it did not follow in the footsteps of the shameful Labor performance over the l-a-w tax cuts and, as a result, this government can say to the Australian people concerning those undertakings that we take back to them for the tax reform cause in the future that they know we have a track record of delivering in full, on time, on budget. That is right. It is not a question of the l-a-w tax cuts, but a government which delivered in accordance with its commitments. Yasser Arafat

Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is minister aware of reports that bogus stress claims by Commonwealth public servants are costing the Australian taxpayer millions of dollars? What steps is the government taking to curtail excessive costs associated with stress claims?

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for O'Connor for his question.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Order! The Minister for Industrial Relations will resume his seat. The honourable member for Canberra on a point of order. Mr MCMullan-On a point of order, Mr Speaker, the question of stress claims to the Commonwealth and the government's initiatives to reduce stress claims is the subject of the Industrial Relations Amendment Bill which is on today's Notice Paper for debate today and, in so far as the question relates to that, Mr Speaker, I put to you that it is out of order.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I am listening to the answer very carefully; If it canvasses the debate, it will be ruled out of order, but thus far there is nothing to suggest that that will be the case.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The question relates to stress claims. The words 'stress claims' do not appear in that legislation. We obviously considered this matter before the question was asked. The answer that I have for the House is to say that, in fact, we are dealing with the issue of stress claims by both administrative and other means. For example, with the administrative measures, we have a stress claims management centre operating. We also have a preventative program in place which is to deal with that issue. To put this issue in context, occupational stress claims are generally high cost claims. While the number of accepted claims is dropping, the cost associated with those claims continues to rise. The average cost of a stress claim is $32,700 compared with $7,700 for other claims. In this financial year, stress claims have cost the Commonwealth $35.7 million. What I am concerned about is the fact that, over time, people have claimed compensation in circumstances where it is fair to say that the injury is not in fact work the related. The previous scheme was not meant to compensate people for injuries which are not work related and particularly not for stress which arises out of legitimate human resource management action. I think members of the House would be interested in some of the stress claims which have been successful against the Commonwealth recently. For example, an employee claimed stress as a result of a grievance process. The situation was that a colleague had lodged a grievance against this employee and the investigating officer found that the employee had acted improperly. The employee was not happy about the result and has not been at work since mid-1995. A second claim relates to a circumstance where certain public servants were moving office and they were in temporary accommodation. An employee claimed for stress as a result of what she perceived to be an inappropriate comment in the workplace. The comment was made to the whole work group, but the individual said she found it personally offensive. I am told the words from the manager were to the effect that, whilst it was inconvenient for people to be moved from permanent accommodation to temporary accommodation, given the circumstances people would simply have to go through the exercise and wait and see. Strangely enough, the individual only lodged her claim when she was interviewed in relation to poor performance. The cost of this claim is approximately $190,000. Lastly, for the bike riders in the House, this claim will attract their attention. An employee claimed that work related stress aggravated a pre-existing knee injury. He underwent rehabilitation and was given modified duties. These duties required him to travel, so he claimed the cost of adding a sidecar to his motorbike to make it easier to ride. The cost to date in this claim, including the sidecar, is over $166,000. These are the general facts which have been provided to me by the relevant authority. These are the circumstances that we have inherited. We are dealing with the issue on an administrative as well as a preventative basis. What is interesting is that the Labor Party is opposed to the legislative changes necessary to fix up the mess which we inherited. Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs

Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The Treasurer is digressing.

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I am. I was also thinking about the timidity of the Labor Party on tax reform, after I read the Sunday Age, but that is a story for another day. This is a government that has had the welfare of self-funded retirees on its mind. It has put in place numbers of measures to help self-funded retirees. Mr Speaker, you will be aware that this is the government that announced the savings rebate: a rebate of up to $450 for a 15 per cent reduction on the marginal income tax rate, up to a ceiling, which is available to all people in Australia. You do not have to be in the work force to claim this, and you do not have to have your investments locked up in one narrow class such as superannuation. If you happen to be a self-funded retiree, you are eligible for this savings rebate. You can have your money in the bank, you can have it in stocks, you can have it in a business-you can have your money where you choose, and get a 15 per cent reduction in your marginal income tax rate. Who are the people who live predominantly on their investments in Australia: the self-funded retiree, the person that is actually retired. This government was very pleased to be able to announce a savings rebate to help them. That still has to go through the parliament, and we know the Labor Party is opposed to it. The Labor Party is opposed to measures helping self-funded retirees; the coalition is in favour of them. In last year's budget we announced that the pensioner tax rebate would be extended to non-pensioners. That meant that the way in which the taxation system worked against a self-funded retiree was abolished by the announcement in last year's budget. What this means is that commencing with a half rebate this year, for 1996-97 income, and a full rebate next year those self-refunded retirees who earn incomes in the range of $11,545 to $21,377 will get the same taxation treatment as pensioners. Prior to that announcement, if you happened to be a pensioner with a private income, you got a better tax deal than a self-funded retiree on exactly the same incomefor exactly the same income there were two rates of taxation. That was one of the changes that our government was able to put in place to help self-funded retirees. On 1 July this year, private health insurance incentives will come into play for self-funded retirees. People who are taking out private health insurance-they had no assistance whatsoever from the government before-will get $125 for singles and $250 for couples. They will get help to take out private health insurance. I want to underline one other thing for the people of Moreton. You quite often hear self-funded retirees complaining about low interest rates. Interest rates are low at the moment because inflation is low. Nothing helps a self-funded retiree more than low inflation. People do not realise that high inflation steals the value of your savings. Under an inflation rate of 10 per cent-which was quite common during the 1980s and 1990s-the real value of a fixed capital sum would erode, have, in seven years. Under two per cent inflation, the real value of a fixed capital sum erodes over 35 years. What low inflation does is protect the value of the savings of those people who have saved and are living off their savings. Even though nominal interest rates are not high as a consequence-in fact, they are extremely low in Australia at the moment-if you happen to be a self-funded retiree, the value is that your savings are not being whittled away by inflation. When you put together the pensioner rebate, the savings rebate, the private health insurance initiatives and low inflation, that adds up to an unmistakable message from this government: we are committed to helping self-funded retirees. We want to encourage people to say: savings are good for this country. Those people who have worked and have saved are not going to be forgotten by the coalition government. Speaker: Mrs DEANNE KELLY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: ANNE KELLY-My question is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. The Minister would be aware of the many petitions presented to this House drawing attention to an apparent anomaly in repatriation benefits eligibility for service personnel who served in particular overseas deployments, particularly with the Far East Strategic Reserve. Speaker: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Dawson for her question. I can say that I am aware of the number of petitions to this parliament over many years. In fact, this year there have been over 700 signatories to this parliament in the form of petitions related to the Far East Strategic Reserve. The government promised before the last election that we would review those anomalies. We have done that, particularly in relation to overseas deployments. The outcome of that review is that 10,500 veterans who were not previously recognised for their overseas deployment will now be recognised. They include service in the Far East Strategic Reserve in the Malaya Emergency. They also include the British Commonwealth occupation forces in Japan, which were not previously covered, in the period from 3 January 1949 through to 30 June 1951. That means that all those who served in the British Commonwealth occupation forces in Japan after the Second World War will now be covered. We also will be covering under new arrangements those who served at the Ubon air base in Thailand between 31 May 1962 and 31 August 1968. Nine other areas will also be covered as a result of our review into those perceived anomalies in relation to overseas deployment. They include the guards at the embassy in Vietnam and the RAAF's evacuation personnel in Vietnam from 12 January 1973 right through to 29 April 1975. These people will now be eligible for disability pensions and also health treatment where they have war injuries as a result of that service. They will also possibly be eligible for a Defence service homes loan. We said prior to the last election that we would review these areas of overseas deployment where there were perceived anomalies. We have done that. As a result, 10,500 veterans are now eligible for disability pensions and also health treatment for conditions they may have received as a result of that service. Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Adelaide for her question. I begin by warmly congratulating the member for Adelaide on having just been awarded the Nike award for her outstanding contribution to the Greek community in Australia. I am aware that the Australian Hellenic Council held its annual meeting this weekend in Canberra, and I am looking forward to meeting with the council during this evening. The Australian Hellenic Council is an umbrella organisation that represents a broad spectrum of the Australian Hellenic community and it has made a very important contribution to multicultural Australia. The government attaches a high priority to our relations with Greece, and that is obviously a matter of great interest to the Australian Hellenic Council. We made an election commitment to strengthen our relationships with Europe, including our relations with Greece, and I expect to make a visit to Greece in the not too distant future. Let me also say that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs will be visiting Greece, I think, in late July. Australia's warm and friendly relationship with Greece is underpinned by strong community links. Greek migrants have played an enriching role in this country, in particular in its cultural life as well as its economic life, since World War II, and there are other deep and abiding links, not least those forged during World War II in the Greek campaign of April 1941 and the battle of Crete. Because of these close links, Australia has an enduring interest in seeing a lessening of tension in the regions surrounding Greece. We are heartened by the constructive relationship that has now begun to develop between Greece and the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia by Greece's commitment to negotiate a solution to the differences that exist between it and its neighbours. The government is sensitive to concerns of communities in Australia which originate from both countries and has instituted a consultation process to enable the views and concerns of those communities to be heard. Let me say in conclusion that the government supports all efforts to achieve a peaceful and lasting solution in Cyprus. I very much hope that during this year we will see real and constructive progress on the issue of Cyprus. The government is keenly interested in the goal of a reunified Cyprus that is acceptable to both sides. I personally raised this issue with the United Nations Secretary-General, with the Presidency of the European Union and the President of Cyprus, Mr CIeri des, when I saw him in late January, early February this year. Earlier this month I issued a press release welcoming the appointment of Richard Holbrooke as the US Special Presidential Emissary on Cyprus and called on all parties to seize any opportunities available to negotiate a just solution. I have reiterated that Australia stands ready to lend all possible assistance to facilitate a solution. I have no allusions that this is going to be a very difficult matter to resolve. It is many years since the Turkish invasion of Cyprus. It is an issue on which the international community is going to have to work very hard. I have just mentioned the appointment of the US Special Presidential Emissary on Cyprus, Dick Holbrooke. The United States administration this year has given a particular focus to the issue. I know the European Union is as well and, as I mentioned, I have spoken to the United Nations Secretary General about this matter and he has made it clear that one of his highest priorities is going to be the resolution of the problem in Cyprus. Let us hope that we can see some progress during this year. I welcome the Hellenic Council to Canberra and look forward to seeing the council continue to play the constructive role it currently plays. Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs

NA NA Motion of Censure Motion (by Mr Beazley) proposed: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving forthwith: that this House censures the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs for misleading the House on his conversation with Mr Greiner and his continuing breach of the Ministerial Code of Conduct. Mr Reith-We will take the suspension and then have the debate on the censure motion.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS
text: Is the motion seconded? Mr Martin-I second the motion and reserve the right to speak. Question resolved in the affirmative, with an absolute majority.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS
text: I move: That this House censures the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs for misleading the House on his conversation with Mr Greiner and his continuing breach of the Ministerial Code of Conduct. What we are getting here today, as we got all last week, is a deliberate campaign by the Minister for Small Business and Consumer  clear-cut breach of the ministerial code of conduct. That obfuscation, in which he has been invited by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to dance around the point in clear breach of that ministerial code of conduct, has finally descended to this. This House now has been misled. This is one step further than the propositions that we were dealing with last week. What we dealt with last week was a total failure by this government-a complete abdication of its responsibility to see its ministerial code of conduct upheld. That code of conduct, which was there in existence when we were in office, which was there of course before we got into office and which has been a very long standing code of conduct, has among other provisions within that code of conduct a clear requirement that there should be no business activities other than the business of the portfolio conducted by ministers when they held that portfoliono business activities whatsoever; no ifs, no buts, no by your leave, no maybes, no perhapses, no in some circumstances-you will not while you happen to be a minister of this country conduct private business affairs. It becomes compounded further, because there are other provisions as well as that simple proposition, when what is added to that of course is the question of whether or not you maintain anything other than an armslength relationship with shareholdings and other activities. It is also taken a point further when there is a requirement upon a minister to ensure that, when he is in that arms-length position, he does not in fact benefit from any decisions that may be taken by his portfolio even where he is not concerned with the day to day management of those business affairs. This minister is in manifest breach of that. We had that two-faced Prime Minister of ours get up and effectively confirm that fact when, at the same time as he said there had been no breach of those standards, after t5 months he removed the minister from precisely the point of breach of those standards, that second layer of standards related to the fact that you should not only be just arms-length; you should not benefit. Of course when the Prime Minister did that he confessed the failure of his minister. He confessed the fact that the minister had failed to properly uphold that particular standard and he made movement on that front. Apart from understanding or believing that he cannot afford another ministerial loss that casts doubt upon his own personal integrity, what the Prime Minister clearly did not understand was that there are other problems as well. Last week we then had the minister getting up on his scrapers in this place and saying, 'While the Prime Minister has knocked me off very temporarily from questions relating to tenancy arrangements, I am still in charge of policy on franchising.' He was very proud of that fact when he got up and said, 'I'm still in charge of policy on franchising.' Of course, then we find that very large numbers of those tenants of his, who pay him rents, restore his family fortunes and establish his family fortunes and his own personal fortunes, are in fact franchisees. A direct conflict of interest yet again and this time an uncorrected-albeit belatedly uncorrected-piece of conflict of interest by the Prime Minister. All these faults are out there singing and dancing. All these skeletons are out of the cupboard. All of them have got their jawbones chattering across the stage of Australian politics as the skeletons run rife from this particular minister's background into the public domain. But what has not been out there singing and dancing yet from that chorus of skeletons of a set of propositions about honesty and integrity in this government has been the ultimate failure as far as this House is concerned-as opposed to simply matters of government propriety-that on matters related to your portfolio, in this case your personal interests associated with this portfolio, you have misled the House. What is more believable: your denial that you did anything other than ask for an exchange of addresses with Mr Greiner; or Mr Greiner's obvious common sense statement that, when he was asked for an address, he asked you, 'Why are you asking for the addresses of these coves; why are you asking for the addresses of these characters?' He did not think there was anything wrong in his saying that even though, having been a minister himself, he might have been alerted to some potential area of danger. He did not see in his own mind anything particularly wrong associated with that when he said that what you were interested in was a Target store in your Eaton shopping centre development. Why would you be interested in a Target store? We will get to the misleading element of that. But let us just set on the record as why you would be interested and why this is at the very heart of both your misleading of the parliament and your last weeks of selfconfession of a conflict of interest-or prime ministerial self-confession of a conflict of interest. If you are setting up a shopping centre, what would you want as the first store in it?

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS
text: A Target store.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS
text: If you can get a Target store, it is bankable; if you can place a Target store in your shopping centre, the entire other 20 or 30 stores in that shopping centre sing and dance around it. You can double the rents; you can put in your 10 per cent per annum escalated clauses; you can establish a profitable shopping centre, built at vast expense out of your personal fortune, for the people who are coming into your shopping centre; and you can ensure that you get a rate of return that justifies this in your own mind and that of anybody else-although there does not seem to be anybody else-who happens to be a shareholder in this arrangement. There is your brother but he seems to be exclusively concerned with protecting your interests, 95 per cent of which constitute the ownership status of this particular shopping centre development. You went to Greiner and you told Greiner that you wanted those addresses so that your brother could contact those people and put a Target store into your shopping centre. You come into this chamber trying to make light of the fact that the tenants in your already existing shopping centres find you a very close-working general manager as far as their affairs are concerned; a decent man no doubt; a good man; and a hands-on man. They find you to be one who is concerned about their welfare, one who, every weekend he is home, looks after the daily affairs of their centres and who even cleans up their rubbish. They think you are a terrific fellow. But what he is, in fact, as far as this parliament is concerned is not simply a terrific fellow. He is a person who has misled this parliament; he is a person who has breached ministerial standards; he is a person who is manifestly in breach of that requirement that to you do not mix your private affairs with your ministerial portfolio and that you exit it if you do so. It is a tough requirement. There is no question about that. It is an extraordinarily tough requirement on somebody who has decent interests that he has built up for himself over the years. I know the honourable member slightly but many in Western Australia know him well. They know him as a person who has built up a considerable personal fortune. He has done that with, in some circumstances, relative decency shown to the people with whom he has treated. We know all that about him. We know one other thing about him, and it is confirmed here time and time again. This is not a man who, having worked so hard to establish those things, establishes himself at a point distant from them. He is not a man who would do that. That 95 per cent ownership that he sustains in all of that is a real ownership. It is a managerial, hands-on ownership. It is an ownership that he cannot let go of because he rightly holds fears that, were he to do so, what goes out the window is his own personal fortune. It is not the sort of arms-length relationship that you would establish with BHP shares or something else down the line where there is a whole managerial substratum out there managing the position that you happen to be in.

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS
text: This is not a blind trust.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS
text: This is not a blind trust. Nobody, in the mind of the honourable member, can be trusted with this beyond himself. He is not actually personally capable of making a judgment between the requirement upon him for an arms-length relationship with this and his own concerns for what is going to happen with that particular business affair of his. He is not in a position to be to do that. That is the simple, sad fact of the matter.

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS
text: You need to get a better lawyer than the Treasurer. He will not save you. Get a criminal lawyer!

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS
text: Order! The member for Banks!

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS
text: We could have sympathy with a person in those circumstances. We could have a great deal of sympathy with a man in those circumstances where he has worked so hard to build that fortune. But there are choices to be made in public life. One of the choices imposed upon us is that we extract ourselves from anything which might either distract us from the ministerial duties that we intend to take up from time to time if given the opportunity, or from anything which might place in the minds of anyone out there who might have to deal with us as a minister a question mark over whether or not we are handling these matters with ultimate, pristine integrity and absolute disinterest as far as one's own affairs are concerned in relation to decisions at which we might arrive. It is not as though these are not areas of controversy. This is at the very heart of the bitterness of the Australian small business community. The Australian small business community--{;ontrary to what the Treasurer (Mr Costello) might like to have us believedoes not spend its life thinking about the capital gains tax regime; it does not. It does not spend its life thinking about the fact that the government may have once promised to reduce 50 per cent of the red tape-and wondering how on earth you measure that; small business people do not spend their waking hours thinking of that either. What small business thinks about is basically its relationship to big business; it thinks about its relationship to vertically integrated suppliers; it thinks about its relationship to the people who own the shopping centres; it thinks about its relationship to the franchisor when it happens to be a franchisee in what is the fastest growing area of small business in this community now-that is what small able business thinks about. That is what small business is indeed obsessed with. That is why small business, even more vehemently than we in this chamber, has repeatedly been asking for the removal of this minister from handling their affairs, because small business understands that the minister cannot bifurcate his mind in the affairs that he administers in relation to them. They understand as they deal with this minister that this is a minister who has embedded in his consciousness-it is the position of the shopping centre owners vis-a-vis themselves-his view of the rights of the franchisors as opposed to the franchisees. He has this understanding from his deep personal day-today operations, and they do not trust him. They do not trust him as a result of that. They are up in arms and amazed that they cannot get the sympathy of a government that wraps itself in a small business flag every time it gets up on its scrapers in this place. They cannot understand that it is a government that sings the tune but does not seem to know the words. The tune for small business comes out, but the words that come out are all wrong because the words that come out have nothing to do with what the interests of small business actually are. The words that come out are front and centre words which are a bitter pill. When they think they are going to get a bit of justice for oppressive conduct, when they think they are going to get a bit of justice for the franchisees, what comes out is obfuscation and delay. When a reference is placed before the parliamentary committee and when the parliamentary committee picks up what everybody knows small business most wants, the minister comes out so fast off the blocks with: 'Even though I said this was a matter of Commonwealth concern, it is not really; it is for the states. And even though I said you shall put forward a reference which relates to a code of conduct as far as tenancies are concerned I will not be pursuing that. I will not legislate.' That was his initial reaction. They know what he thinks and they know why he thinks it. They know that it is not a product of the disinterest of somebody standing at arms-length from what is going on, but the interest of somebody who cannot help himself because his claws are right there in the middle of it, whether he likes it or not. Unfortunately for this minister, he has not comprehended that in the extraordinarily difficult circumstances in which he finds himself he has a requirement here to be very careful in the way in which he answers questions. He has not been. What he has to do when he answers in this place defending the indefensible is not take his error a point further-not take his error to the point where he actively misleads this House. He has to be extraordinarily careful about this. He probably would have been better placed in terms of his own interests had he stood up in this place and said: 'I know nothing, I see nothing, I do nothing, I answer no questions.' It would be better for him to get up in this place and refuse to answer. But the minister has answered. The minister was being advised by the Treasurer, who may or may not have his best interests at heart, and the Leader of the House (Mr Reith), who mayor may not have his best interests at heart. It must be said that when we saw his defence last week a question mark can been placed over whether or not he has the minister's best interests at heart. He was advised by them and by his bush lawyers that as far as this item is concerned what he ought to do is leave himself with enough ice to skate on. But he did not. He said: 'I have gi ven full detail on this matter.' He has not given full detail on this matter. Mr Greiner is absolutely believable when he says, 'He discussed with me.' It is not as though we have not given him an opportunity to rule it out, to deny it-to do whatever it is that he wants to do to get himself out of this. We have given him every opportunity. Three times he has come to this dispatch box-four times, if you count the answer that he gave last week-and he has obfuscated every time on a simple proposition. Why would he want to deny it? Why would he want to deny Mr Greiner's statement of the obvious? Because if he fails to deny Mr Greiner's statement of the obvious, any conceivable pretence that he is not a hands-on manager of his 95 per cent personally owned operation of three shopping centres is straight out the door. We think it is straight out the door for other reasons. We think it is straight out the door on the testimony of his tenants. We think it is straight out the door on the Prime Minister's two-faced action of denying it on the one hand and actually doing it on the other, effectively ripping it off him. We think that ought to be enough for right-thinking people. We think that a common sense prime minister should be prepared to shed somebody who, whilst a nice bloke, is not much chop as a minister under any set of circumstances. We think that this is an eminently jettisonable minister. We think that in those circumstances, where you had somebody who was a bit stronger than this Prime Minister-who is rapidly emerging as one of the weakest around this region and one of the weakest this country has had since Billy MCMahon, with whom he competes-we would get from the Prime Minister a discarding of his minister, as there should be. We think that would have been sufficient. But it is not sufficient. We are obliged to build more on top of it. The problem for this minister is that he gives us more and more. It was not a matter simply left to his brother. It was not a matter simply left to the managers of his business apart from his brother. He told Mr Greiner, utterly believably, that his brother, who is his manager, who manages affairs that he owns 95 per cent of, wanted to discuss with him what single decision could be taken to establish the total financial viability of his store-the movement of a Target centre into it. If you think that there has not been a bitter precedent around here for what happens when you act in this way for relatives, apart from anything that directly interests you, contrast your position with that of a former Minister for Health, Senator Richardson-not acting for his own interests, not acting for something from which he profits, not acting in relation to something directly in his own purview as a minister, but simply as a minister. What did Senator Robert Hill say as Senator Graham Richardson left the affairs of this state, when a government with a bit of guts took a stand? He said this: He was making that contact on behalf of his cousin for no other purpose than to use his status, his stature as a Minister of the Crown in this government, to seek advantage, maybe, for his friend in the Marshall Islands. 'Advantage, maybe, for his friend'. He was sacked for that. But it was not his friend who administered his business affairs. It was not his friend who walked into that place and said, 'I want a Target shop in my shopping centre.' Out went Richardson. Out you should go! You have misled the House. You have breached the prime ministerial standard of conduct. You are lucky in that we have a weak, worthless Prime Minister who cannot comprehend that fact and therefore you survive. But this House must be made of sterner stuff. You breached his code of conduct, but now you have breached the oldest standing order, the oldest rule of conduct for a minister in this House-you have misled us, and you should go! (Time expired). Speaker: Mr MARTIN
Title: AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS
text: Cunningham) (3.45 p.m.)As we have said on a number of occasions, and as I have said publicly on radio, and as I have said to any person who would want to listen, this particular issue is not, as the Minister for Small Business and Consumer  of envy. It is not about the minister's children and him visiting shopping centres. It is abouL ministerial conduct. It is about his position as a minister of the Crown and, importantly, it is about the standards and the code of conduct which the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has set for ministers in the government. On each one of those particular counts, this minister has been charged and, we believe, found guilty of misleading, of engaging in conduct which is absolutely contrary to the Prime Minister's guidelines and of engaging in conduct which, by any standards set by this or any other previous government, should result in this minister's removal. In the course of this particular debate this afternoon, and in the course of question time, on three separate occasions a charge was put to this minister to deny the substance of the question that was put to him last week and again put to him today. That question was: did he raise with the Nick Greiner-the Deputy Chairman of the Coles Myer board, former Liberal Premier of New South Wales and not an insignificant person in Australia's commercial background today-issues about the development of a Target store at a greenfield site at Eaton, Bunbury, Western Australia, which the minister for small business owned? That was the question that was asked three times This today and, on three occasions, the minister refused to answer. He refused also to substantiate his claims that he had done nothing wrong or, indeed, to answer that question in the 15 minutes in which he has responded to this censure motion. He would not answer that question in this place today. He would not answer it three times in question time. He must now answer to the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer). The Acting Prime Minister must go outside this place-I see he is in deep conversation with the minister now-and he must call him around to the oval office. He must sit the minister down and have one of those little chats that the Prime Minister and ministers are becoming famous for in this government. If he does not satisfy himself as the Acting Prime Minister that this minister has done nothing wrong, then he too has failed this parliament. I know that this Acting Prime Minister puts great faith in this parliament. He is one of the very few people that I can recall in times gone by that has actually stood in this place and spoken at length about the great traditions of parliament, about the roles and responsibilities of ministers in this place and about the fact that if ministers mislead, either deliberately or unintentionally, there are remedies to fix that particular issue. I say to the Acting Prime Minister: I am relying on that integrity that I know you have in respect of this matter. What is the issue at heart here? The issue is very simple. There is a code of ministerial conduct that this Prime Minister brought down and has given to each of his ministers and requires of them absolute adherence. One of those particular codes says: Ministers must be honest in their public dealings and should not intentionally or the public. That is what this issue is about today. It is about whether or not this minister has misled this parliament. The basis of the charge that has been laid is quite simple: it is conflicting evidence given in various newspaper reports and this minister's refusal to answer questions in the parliament. He mocked the newspaper article when he said that if I read on I would find that something was completely different. Let me refer to one of those articles. The Australian, on Friday, 20 June 1997, contained the headline 'Prosser admits seeking help for family business'. The article said:  Mr Greiner "four or five months ago to ask for a contact name in Coles Myer for my brother". The same article, one paragraph later, said:  the only contact he had with the Coles Myer directors since becoming a minister had been social. Two days before, he told a journalist from the Australian, 'Yes, I had met with some directors of Coles Myer, but it was social.' He is quoted as saying, 'Four or five months ago I asked for a contact name in Coles Myer for my brother.' Is that significant? Indeed it is, because again the ministerial code of conduct is very specific on this. The ministerial code of conduct says: Ministers are required to divest themselves of all shares and similar interests in any company or business involved in the area of their portfolio responsibilities. We have established that retail tenancy, franchising and other recommendations contained in the fair trading inquiry report come within the ambit of responsibility of the minister for small business. And he has been in the newspapers over the weekend, he has been on radio and he has re-established that fact. This therefore can be no clearer. It is in absolute breach of that. If that does not satisfy this minister, the other sentence in that code says: The transfer of interests to a family member or to a nominee or trust is not an acceptable form of mislead the parliament divestment. Minister, you stand up in this place and say, 'My brother does all the work.' The company records show that you, your brother and your wife are the people who own all of the businesses with which we are concerned. This guideline captures the very essence of what we are saying. Your brother, in your own words, as your manager, is carrying out work on your behalf. Your constituents, your tenants, say that you walk around on weekends. You say you are going down to buy some milk with your kids. That might well be so, but they say that you are there, you are friendly. You have hands on, as you admitted yourself on a small business program a couple of weeks ago. Then you go on to say that there is no contradiction, that social conduct and contact names to you are one and the same thing. Minister, you are the one who goes on television, who goes into the media and says that you believe in voluntary codes when it comes to dealing with small business. You go on and say, 'I don't believe in legislative underpinning. I don't believe that we need to have support for small businesses other than voluntary codes.' Minister, you believe in voluntary codes because you think it is voluntary to comply with them. On this particular occasion, the voluntary code and the voluntary compliance that you have are the Prime Minister's code of conduct. You take these, you snub them, you basically give the old-fashioned two-finger salute to them in the face of your Prime Minister and you say, 'I have dealings on new shopping centres that I own in my town of Bunbury. I want to get a new shopping centre with a Coles Myer tenant, that is, Target, and I'm quite happy to raise with deputy chairs of Coles Myer my concerns of the need to find contact people.' Then you come along to this parliament and, if not denying it, which you have done in this place, simply refuse to answer. And you expect us to tum around and say, 'Oh well, that's all right, Minister. You must be right. You haven't got the day-today running of your business.' That does not mean you are there every day, Minister. You seem to be under the misapprehension that the prime ministerial guidelines require that you be in the office in Bunbury every day doing the work. That is not it at all. So long as you have some role to play-and you have admitted that you do through your brother and through your companies-you are caught by this code. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) made some comment about a comparison with what happened in the case of Graham Richardson. I think it is instructive to look at that for a moment. When Graham Richardson was Minister for Health, he also made a telephone call in which he asked for a favour for a distant cousin, as I recall. It is interestgo ing and instructive to see what the now Prime Minister, the weakest Prime Minister in the history of Australia, had to say at the time. Back on 7 May 1992, in the parliamentary debate on whether there should be a suspension of standing orders to deal with the Marshall Islands affair, the now Prime Minister said: The Australian people will judge this Prime Minister on the standard of probity that he is prepared to defend. It could be the same bloke. He goes on: The supreme test of the courage and probity of the Prime Minister is whether he insists on Ministers observing the basic requirements of a Minister, that is, that they tell the Parliament the truth. John Winston Howard, 7 May 1992: The Prime Minister ought to be in here explaining Senator Richardson's lapse. So too should this Prime Minister. He continued: Better still, he ought to be hopping in the car, going out to Yarralumla and withdrawing Senator Richardson's commission. It is with great pleasure I second the motion. To do much what we are doing today. Acting Prime Minister, those words are the words of your Prime Minister when faced with exactly the same dilemma. The only situation that is different now is that this Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, who has hands-on involvement with his companies, contrary to the ministerial guidelines, also has responsibility for taking to cabinet and implementing the recommendations of the fair trading inquiry report, contrary to ministerial guidelines, and has responsibility for reporting in this parliament on questions raised about standards of conduct and ministerial probity and has the responsibility to respond in this parliament under our Westminster tradition. On each of those particular charges, this minister fails. Yet back in 1992, when pursuing a similar issue, this absent Prime Minister raised those issues in this place and called on the then Prime Minister to sack the Minister for Health for phone calls and for supposedly using his own ministerial office to assist somebody. It would be an absolute joke, if it was not serious, that this minister should not back and reflect on that. Reflect though, Acting Prime Minister, on what Minister Richardson did. What did he do? He resigned. He understood what it meant and he resigned. This minister, though, says, 'I've done nothing wrong. I come into this place on a daily basis and I do nothing wrong.' Acting Prime Minister, if you have not phoned the weakest Prime Minister in Australia's history yet, then I suggest you do so. You should get onto the telephoneperhaps use the same telephone that this minister phoned Nick Greiner with-and say to the Prime Minister in the UK, 'Prime Minister, you remember what you said back in 1992 relevant to Graham Richardson? Well, we've got a bit of a problem here. One of our own has been caught out. One of our own is acting contrary to the ministerial guidelines that you brought down. One of our own is basically giving the two-fingered salute to everything that you said you stand for about raising standards.' This is the weakest Prime Minister, who sees himself modelled on Menzies. This Prime Minister is away at a time when an issue of such significance is also before this parliament. It falls squarely to you, Acting Prime Minister, to respond to these charges. This minister must be cut down and must be cut down now. He is acting absolutely contrary to this and he has misled this parliament. He has misled this parliament with respect to the work he has done, he has misled this parliament in terms of the phone call he has made to Nick GreinerMr Tim Fischer-Plural, not singular.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS
text: This is a baseless, shallow censure motion and we reject it. This is a motion which is more in the imagination of the opposition than in fact or reality. This is just a censure motion from an opposition, busying off now for their afternoon tea, who are only interested in a bit of cheap political point scoring against a very successful small business person who also happens to be the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs in this government. This motion is so far based on a couple of reports in the Melbourne Age, neither of which are actually quotes of what Mr Greiner said. In fact, there is no formal statement on the record by Mr Greiner with respect to this matter, except a statement which Mr Greiner made this afternoon during this particular debate. This statement was received by fax in the parliament this afternoon whilst the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) was on his feet. I will now read this statement from Mr Greiner. The statement is headed, 'The Hon. Nick Greiner, AO-23 June, 1997' and the title is 'Telephone Call'. It states: As I have previously indicated Mr Geoff Prosser rang me. We had a short conversation. He asked me for a contact point within the Coles Myer Group for his brother. I asked him to get his brother to write to me. I duly passed his brother's letter onto a relevant executive within the company group.  myself about any of the details about which his brother subsequently wrote to me. I have not had any further discussions or contact  At the conclusion of my remarks, I will table that statement. The point simply is that those remarks are entirely consistent with what the minister has said in this parliament. It is a serious charge to say that a minister has misled the parliament. Normally when you get one of these censures based on misleading the parliament, the opposition would normally read through the transcripts in the parliament and then point to other material where they would then claim there was some misleading statement. That was mysteriously omitted from the presentation on this censure motion. It was no surprise that it was omitted; they had no basis upon which to make that allegation. Later we will come back to some of the other incredibly trivial material they raised here in question time about how often the minister went shopping with his kids. On their strongest c1aim-or should I say, the most excited part of their claim today-there was absolutely no shred of evidence to back up the claim they made. In fact, this minister, unlike the now departed Graham Richardson, has not misled the House. This minister has given a full statement of the circumstances surrounding this relatively minor matter.
