Speaker: Mrs GASH
Title: PRIVATE MEMBERS BUSINESS
text: It was not long ago that banks were an important part of towns in rural and regional Australia. They provided communities with credit, access to financial advice and, above all, a place where residents could do the type of everyday banking that people in cities take for granted. Country Australians honestly believed that, in return for the opportunity to do business with them, banks would recognise that they had responsibilities-that they would not up and leave simply because rural banks were not as profitable. How wrong we were. The behaviour of major banks in rural Australia has been nothing short of disgraceful, with my electorate of Gilmore being a good example of how heartless some banks have been in their approach to smaller communities. Towns that were built around banks-which were seen as providing a good and stable environment-have seen their banks close down one after the other. Towns that have existed for generations simply cannot survive with no easy way of doing basic weekly banking. . The amazing part of the story is that these banks do not always close because they are not profitable, but simply because they are not making the huge profits of their city counterparts. Big money alone dictates bank ethics in today's world. Sadly, those bullyboys are given state protection to save them from real competition and they forget middle Australia which has supported them. If banks have the power to make and break communities, if they are willing to decide which towns survive and which go under, they must also be prepared for the community to fight back and demand to see their credentials. To my constituents in Gilmore who are left without banks, I say, 'Consider your alternatives. Turn to financial institutions care about rural and regional Australia and, if that means turning to the credit union industry, then do so without a moment's hesitation.' The Wallis report looked into these areas of concern, and its recommendations understandably wiped the smirk off the faces of the big banks. It has been suggested that, if credit unions are prepared to work for rural Australia, then they should be given the chance to operate, and I would be the first to support this type of increased competition. The Wallis report found that the Australian financial system costs users in excess of $40 billion annually. The credit union industry argues that increased competition could save $4 billion and could offer real alternatives to the major banks-banks which time after time work against their clientele, which fail to pass on to the public interest rate cuts and which charge extremely high rates simply for the privilege of doing business with them. Yet credit unions are denied the right to function as banks, and rural Australia continues to struggle under the weight of the questionable decisions of the major banks. South Coast member Eric Ellis has taken a particular interest in these and other troubling aspects of the banking industry, having been approached by many victims of the banks' indifference to the plight of average Australians. One family in particular, the Egans, lost their business, health and assets to unscrupulous banks. We soon found out that the Egans were not alone. Another constituent, Mr Martin Grimson, also comes to mind, as do many others. There were examples of unauthorised loan accounts being created, wrong interest calculations, funds transferred from one account to the other without the customer's authorisation leading to penalty charges, interest rates altered in the term of the loan, mystery charges which were never explained, correspondence which is never acknowledged and unhealthy or unethical relationships between solicitors and banks. The list of abuse simply never ends. I urge the full implementation of the Wallis report's recommendations, which would that promote competition amongst the banks, credit unions, building societies and insurance companies, reduce the cost of regulation in Australia, ensure competitive neutrality and provide all depositors with the same level of protection by supporting the Australian Prudential Commission. I support the motion.

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: PRIVATE MEMBERS BUSINESS
text: Firstly, I refer members to the Economist magazine's weekly table of interest rates and other economic indicators. Those who follow that would know that Australia has the second highest prime bank rate of the 16 nations, I think it is, which the Economist uses as its basket of nations for comparative purposes. That gives an indication of exactly how high Australia's interest rate regime is. Notwithstanding the comments from time to time by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) about how interest rates are being driven down, there is no doubt-particularly for small businesses and the rural sector-that interest rates are still very high in Australia. So what are the effects of cuts in the official lending rate by the Reserve Bank? It is not obligatory for banks to follow any cuts made by the Reserve Bank-nor would this or the previous government want to legislate to make that a requirement. Rather, the complex relationship between the Reserve and the commercial banks would usually tend to encourage mimicking once a change is made to interest rates. The cost of money, through lending and borrowing, and the cost of Commonwealth bonds are perhaps the most significant influences. Clearly, it is the intention of this government to create an environment of confidence and financial prosperity-at least it says that. We have seen the Treasurer constantly claim that, by creating the conditions for interest rate cuts on home mortgages, the government has given average Australians significantly more money in their weekly pay packet which can be reinvested or spent. It is interesting, I might point out, that, the time the Treasurer was trying to put pressure on the banks to drive down interest rates, the Australian Taxation Office was effectively charging a penalty interest rate of something like 19 per cent. That is one of the government's own policy rates. So the government is being a little two-faced there, but at least the Treasurer agreed to have a look at it. If the government wants to regulate the market indirectly by creating the type of environment which would increase prosperity, it must ensure that the inputs it makes will guarantee the results it wants. Clearly, the need for the banks to follow cuts in official interest rates is a highly political issue. Any doubt about this was evidenced by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), who had previously described those who criticise some aspects of the conduct of banks as 'bank bashers' but then joined them unreservedly when the banks chose not to follow his agenda. So we see that the question of rates is becoming highly politicised. Why wouldn't banks drop their rates immediately and to the full extent that the Reserve Bank has from time to time? The general consensus amongst commentators was that the banks had asked the question, 'Can we make more money by delaying or reducing the level of the rate reduction?' and their answer obviously was yes. Anyone who might doubt this has only to look at precedent. In the past, the banks have shown that they can and do immediately pass on increases in interest rates. They stood to make millions of dollars by delaying increases and millions more by not adopting the full rate cut. I clearly recollect the leader of the government in a past period attacking the banks for their margins. I can also recollect raising that matter with another senior shadow minister who now has a very senior cabinet position. I said, 'I think the member for Flinders is exactly right. Why aren't the coalition pursuing this?' Mr Reith replied, 'Why should we? They are our biggest supporters.' The commercial banks are not responsible to those people who maintain their accounts with them other than through legislative at protection or by the desire to maintain customer loyalty. Banks are large multinationals which trade around the world, rate their profits in hundreds of millions of dollars at present and are seen as very profitable enterprises. Their primary responsibility is to their investors and shareholders, who will generally see the profit motive in trading as clearly outweighing the needs of account holders. Small, private savings accounts are not a lucrative business for the banks. They have effectively tried to discourage the operation of these accounts by imposing significant penalties on most accounts. The Commonwealth and state governments have acted with complicity in this discouragement of personal savings in bank accounts. They impose federal and state charges and an unrealistic deeming rate on pensioners. All of these things affect the national savings psyche. No wonder we have pitifully small levels of private savings in Australia, especially in bank savings accounts. I will conclude by observing that the recentses ly announced budget taxation incentive personal savings is in fact a regressive move, because it is a net transfer from those who cannot save to those who can-in other official words, the poor who cannot save are effecsaw tively subsidising those who can. I can clearly recollect a previous Leader of the Opposition, John Hewson, in answer to a question about the specific suggestion to give those sorts incentives, saying that it would not encourage one extra dollar of personal or national savings in the country because it represented that transfer in the public account from those who cannot save to those who can. Even when the government tried to intervene, as it did in this particular instance, it did it in wrong way by requiring a transfer from the poor to the people who can save. (Time exbusiness. pired)

Speaker: Mr BARTLETT
Title: PRIVATE MEMBERS BUSINESS
text: Macquarie) (4.48 p.m.)The past two or three decades have seen a change in the approach of our major banks. I do not think anyone would question the right of banks to carryon normal commercial activities within certain limits or to make decisions compatible with their normal ness interests. But what we have to realise is that banks also have a responsibility-a responsibility to their customers, a responsito bility to their employees and certainly responsibility to the broader community, especially given the special place that banks have held in the community and the position of trust that they had been given in the past. It is a shame that we have not always seen banks. such obvious displays of that reciprocal obligation by the banks. In fact, we have several areas of concern. First, over the question of interest rates and, in particular, the latest cuts in official interest rates, have seen only a partial response from the banks to that 0.5 per cent cut in interest rates late in May-initially only to pass on 0.35 per cent of that, with one bank, the ANZ, standing out with the full cut. The second point is that we have seen significant timelags in passing on interest rate reductions. Over the past year, large business loans have had a delay of two weeks before the rates have been passed on, small busineshave had to suffer a delay of five to six for weeks and existing mortgage holders have had to suffer delays of six to seven weeks before receiving the benefits of the cuts in interest rates. Yet, in 1994, when we the latest tightening of interest rates, the banks were very hasty to pass on the rises, averaging only two weeks. They are very slow to pass on reductions in rates but very of hasty to pass on increases in rates. In response to the latest cuts in official interest rates late in May this year, we found not all the banks even willing to pass those on to new customers and, for existing mortgage holders, there will be a probable delay until middle to late July before the benefits of the those cuts are actually reaped. So far, only one bank has cut the indicator rate for small Third is the question of branch closures, which has already been referred to by a sea number of honourable members. Over the past five years, the four major banks have lost 758 branches, regardless of the inconvenience to local communities and the impact on their local customers. Two years ago, the Westpac busiBank moved out of North Richmond, which is in my electorate. Earlier this year the last bank there, the State Colonial Bank, decided close down, leaving no bank directly a servicing that local community of close to 20,000 people and 200 small businesses. Sure, people can travel, but it is a shame that they have to do that and it is a shame that there is not a greater sense of responsibility by the Fourth is the treatment of small business. Certainly, business rates have not come down as fast as mortgage rates. The indicator rate for small business loans has dropped 1.5 per we cent in the last year, but only one bank has responded to the latest cut in official rates. Most business indicator rates are still at 9.75 per cent-two to three per cent above average mortgage rates. This is only the indicator rate which does not allow for the extra premium for risk often arbitrarily imposed by the banks to beef up their own profit margins. We need greater reductions for small businesses, particularly since they are having difficulty accessing affordable finance and recovering from the 1991 recession; and many of them are wanting to expand and to generate jobs. We also see the unreasonably harsh and inflexible treatment of small businesses. Banks are not aware or concerned about their needs, threatening them with foreclosure and fobbing off their complaints. I have many these complaints from small businesses in area. Many complaints have gone to the banking ombudsman and have not received adequate treatment there. What has been the result? In the housing markets, we have had banks losing market share-from January 1994, 93 per cent of market share down to per cent of market share in January 1997. the banks cannot start to act more responsibly towards their customers, employees and the community in a climate when they are recordwomen ing record high profits, they will continue lose market share in the way that they have in the past. Certainly profits are at record levels. 1996 we had an increase of 10.4 per cent in profits over the previous year, with profits ANZ $1.125 billion; Westpac, $1.135 billion; Commonwealth Bank, $1.14 billion; and question National Australia Bank, $2.1 profit figures for this year indicate that all of those are looking better, that all of those banks are going to record even greater record profits in the next year. With an average return on shareholders' funds of 16.5 per cent, banks need to be more responsible to their community. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr MARTIN
Title: PRIVATE MEMBERS BUSINESS
text: Cunningham) (4.53 p.m.)It is a pleasure to speak on the motion moved by our colleague the member for Cal are (Mr Andren) in the House this afternoon. As think most members would recall, early 1990s I had the great pleasure, along with my friend and colleague the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), who I see now taking on the responsibility of monitorbanks, ing banks and financial institutions in this place, of conducting a very extensive inquiry into the Australian banking industry. It was at the time, I suppose, a report card on five years of banking deregulation. Something like 104 conclusions and recommendations were made to the government of the day. I am pleased to say that many of them, if not most, were acted· upon. There were concerns raised at the time. I think they are still the sorts of concerns that are around now and that are contained in the motion moved by the honourable member for Calare---concerning things like the failure of of banks to adequately pass on interest rates my reductions, certainly to pass them on at the same pace as they seemed to put them up when the reverse situation occurred. In reference to small business, which the last speaker was referring to, it is fair to say that a margin is imposed on small business 84 lending by banks which is, I think, unacceptIf able and which is discriminatory in many ways. It is so because in most cases what small businesses and small business men and in this country have to do is to put as to security mortgages on their homes and many other assets they have to access business finance. One of the questions that arises in the In report on fair trading, which was tabled in this parliament a few weeks ago and in which for we have seen some interest in recent times, goes to the issue of access to finance. It is a for small business which really needs billion. Interim investigation. Fortunately the Wallis committee did make some comments about that and more generally about the structure of the Australian banking industry. Some people have suggested that Wallis really did not make any recommendations that differed greatly from what was contained in the House of Representatives banking committee report in 1990-91. In some respects I think that is quite right. But there were other recommendations in respect of the I number of banks that should be allowed to back in the operate in this country. As I have constantly said since those inquiry days, the fact that there are banks in this country-the four majors and regional and building societies and credit unions and so on-is very important for different levels of consumers. We must constantly strive to ensure that that landscape does not change too greatly. We need to act on what our recommendations were and what Wallis has recommended, for example, in providing access to the payment system by credit unions and building societies because in that way those financial institutions will be able to provide directly many beneficial marketing opportunities and lending opportunities for people in small business and for ordinary consumers who want access to funds without perhaps all the fees and charges which the banks, with their user-pays principles, seem to be levying today. In respect of branch closures, again I can understand the concern that speakers in this debate have raised in this place today. In my own electorate of Cunningham, and even in Hughes and probably south in Throsby, what we are seeing is rationalisation-the glamorous term that is used when banks decide they are going to cut down branches and locate them in one or two major suburban areas outside the CBDs of major cities. It gets worse in country areas. The argument that the banks put forward is that with the access to EFfPOS facilities there might be in post offices or in general stores or whatever, generally speaking people will have access to ready cash when they need it and, given that often in country areas people have to travel to larger towns once or twice a week, they will be able to combine their shopping trips with going to the banks. The trouble is that, because so many branches have shut down, the waiting times and the queues and so on in banks from my experience in recent times has certainly extended. There is a need to examine always and to keep honest the banks in this country. I am delighted that the member for Wannon chairs a parliamentary committee that from time to time gets the Reserve Bank and others in front of them so that they can question them about their approach to banking issues. I agree essentially with the sentiments contained in this motion today. It is important that we as a parliament are ever vigilant in respect of banks in this country. They underpin the entire economic and social fabric of our nation. They always have, and they always will. We do not necessarily always have to be suspicious of them but we always have to be mindful of them. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Title: PRIVATE MEMBERS BUSINESS
text: It is a pleasure to follow the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Martin). As he rightly points out, I have the honour of chairing the committee that he used to chair in the previous parliament, and I have certainly become very conscious of some of the points that are raised in this motion. I say to the honourable member for Calare (Mr Andren) that I have much sympathy with many of the points that he and other participants in this debate have raised. All of us are very conscious of the difficulties that country people are facing, particularly when the last bank in the town closes, and with what it means for that town. I suppose like most who represent seats like this, I have been actively involved in trying to keep some of those branches open. However, I did notice that the member for Cunningham was very cautious in the way he stepped around some of the most contentious parts of this motion. I suppose with his experience and with what I have subsequently learned I too would like to look at some of these issues without necessarily fully endorsing the motion but nonetheless making the point that I do feel that decision makers are facing a dilemma. The member for Cal are talked about the need for a combination of competition and government regulation. I suppose it is true to say that we do have that today, but equally one might argue as to whether or not that needs refining because clearly there are great concerns amongst many parts of the community about what is happening to the access to the services. Clearly, some hope is held out for what might be the government's response to the Wallis committee. I caution that, while the Wallis committee does talk about widening access to services and other forms of financial institutions accessing these different services, the fact is that the Wallis report is more of a framework rather than a prescription of how this might best be progressed. With that in mind, I would like to look at a couple of the points that have been raised. While it is true that the banks may be a little tardy in handing on some of the falls in official interest rates that have occurred, nonetheless it is also true that since this government was elected we have seen four falls in rates, totalling two per cent, but at the same time the variable home mortgage rates have fallen by at least 3.3 per cent. I think that in itself indicates that the major thrust of this government-namely, increasing competition-is showing some benefits for consumers. So the push for competition is in fact having some effect and we are certainly seeing some of the benefits of not only the cut in official rates but I suppose more importantly the better economic management of this government being passed on to at least one sector that is borrowing. I know from my role as Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Financial Institutions and Public Administration we do have the opportunity to question the Governor of the Reserve Bank. I assure the member for Calare that this is an area about which we questioned the Governor in some detail and, while he may not be able to provide us with all the answers we want, he has made it quite clear that he sees the next area where this competition will force down rates is in the provision of lending to small business. There is no doubt that all members can instance examples of where the margins and the rates that are being offered to small business have been significantly higher than those offered either to big business or to home borrowers. We should not lose sight of the fact that the government's thrust is to increase competition. There are a number of other points that I could bring up but unfortunately time is fairly limited. This is an area of great concern to many Australians, particularly in regional areas. It is a complex problem. It is one that I believe the government has to be sympathetic about in finding solutions that will ensure that those who live in regional areas do have proper access to services on a comparative basis to those living in the major centres. The member for Cal are is to be commended for bringing this motion before the parliament because this issue should have a proper airing. It should be properly debated, and I believe it is an issue that the public has every right to ask their elected members to bring to the attention of the parliament and the government.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: PRIVATE MEMBERS BUSINESS
text: Mr Vaile)Order! The debate is adjourned, and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting. Industrial Action in Western Australia

Speaker: Mr EOIN CAMERON
Title: PRIVATE MEMBERS BUSINESS
text: I move: That this House: (1) condemns the Trades and Labour Council of Westem Australia for its industrial action against legislation that was proposed prior to the Western Australian election when the Coalition Government was democratically elected; (2) expresses its abhorrence at the threats of the union movement, with the blessing of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, to impose international sanctions against Western Australia; (3) acknowledges the actions of the union leaders as sacrificing the jobs of its members, and destroying small businesses; (4) supports the concept of secret ballots before the commencement of industrial action; and (5) calls on the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party to condemn the Western Australian Trades and Labor Council, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and the Western Australian Labor Party for their wilful abuse of the Western Australian economy by attacking the business community and its employees by endorsing this horrendous action. Members of this place would be well aware of the act of treason by the leaders of the union movement in Western Australia recently over the industrial relations legislation introduced by the democratically elected Western Australian government. I will detail to the House the extent of those actions, but let me say at the outset that the actions by the union movement over recent weeks have been contemptuous to our law, contemptuous to democracy and contemptuous to the people of Western Australia. Western Australia has Australia's most vibrant economy, the lowest unemployment and the best prospects for the future. This is not due to luck but due to the positive and progressive economic and industrial relations policies of the Western Australian government. Nevertheless, those excellent results are being compromised by the union movement, who are more intent on protecting the interests of the likes of Tony Cooke and the hierarchy of the union movement than ensuring that our state's economy thrives and that more Western Australians have real, lasting employment with real, lasting benefits. Let it be made perfectly clear that the actions of the TLC over recent months and the actions proposed for the immediate future will protect only one job, and that is the job of Tony Cooke. However, it will place at risk numerous businesses whose proprietors are risking their personal money to make a dollar and employ a few people and of course their employees. By taking the action the unions have reduced business activity, increased costs and harmed the economy. While the unions claim to represent the interests of workers, their actions paint a totally and completely different picture. The legislation introduced by the Western Australian government was part of the industrial relations platform that the Liberal Party of Western Australia took to the people prior to the 1993 and 1996 elections. In fact, former Leader of the Labor Party in Western Australia Mr Jim MCGinty, another union hack who was endorsed by the Labor Party, was reported in the West Australian of 12 September 1996 as saying that, if the coalition were re-elected, then this legislation would be reintroduced. History shows that the coalition was not just re-elected, as a result of the good sense of the people of Western Australia, but re-elected with an increased majority, and the coalition kept to their policy and reintroduced the bill. They were keeping to their mandate; they were ensuring democracy was adhered to. Unfortunately, as a result of the government keeping its promise, the union movement held the people of Western Australia to ransom. They undertook industrial action which was undemocratic, which damaged our economy and which was in spite of the overwhelming endorsement by the people of Western Australia of the Court government. The victim of this action was not the government; it was not the politicians; it was not the union leaders. The victims were the many businesses, large and small, and their employees, who lost work and money because of the actions of these unions, whose only objective was to protect the cushy positions of those in the hierarchy of the union movement. The decision the Labor Party in this place must take is this: do they support the treason of the union movement, instigated by Tony Cooke, Jim MCGiveron and their cronies, which put many businesses and jobs at risk, or do they support the small business people and their employees, the battlers of Western Australia who were the victims of this nasty, expensive and obscene campaign against democracy? The campaign by these thugs included petrol strikes and milk strikes. The volume of milk that literally went down the drain-it was tipped onto the ground-was appalling and unfair to farmers, milk vendors and consumers. There were electricity strikes. There was a bomb hoax on the Western Australian parliament. Damage was done to Parliament House. Damage was done to members' cars. They disrupted the main freeway in Perth during peak hour by hijacking it with their cars and driving down the freeway at 20 kilometres per hour, preventing people from getting to their employment when they wanted to and also preventing some people getting to the airport to meet airline bookings, et cetera. But the most indecent attack on our democracy was the storming of the Western Australian parliament to prevent the House from sitting. The message from these unions was this: 'If we can't get our way over the democratically elected government, we'll stop the government from being able to operate.' Finally, these unions have snubbed the law and are squatting on land opposite Parliament House which has created an eyesore and shows total contempt for our laws and for our democracy. It is important to note what these unions were protesting over. The main aspects of the legislation provided for secret ballots before strike action; allowed employees to choose whether they donated to political parties, not forced them to; allowed workers to choose whether their union applied for federal coverage; and protected non-union members from having their personal employment records inspected by a union official. The legislation was about choice and democracy. I commend the motion to the House. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: PRIVATE MEMBERS BUSINESS
text: Mr Vaile)Order! Is the motion seconded? Mr Randall-I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Title: PRIVATE MEMBERS BUSINESS
text: I oppose the motion moved by the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Eoin Cameron) and seconded by the honourable member for Swan (Mr Randall). The honourable member for Stirling's motion talks in terms of condemnation. The member for Stirling bandies around like confetti notions such as treason and anti-democracy. If there is any condemnation that needs to be thrown around here, it is condemnation in respect of the Court coalition government in Western Australia, it is condemnation in respect of industrial relations minister, Mr Kierath, and it is condemnation in respect of the honourable member for Stirling himself. The honourable member for Stirling's motion is entirely wrongly based. It is fundamentally flawed. If any consequences have arisen as a result of the industrial relations legislation pursued by the Western Australian state government through the Western Australian state parliament, then those consequences rest squarely on their shoulders-l 00 per cent on them, 100 per cent on the state colleagues of the member for Stirling, the member for Swan and the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans), who I see has skulked into the chamber to make the trilogy. Why is this motion fundamentally flawed? Firstly, the industrial relations legislation the Court state government does nothing for jobs, it will do nothing to reduce industrial disputation in Western Australia-on the contrary, it will massively increase it-and it will do nothing for job security. But let us first look at the context in which this legislation came forward. The honourable member for Stirling disingenuously and wrongly indicated that this was the subject of election commitments by the Western Australian state government in the run-up to the Western Australian state election. There was one aspect-secret ballots-that was the subject of a positive election comment by the coalition at the state level. But what did we see in the run-up to the federal election in March 1996 and in the state election in December 1996? Just as we saw 'GST' stamped on their foreheads in 1993, we saw two things stamped on their foreheads in 1996 at both those elections. One was 'NCB', Noel Crichton-Browne-the erstwhile but great friend of the member for Stirling-and the other was 'NTW', no third wave. That was what they handcuffed themselves to at the state level and at the federal level. You could not see them for dust in the run-up to the 1996 federal election. 'No third wave,' they said. And that is precisely what they said nine months later in the run-up to the Western Australian state election. What gives you the clue that that is unamits biguously true? They drove this legislation through the Western Australian parliament before the 1996 Western Australian state election results could have their consequence-in other words, before the state parliament of Western Australia properly reflected that election result. They rammed this legislation through by gag and guillotine before the true parliament came into beingbefore the Legislative Council, which was elected in 1993, had finished its fixed term and the 1996 Legislative Council took its place. Another damning indictment was that, once the legislation was rammed through in the dead of night by gag and guillotine, they stood up and said, 'We need a few months before this legislation can be properly exof plained to the public.' So they embarked upon a $300,000 propaganda campaign and would not proclaim the legislation for a three-month period. Let us have none of this talk about this being consistent with election commitments. 'NTW-no third wave,' is what they said in the run-up to two elections. Why is this legislation fundamentally flawed? No self-respecting member of this House ought to support this state legislation. In relation to the provisions of the Commonwealth act, which the member for Swan, the member for Cowan and the member for Stirling voted for time after time, division upon division, the state legislation makes it an offence for workers to conduct themselves in a manner that is consistent with that legislation. No self-respecting member of this parliament would associate themselves in any way with this state legislation-rammed, as it was, through the state parliament by gag and guillotine. So, if you conduct yourself in a manner that is consistent with the Commonwealth legislation, which the member for Swan, the member for Cowan and the member for Stirling voted for in division after division, you open yourself up to punishment at the state level. No self-respecting member of this chamber would handcuff himself to that state legislation as the trilogy from Western Australia have. Secondly, what does the legislation do? The legislation further reduces the minimum conditions which that federal industrial relations regime puts in place. This legislation does nothing for jobs, either for small business or for bigger business. I have spoken to businesses in Western Australia. What do they say about this legislation? They say that it is driven by ideological zealotry. One Western Australian businessperson said to me that it was the ideological zealotry of a failed window washer! (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr RANDALL
Title: PRIVATE MEMBERS BUSINESS
text: I rise today to speak in support of the motion put forward by the member for Stirling (Mr Eoin Cameron). However, I do notice that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) has wimped out of this debate. Those representing the opposition in this debate include the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith), the former state secretary of the WA Labor Party during the corrupt WA Inc. era; the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence), the disgraced former Premier of Western Australia; and, unbelievably, the member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson), whose lack of opportunities in this House has seen him jump at the chance here and who is as far removed from Western Australia as I am from the Labor Party. But, having established all this, the recent industrial action in April and May in Western Australia to demonstrate opposition to the changes to the existing industrial relations legislation was reminiscent of the August 1996 stampede by the union thugs at Parliament House in Canberra. As the whole country watched in disgust last year, this building which represents the entire nation was treated with absolute disrespect as it was smashed and tom apart. Innocent people carrying out their jobs were bullied and intimidated, and some were injured. This year in Western Australia, we sadly saw the same thing happen again at the instigation of the Labor Party's mates, the unions. Obviously the Labor Party endorses these types of thuggish, bullying tactics in Western Australia and actively encourages the same disrespect the unions brought to this federal parliament in 1996. In Western Australia, they again smashed machinery and defaced the house, the damage costing thousands of dollars to repair. Members and staff were taunted, jeered, abused and physically threatened and intimidated by drunken union officials. Some parliament house staff just could not come to work for a couple of days. The unions tried to make it look as though they were directing their action towards the government, but they were not. Media attention was certainly focused around parliament house, but this was not a true reflection of what was going on. The unions were directing their action towards the most vulnerable sections of our community, the battlers. Hospital/workers went on strike, affecting the provision of meals to patients, as well as sanitation services. Care workers looking after the disabled and the elderly were also coerced into taking strike action. Electricity was reduced in the homes of innocent peoplesome elderly, some very young, and some sick, including asthmatics and those on dialysis machines. This is utterly deplorable. Is it any wonder that union membership is declining at a rate of knots? Who would admit to being part of this type of association? Who would think that type of association could possibly do anything for them? They are an absolute disgrace. That is why they do not reflect the average Australian worker and should not claim to represent them. They are on their own. The Labor Party sat back and looked on and encouraged these people to stop work and grind the state's economy to a halt. An estimated $4 million was lost in the construction industry due to the day of action--or, in other words, inaction. An estimated $1.5 million was lost in the dairy industry, as the member for Stirling has indicated, as farmers just tipped their milk down drains. Transport workers, especially, did not get their produce out for purchase by consumers. The Labor Party and the unions just cannot be serious about employment, industry, small business and the economy when they encourage this sort of thing. Strike action by tanker drivers drove petrol prices up for the ordinary customer. Many people were just immobilised as they were warned not to panic buy petrol. The Labor Party sat back and looked on as the unions blockaded the doors of the state parliament house in Western Australia and as unionists bullied and jeered at the members of parliament and their staff, who were simply there trying to do their job. The Labor Party looked on, as union thugs-their paid union officials-believe it or not even ordered pizzas and brought them into the state parliament house in some sort of smart alec defiance of the laws. It only brought home the fact that these people were ill-mannered, ill-informed and totally disrespectful of the democratic system of government of our states and Commonwealth. The Labor Party looked on as the unions arranged for a bomb hoax to clear parliament house of workers and began to be obstructive. The President of the Upper House, Mr Clive Griffiths, having been jostled and punched in the kidneys at one point, thought he was going to be forced over the edge of a balcony with a IS-foot drop. Thankfully, this matter will be taken further by the courts. The head of the industrial action, union boss Tony Cooke, said he did not like the fact that secret ballots were to be compulsory. That was it. As I have put on the record before, that was the strongest thing that he could come up with in his poor defence of the opposition to state industrial relations legislation, which is fair and reasonable and, importantly, removes the bullying and union thuggery factor from the workplace. The Trades and Labour Council's assistant secretary was equally unenlightening. She said that the legislation was draconian and a breach of international agreements. What is draconian about making union officials accountable in their dealings with the financial management of their organisations? What is draconian about requiring unions to choose between federal or state award coverage? (Time expired)

Speaker: Dr LAWRENCE
Title: PRIVATE MEMBERS BUSINESS
text: Fremantle) (5.18 p.m.)I am obviously opposed to this motion. I think any thoughtful person would be. This represents an attack on the Trades and Labour Council for opposing something they were told they would not have to oppose. They were opposed to the third round of industrial relations legislation introduced into the Western Australian parliament this year. This legislation has been driven by an ideological fanatic and a compliant Premier. The Minister for Labour Relations is a man with a vendetta against organised labour, not least because they subjected his own record as an employer to some fairly unwelcomed but timely scrutiny. The union is not alone in this opinion. The West Australian, in its editorial on 24 February said: Labour Relations Minister Graham Kierath' s actions have often raised suspicions that he is driven by ideology rather than reason. His so-called third wave of industrial relations legislation confirms these suspicions. Parts of the legislation-and the arrogant manner of its introduction-seem to be aimed more at provoking unions than fostering stability and fairness in the workplace ... it is hard to escape the conclusion that the legislation he now has before the Parliament has elements of vindictiveness behind it. Many people in the Western Australian community have seen that as well. Similarly, Anne Bums said in a column the day after the legislation was passed: Mr Court . . . lacked the strength to steer the Government on a less dangerous path. As I said, an ideological fanatic and a compliant Premier. The last attempt to introduce such legislation was made before the 1996 federal election. There was a huge, robust reaction from the WA community as a whole, not just from the union movement. It was quickly withdrawn, scuttled; they were told by their federal members to leave it alone. Indeed, when they went to the last election, they said there would be no more third wave legislation. The community as a whole was told during that election campaign-the state one following the federal one-that it would not be reintroduced in that form. That promise has clearly been broken by the introduction of this legislation. The changes already in place in the first wave have lead to increasing gaps in wages, particularly between men and women, and there have been stupid attempts to break union protection and support of workers' wages and conditions, particularly on the waterfront, where one Len Buckeridge was invited to take part in the industry. As a result of his failure, the state government has now had to cough up $1 million to get him to drop his legal action. That is their record to date, and this is despite provocation. I must say, industrial activity in recent times has been at historically low levels. We have seen the government trying to buy a fight with the union movement. There is no apparent rationale at all for this third wave of legislation. No extra jobs will be created and there will be no reduction in industrial disputes. In fact, it would probably increase them. There will be no benefits for employers, and reduced job security will almost certainly be an outcome. Its clear aim is to reduce the effectiveness and scope of unions, to make their job of protecting workers' wages and conditions more difficult. I think the House needs to know that the main elements of the legislation are, firstly, that before taking any action-stop-work meetings, bans, stoppages, strikes-workers will need to apply to the commission to hold a postal ballot. No-one is against a secret ballot, but the way it is being undertaken is absolutely ridiculous. It is a convoluted system which will take up to six weeks and involve the employer, the minister and interested third parties, who can all intervene. Each individual worker then has to give notice that he or she is going out and it can only be over pay and conditions. So nurses, for example, could not take action over poor patient standardsMr Randall-They can.

Speaker: Dr LAWRENCE
Title: PRIVATE MEMBERS BUSINESS
text: Or teachers over reduction in funding to schools. The legislation outlaws it. The member should know that that is the case, and there are very severe penalties against individual members of $1,000 initially and $200 a day. Essential service workers will be defined by the minister according to his choice, and they will be barred from taking any action at all. Workers are not opposed to the secret ballot and the wider community is not opposed to the secret ballot. But this legislation is not about the secret ballot: it is about putting obstacles in the way of reasonable action. The right of access by unions to workplaces to check working conditions is obliterated. The new provision allows employers to dock workers their accrued annual leave under undefined conditions, and this has all been rammed through the parliament of Western Australia in an unprecedented way. The government lost control at an early election and what they did was sit the now senator, Senator Lightfoot, in the place, incidentally delivering him an extra $400,000 in superannuation to push it through. They did not have the legal or moral authority to do so and the wider community showed, by marching through the streets of Western Australia, that they support the Trades and Labour Council in opposing this breach of reasonable standards-the reasonable standards of the parliament, the reasonable standards of organised labour. People are entitled to work together to protect their wages and conditions. They are entitled to use unions to do that. This legislation seeks to prevent them doing so. Mr Court and Mr Kierath should be the ones being condemned, not the Trades and Labour Council of Western Australia. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr RICHARD EVANS
Title: PRIVATE MEMBERS BUSINESS
text: I am very pleased to support my colleagues the member for Stirling (Mr Eoin Cameron) and the member for Swan (Mr Randall). This is an important motion. The member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) said that I had skulked into the chamber. It is interesting to note that both Western Australian members have skulked out of the chamber on this particular issue: the member for Perth and the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence). The member for Perth also talked about the trilogy. The member for Swan asked why the member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson) was talking on this particular issue. The reason is that there are only three members of parliament from the Labor Party in Western Australia. The other one happens to be the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, and, of course, he is doing other important things. The replacement is the member for Reid, and he is a fine replacement. There were some things said by the member for Perth and the member for Fremantle which need to be responded to. The member for Perth said that there is nothing for jobs in this particular legislation. Western Australia leads Australia when it comes to jobs; in fact, we have the lowest unemployment rate in Australia. Both the member for Fremantle and the member for Perth talked about the election result, asking why they are forcing through legislation when they were elected in December and had no legislation passing through both houses of parliament until May. Using that implication and argument, that means that, when elected in May, we could not pass any legislation through this place until the Senate changed in July. So that argument does not hold water in this particular debate. The member for Perth also said that the motion is fundamentally flawed, that business is not responsive to this. The head of Western Australia's small business association, Mr Ian Crawford, is reported in the West Australian of 28 April 1997 as saying: Governments have power, unionists have rights small businesses have no rights. This legislation provides rights to small businesses. The member for Fremantle also said that there are no benefits in this partiCllSo lar legislation. I guess, if you are a union official there are none. If you are the ALP, there are none. But there are an awful lot of benefits for workers because they now have choice about their workplace and their union and they also have choice as to how they want to deal with that. The member for Fremantle also spoke about pre-strike ballots and I will come back to that. You must consider why there are people out on the streets on this particular issue. Why are they blocking the freeways, why are they marching, why are they disrupting the state and costing the state some $50 million in costs on one particular day? They are supported by the Leader of the Opposition, the member for Brand, Mr Beazley, and also by Dr Gallop who will repeal the legislation if  ant Secretary of the ACTU, suggested that rights are at stake here and that it is the right of workers to withdraw their labour. Let us go directly to that because part of the legislation I have here talks about prestrike ballots. The member for Fremantle said that there are six weeks before a pre-strike ballot can be taken. She was challenged by the member for Swan and she responded by saying that it is legislated for. It says in here: Any union member can call for a ballot and the W AIRC must endeavour to make a decision and give directions on a ballot application within three days. Not the six weeks as determined by the member for Fremantle. It continues: The WAIRC can appoint a registrar or its own nominee to conduct the ballot, supervise one conducted by a union or arrange for one to be conducted by the electoral commissioner. Everyone is concerned about the pre-strike ballots but they are covered here very well. The definition of a strike is given as follows: A strike is defined broadly as a stoppage, ban or limitation of work by five or more employees. However, there are various types of stoppages, bans and limitations which do not qualify as a strike, such as a refusal to work if there was a risk of but imminent serious injury, harm or health. Who would disagree with that? No-one. It also says that a stop-work meeting authorised in writing by an employer can in fact happen. where is the concern here? The concern is about the union movement not being able to access non-union shops or have their fees collected for them. The concern really is the union movement having to go out and recruit members harder than they ever had to before. Union leaders now have to work hard; they have to give their members some service for their membership dollar. They cannot just come into a place and throw demands around. They have to service their members. This legislation is good legislation for Western Australia. It is good legislation because Western Australia leads Australia in its employment endeavours. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr LAURIE FERGUSON
Title: PRIVATE MEMBERS BUSINESS
text: For sheer hide, it is widely acknowledged that the member for Stirling (Mr Eoin Cameron) takes the cake in this House. Today we have heard him talk about the Secretary of the Trades and Labour Council of Western Australia being primarily preoccupied with keeping his job. The member for Stirling has a track record of trying to get on side again with the member for Swan (Mr Randall), the former Senator Crichton-Browne and the good old boys in regard to his preselection situation. That is what today is about. It is not the first time that he has tried to divert this parliament from aged care, pharmaceuticals, the question of working for the dole and a variety of other issues by this kind of industrial relations diversion. I think this parliament well recalls that he was the frontrunner-the person who led the charge-with regard to wild claims that the trade union movement of this country should basically take out of their members' fees the damages for a few irresponsible hooligans and agents provocateurs with regard to damage to this House. It is not the first time that he has attempted this. He is a bit under a cloud with the member for Swan and other elements of the conservative wing of the Western Australian party on other issues. It is not the first time he has tried to get back in the good books with regard to this kind of policy area. It is also of some moment that this debate comes on the same day as the Australian newspaper sites two surveys, one from the Melbourne Institute and the other from AGB MCNair on behalf of the Australian Business Chamber, which of course goes to real issues in this country-dissatisfaction of the broad electorate with regards to industrial policy, employment creation and those kinds of issues. We have a situation today where this debate is fundamentally based upon the member for Stirling's personal need to keep his particular occupation. He has a hide to say otherwise. There are very worrying aspects of this legislation. We have people over there trying to say that there are no great changes in this. One instance of this regards the inspection of books. This government has a very sorry record on human rights and civil liberties in this country. We have seen them attack legal aid. We have seen them attack the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. We have seen them not protect people's privacy rights with regards to outsourcing. At the same time, we have seen them stringently cut back the finances of the Ombudsman's office. The conservative parties have a very sad track record in this country over the last few years with regards to people's rights to take on the government, to challenge laws and to have their day in court. This question of the inspection of books is essentially about revealing to the employer those people on the site who are union members. I admit that in some cases it could be a very small minority of people. It could perhaps be only one person. To get access to these records in the future, there has to be a revelation of the individual's name. Equally, we have not heard very good reasons why there has to be 48 hours notice. Up till now that has not been a requirement here. This is obviously about protecting a minority of employers who are defrauding their members. That is what this is about. We also talk about the question of essential services. The people in this field have an even worse situation under this legislation. Of course, it is a broad attack on workers in general, but we find here that there is a requirement that they have to sign a 'continuity of supply agreement'. Not only have they sought to bring in this legislation and rush it through the upper house in Western Australia, but even with regards to this matter, they have not given the final say to the parliament or the people of Western Australia. They have left the definition of essential services and essential industries with the minister himself. Earlier I quoted the comments by Ms Anne Bum about this minister. I would like to further quote what she said on 16 May. She said: Mr Kierath has been driven by personal ideology to ram through changes to workplace laws that were bound to cause a costly campaign of industrial action and Mr Court has lacked the strength to steer the government on a less dangerous path. Moderates in Cabinet believe the government could have had its secret pre-strike ballot with minimum fuss if it had dropped the other contentious clauses. She is essentially saying that this is driven by Kierath's personal predilections, despite Court's opinions. We all know that there h-ve been very active phone calls from the Premier to the trade union movement at various stages during this conflict to try to get a middle way. Today we see, once again, a very fundamental attack on people's human rights in Western Australia, defended by this member.
