Second Sydney Airport

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: I grieve for the 500,000 residents of southwestern Sydney adversely affected by the Howard government's plans to site Sydney's second international airport at Holsworthy. I grieve in particular for the way in. w-ich the environmental impact statement gUidelines are being distorted to virtually guarantee the site selection of Holsworthy. The former federal government had plans for a limited overflow airport at Badgerys Creek, with some 270,000 aircraft movements per annum. The minister elected last year, Mr Sharp, wants a much bigger airport for Sydney's second airport facility. He has increased the scope and size of the plans for the second airport to some 360,000 movements per annum, an increase of one-third. But Badgerys Creek, the site that was acquired over a seven-year period by the former government, does not have sufficient land to accommodate Mr Sharp's bigger second airport. It would take perhaps another seven years to acquire the land needed for the new government's expanded second airport plans. The only site under consideration which can cope with Mr Sharp's bigger airport at Sydney's west is Holsworthy. In this sense, the fix is on. The goalposts have been moved and the rules have been rigged to guarantee the minister's chosen preference for Holsworthy as the only result that can come from the EIS process. The fix is on. The fix is on from a hands-on minister-the sort of minister who tests aviation safety material off the balcony of the ministerial wing of Parliament House and the sort of minister who rings air traffic control direct to get himself into Sydney airport. This is the minister who has always had a preference for Holsworthy and now sees himself, in terms of Sydney's second airport, as the site selector, the designer, the builder, the operator, the air traffic controller and the pilot for such a facility. This is the sort of minister who is bringing to the aviation portfolio the principles of vertical integration-a hands-on minister who has put the fix on to get his chosen site at Holsworthy as the only option that can be chosen out of the distorted EIS process. In this shabby task he has been aided by John Fahey, the silent MP for Macarthur, the same person who, as Premier of New South Wales, said that he did not need a royal commission to tell him about the New South Wales police service, but who now says that he needs a 12month EIS to tell him why an international airport on the other side of the Georges River will be harmful to his electors in the suburb of Campbelltown. What sort of local member remains silent while two 4,000-metre runways are pointed directly at homes in his electorate just five to six kilometres away from the airport site at Holsworthy? This is a problem not just for the future, not just for when the second airport would be constructed at Holsworthy, it is a problem right now. It is a problem right now not just for the anxiety and the concern that residents have about this proposition but for the way in which it is running down property prices and home values in the south-west of Sydney. My office has contacted a number of real estate agents in Campbelltown and Ingleburn in my electorate to find out how sales have been affected. The facts are that home prices in Campbelltown have remained low over the past year, even from a low base relative to the rest of Sydney. According to local agents, it is becoming very difficult to sell in any of the suburbs of Campbelltown. Indeed, in most areas of Campbelltown, prices have either remained stagnant or have, in fact, fallen. Mr Frank Ward, representing the members of the Macarthur Real Estate Institute, said: Members of the real estate industry share the anger that most of our fellow residents have for the Howard Government's attempt to move aircraft noise from the Prime Minister's electorate to the people of Macarthur ... There are many residents who, for personal reasons, will have to sell their homes. As agents, it is our duty to assist them to achieve their objective and minimise any difficulty. Any effects on the home market by the Howard Government's betrayal of our area will be nothing compared to the damage to the health of our families and loss of quality of life caused by a Holsworthy Airport. It has been well documented in the media in Sydney that the metropolitan area is experiencing a housing price recovery. Over the past year, house prices in Sydney have increased by 38.4 per cent in the eastern suburbs, 26.7 per cent in the inner city and 32.9 per cent on the lower North Shore. Campbelltown has had an increase of just 1.4 per cent, the lowest increase of any area. This has been after decades of high demand and growth for housing in Campbelltown. The real indicator is the lack of any increase in the Campbelltown local government area and the huge disparity between increases in other suburbs. Quite frankly, Campbelltown is missing out on Sydney'S housing boom just as we have missed out, due to the Howard government, in the investment in the orbital road, in services and employment growth. We are missing out on the opportunity for residents in the south-west of Sydney to enjoy the home price benefits of Sydney's boom. As figures for the Real Estate Institute of New South Wales illustrate, in June 1996, just after the government's Holsworthy announcement, the median house price in Campbelltown was $130,000. The figure for North Sydney at this time was $458,000. By September 1996, the median price in Campbelltown dropped to $125,000, while the figure for North Sydney rose by $10,000. By March this year, Campbelltown median prices levelled out to just $131,500 while North Sydney had increased to $477,000. I would argue that a major reason for Campbelltown failing to benefit from a Sydney housing recovery is the threat of Holsworthy. I am not alone in my conclusion. One of my constituents, Mr Wayne Simpson of Minto, recently wrote: For the past three months, my wife and I have been trying to sell our house in the Campbelltown suburb of Minto, where we have lived for the past six years. Real estate agents in the area have told us that the house prices in this area have been affected by the Second Sydney Airport proposal. In fact, we stand to lose 20 per cent off the total price of the house just because the Government is not prepared to state the facts surrounding this whole airport situation. Mr Simpson went on to say: When I look at the options outlined in the Government's study, all I see is one big mess for the people that live in Sydney's South-West ... I would suggest that the Government bring forward its decision on this whole airport debate and let the residents of South-West Sydney get on with their productive lives. At the prospect of losing 20 per cent off the sale price of my house, I wonder if you can advise me of where I might claim compensation for this loss. I have been living in Minto long before this new proposal was invented, and I would not have bought the house here if I knew that the Holsworthy option for a Second Sydney Airport was known at the time. This was a government that said it was for families. It said it was for young families trying raise their children and purchase a home. Here are residents in the south-west of Sydney who have had that dream ripped from them because of the spectre of the Holsworthy airport proposal. This is a threat not just for the future, not just when an airport would be constructed under the Howard government, but for the present, due to the dramatic decline in relative home values in the south-west of Sydney. These are concerns which are explained in housing price differentials for the rest of Sydney. They are experiences which are being felt right now by the residents I represent and who the Minister for Finance, the member for Macarthur (Mr Fahey), should be representing with an active voice in this parliament. Let it not be said that the government has not had the opportunity to consider these legitimate concerns from constituents about falls in housing values. The Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) agreed to answer 20 questions put to him by a local newspaper, the Macarthur Advertiser. One of the questions was: Imagine a Labor Government announced out of the blue that it was going to build a 24-hour international airport right next door to your Tablelands property ... You had worked hard to pay your mortgage and now stood to make a big loss on any sale. How would you feel? Minister Sharp answered: See answer to Question 9. What was the answer to question 9 in this survey? It said: The management of potential aircraft noise associated with the second airport will be one of the issues addressed in the EIS. It said nothing about home values or about how the minister would feel if a Labor government was going to build an international airport in his backyard. It said nothing about the government's deceit in failing to give any notice of this proposition prior to the last election. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) asked people to trust him. He asked them to regard him as 'Honest John', but he was not honest enough to let people know in the south-west of Sydney that he and John Sharp had plans for an international airport at Holsworthy which would destroy property values, cause anxiety all around and lead to massive concerns for the 500,000 residents in Sydney's south-west. Once again, I urge this government to consider the harm caused to local residents due to the threat of a 24-hour international airport constructed on Campbelltown'S doorstep. These residents are not benefiting from Sydney's housing recovery. They are experiencing an ever-increasing spiral of anxietyanxiety about the future prospects of an international airport. There was no mention of it before the last election, but there are now plans to construct it just on the other side of the Georges River in Sydney's south-west. If it was not good enough to mention this proposal prior to the last election, it should not be built now and the government should understand, especially the Minister for Finance, that people are suffering anxiety-not just for the future but right now. They have concerns about their children's education and well-being and most of all about the absolute failure of south-west Sydney to capitalise on Sydney's housing boom. This is costing money and peace of mind. The plan should be abandoned right now. Food Safety

Speaker: Mrs BAILEY
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: I wish to bring to the attention of the House tonight the need for uniform food regulations and hygiene standards in the Australian food industry. With the number of food poisoning incidents recently, the current plethora of different laws which currently exists around Australia is no longer adequate to properly address the issue of food safety. The Howard Government has taken the lead on the issue of food safety and, while much progress has been made, there is still much more which needs to be done. This year, more than any other in recent times, the issue of food hygiene and standards has remained firmly in the public eye. It is an issue which affects each and every Australian, and particularly food producers like those in my electorate of MCEwen, who depend on the reputation Australia has for clean, hygienic food for their livelihoods. We have all read the headlines of recent times, like the ones that said 'Two Dead, 30 III from Salmonella', or '100 III in Pork Roll Poisoning Outbreak', or 'Deaths Spark Meats Recall', or 'Bugs in the Food System'. Two of the most publicised food scares this year related to outbreaks of salmonella poisoning, traced to ham and corned beef produced by a Melbourne smallgoods company and pork rolls from a Springvale bakery, both in Victoria. Then there were the Garibaldi sausage scandal in 1995, the Kraft peanut butter recall last year, the salmonella outbreak on an international Qantas flight last year and the recent hepatitis A outbreak resulting from contamination of oysters from Wallis Lake. The few food scares I have mentioned are merely the ones which have made headlines. There have been dozens more over the past two years alone which have led to well known food manufacturers voluntarily recalling their products due to contamination by foreign bodies or bacteria. The most frightening aspect is that, despite all our modem technologies, better surveillance techniques and greater knowledge, the number of food scares is increasing, leaving a trail of death, hospitalisation and illness their path. This trend is reflected right across the country, with the number of reported food poisoning incidents nationally increasing tenfold in just three decades. I might say that, unfortunately, I speak as a victim of some of these recent food poisoning outbreaks. Some have said it is a hazard of the job. Australia has a reputation for having one of the highest standards of food safety in the world. But that reputation could be damaged if we continue to read headlines like those that I mentioned. Australia prides itself on having food producers which are among the most efficient in the world. Our agriculture and food industry is the backbone of the Australian economy, providing substantial employment and billions of export dollars. The total value of our agricultural exports is nearly $20 billion, with more than $9 billion of this coming from the food processing industry alone. In Australia, we have one of the highest food safety records in the world. Our reputation for safe, clean and healthy food has been built up over a long period of time and is envied by many of our trading partners. But, if we continue down our current path and do not take action to stop the increasing incidence of food poisoning and contamination, this reputation could cost our economy billions in export dollars. In my electorate of MCEwen, the food industry is the cornerstone of most local communities. MCEwen is fortunate to have a strong and diverse food industry which includes wine and grape growing, horticulture, sheep, poultry, beef and dairy industries, as well as the new venison and cheese industries. If our food industry's reputation were threatened, it is rural and regional communities such as those in MCEwen which stand to lose the most. We also cannot forget the human side to food safety-the many thousands of people who fall ill, are hospitalised or die as the direct result of food poisoning. This human cost is much greater than any extra financial burden we wear as a result of inadequate food standards. The mad cow disease scare which swept through the UK last year is an indicain tion of what can happen if food becomes tainted. The link between mad cow disease and the fatal Creutzfe1dt-Jakob disease in humans prompted bans on British beef and beef products throughout Europe and around the world, including Australia. More than 150,000 head of cattle were destroyed in Britain, thousands of jobs were lost, beef and cattle sales plummeted and billions of dollars in income were lost. A similar scare in Australia would spell disaster for our meat export industry, worth about $4 billion a year. The freeze on Australian processed meat and dairy imports into South Korea as a result of the anthrax outbreak in Victoria this year, the European Union ban on hormonal growth promotants in meat since 1988 and the recent interstate ban on Victorian grown apples and pears due to the discovery of a strain of fire blight are a very small taste of what we could expect if our food regulations, inspections and hygiene standards were to slip below acceptable levels. Increasingly, foreign food markets, particularly in Asia and Europe, are looking for food which has high standards of quality, is nutritional and has clean production processes. The demand for food in Asia is growing by about $16 billion a year, providing excellent opportunities for Australian exports to niche markets. The government has already targeted Asia as a potential growth area for food exports. If we are to meet that potential, we need to ensure that our reputation for top quality food not only remains intact but continues to grow. It is for this reason that the Howard government has taken a tough stand on the relaxation of import bans on uncooked salmon products and New Zealand apples and on undertaking stringent testing procedures before making a final decision on the importation of cooked chicken meat. While our stand has incited the wrath of trading partners such as the United States, Canada and New Zealand, we will not be deterred from protecting our vital primary industries and the communities they support and our reputation as a producer and processor of clean, green food. The results of two recently completed food surveys prove that we can be confident in the general quality of our food. The national residue survey found that almost all our meat, grain, dairy, egg and horticultural products met good agricultural practice. The national market basket survey found that all foods tested fell within the accepted international standards and safety limits for the dietary intake of herbicide, pesticide and other contaminants in food. This sends a clear and positive message about our food industry to not only food consumers in Australia but also to markets around the world. The challenge for governments and for everyone in the food industry-from the smallest producer, to the largest food manufacturer to the local take-away food shop-is to ensure that the food we eat and produce continues to be clean and risk free and that our worldwide image as a quality food producer is maintained. While that responsibility starts with food producers and food manufacturers, it extends also to the consumer. While action such as the introduction of food handling regulations, smallgoods quality standards and meat inspection reforms will provide greater assurance for both food buyers and our export markets, consumers also need to play their part in food safety. They need to ensure that foods are handled in a safe manner until they are consumed. These measures are very important to our industry. The Australia New Zealand Food Authority plays a key role in our food industry by developing food standards, coordinating national food surveillance and recall systems, conducting research, assessing policies about imported food, and developing codes of practice within the industry. The authority has unveiled its food hygiene proposal which, with cooperation from industry and the states and territories, will create uniform national hygiene standards for the first time in Australia's history. The future reliability of our primary industries and the livelihoods of hundreds of thousands of people who work in the Australian food industry depend on vigilantly maintaining and protecting our internationally envied reputation as a clean, green nation. (Time expired) Fire Blight

Speaker: Mr ADAMS
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: My grievance relates to the state of play with New Zealand with respect to the handling of the fire blight issue. Last week I was in New Zealand with the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Primary Industries, Resources and Rural and Regional Affairs. Although we were briefed on the fire blight issue, there was more left unsaid than was passed on to us. They tried to convince us that fire blight had been in Australia for years. Although they referred to media clippings and findings from tests, no evidence was offered in evidence that the disease is established in Australia. Because of New Zealand's disease status, and the fact that it has fire blight, orchardists have to check for the disease 500 metres around orchards about every four months. many orchards are close to towns, creeks and open ground with blackberries and other weeds, et cetera, this can become very expensive. We certainly do not want to have same regime imposed on us-the New brought Zealanders are trying to level out the playing field by unethical means. There is no other reasonable explanation to why some of their scientists came to Australia and picked out two places to have a look at and then claimed to have found blight. It is extraordinary that, while claiming to have found it in the botanical gardens, searches of domestic gardens within a 20-mile radius found nothing. Searches through orinterests chards, at a huge cost to industry, revealed nothing, and Tasmania has lost a whole shipment of fuji apples to Japan because this scare. Fire blight has never been discovdisease ered. The Tasmanian industry has been so distressed that they are planning to launch class action against the New Zealanders for this intrusion into their industry and their ability to export. This 'must have at any cost access to markets' attitude is becoming the new reality. It is something that has developed because of the intense competition in domestic markets. If we allow countries to undertake raids on us with this sort of attitude, then our industries are going to suffer. Of course, individuals certainly going to go broke and be pushed off their farms. There should be an avenue to protect our industries on ethical grounds. The scientific argument is fine and should be undertaken with authorities being the main arbiters. However, the decisions made are political and, whatever science says, there are still the political realities. The political reality in Australia is that our whole interstate trade is disrupted and many people have to face the consequences. There should be some disincentive fo countries which point the finger without using correct protocols. Why, for example, did the professor who was visiting for a conference and who found some fire blight wait two weeks before contacting AQIS? There are As many more unanswered questions on this issue. There must be a way of protecting our industries from industrial sabotage. Just look at the salmon industry. It would the be a complete disaster if a disease were in deliberately. The industry is very concerned about the possibility of disease being introduced accidentally if Australia allows uncooked salmon into the country. as New Zealand, like many other countries, is now undertaking risk analysis on its fish products imports. It understands the real fire problems faced by countries that have a disease free status, yet it still pushes this attitude of 'must have at any cost' access. We learnt that New Zealand has fisheries in Chile and that it has bought farms over there. However, these fish are not disease free and it makes it difficult for New of Zealand to sell them to countries where entry is a problem. We were told about two container loads that were brought a into New Zealand from Canada-one was sold but was in such poor quality that the market never developed; what happened to the other one is still anybody's guess. We get examples from other countries of the impact imports have on recreational fishing. There are different places in the world where recreational fishing has been greatly affected by the introduction of diseased fish. In America, there are streams which are are closed because of 'whirling disease'. No fishing is allowed, and you can see the signs up. Our recreational fisheries do not want to face that situation; neither, I put to the House, would the New Zealand recreational fishing industries. The general attitude over there is that we have to break down barriers no matter what to reach the goal of no restrictions across the Tasman, which is all very laudable if you have a comparatively disease free status. But Australians are very aware that we have a better record than most other countries on many of these diseases because of our strict quarantine regulations in the past and partly due to the fact there have been tariff barriers as well. One interesting thing we did learn in New Zealand was the setting up of a ministry bio-security, administered by a council. The idea is to pull together all scientific ledge which they will utilise when arguing access to other countries. We might well to look at such a body. It may be required we are to fend off other incursions of the apple blight nature. I would like to see this raised throughout the deliberations among parties. The New Zealanders have always been competitive and I admire the aggressive zeal they have in making sure that their products are at the forefront of new markets, but we should not be attempting to compete on each other's home turf. We can exchange informajobs tion, we can develop ideas and, certainly, share industries, but not to endanger each other's markets. The four-day visit was very informative in lots of ways and lent committee is visiting Australia this week, but we should continue to ensure that we respect each other's marketing potential. When we have a situation of capital and finance controlling where the market develinto ops, we have to be aware of the companies' ability to be able to manipulate brand names. When discussing the package labelling quesoverseas. tion some years ago, we saw that, when brand names are packaged under an Australian label, they can substitute the raw material from other countries when supplies are short. I can remember at that time quoting an Edgells label from a tin of tomatoes. Written on the label was: When adverse weather conditions affect supply of our Australian crop, we seek the world's best tomatoes, harvested when sunripened to perfection, rich red and full of flavour. It is the sort of substitution that can take place from one country to another. In other words, an Australian product can be substituted with product from anywhere in the world imported into Australia and merely canned here. The concern here is the substitution. The consumer cannot be sure that just knowing a brand name will ensure that the product is from Australia, New Zealand or anywhere else. Substitution is occurring in other places. We were told about Sainsburys in England selling of lamb from New Zealand. The consumer knows of Sainsburys lamb, but not necessarily knowits country of origin. The brand name befor comes the identity of the product. This will have not be useful to Tasmania because we pride if ourselves on the clean green image. Other Tasmanian regions are beginning to market under their regional names to try to offset the the push for brand name rather than country identification. The very real names of Tasmania, Hunter or Barossa would conjure up an image of excellence and people would seek out these products because of their regional name. Our regions are crying out for assistance to keep and enterprises in them, yet they have to compete on this very unlevel playing field of capital 'striding the world in seven league boots', moving the home of their brand names their equivaas the markets change. Why, oh, why did Amott's Biscuits get sold and lost to Australia? It was because Pacific Dunlop did not want to develop the line and the Americans saw the opportunity to break Asia at our expense. We might make biscuits in Australia, but the profits have gone overseas and the administration has gone Therefore we have exported that number of jobs, and we are the poorer for it. So I believe government has a duty to be a facilitator, an intervener and, to a certain extent, a protector of Australian industry to ensure that we are a country that can compete-within the boundaries laid down by the World Trade Organisation, but not to try to go beyond it is detrimental to keeping jobs in Australia and to keeping our economy growing. (Time expired) Small Business

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: I grieve today for the difficulties confronting small businesses in Australia. Life has been hard for small business over many years-and it was never harder than under the Australian Labor Party-and they are finding the recovery extremely testing and hard to achieve. I want to grieve for them because I want to bring to. the attention of the House some of the problems that have been created by the obstructiveness of the Senate and by the attitudes of the minor parties in that house. I want to draw to the attention of the House the difficulties that any government has, particularly this government, in bringing change when there exists an attitude that seems to grudgingly agree with the general thrust of government action but does everything to frustrate bringing the government's intention to a quick conclusion. We have had budgets through this House which have taken nearly nine months to finalise. So, when there have been initiatives undertaken, when there have been changes to tax law, when there have been benefits which would flow onto small business, the Senate, particularly the Democrats and the Greens, I am sad to say, have made a great show of how thoughtful they are for the Australian community, but the real group which has been penalised by their delays and inactivity has been small business. I refer especially to the changes to unfair dismissal laws, which were held up for weeks and months by a process of commitVx: inquiry and delay and now have been rej . -;,[ed Senate. Where employees have been employed continuously for 12 month5 and where there are no more than 15 people in an organisation, the unfair dismis';al laws have been removed. Many people in small busilless say to me, 'These laws don't really apply to us because it is very hard to administer them in small business. We are unaffected by them.' In fact, they are affected by them because some of the standards of their larger competitors are really pegged to the costs of paying for unfair dismissal laws. Their competitors and their own environment preclude them from employing a person and expanding their business if they have a degree of uncertainty about that person's intention. An example in my electorate is that of a young businessman starting a new business. He employed somebody who completely misled him in their statements about their fitness to undertake the work. After some period of patience, he suggested they leave. The person left without complaint, but that young businessman found himself before the courts and fined to the extent of $10,000. It absolutely ruined his business. He could not afford the money. His young wife and young children were removed from that business, never to return. So we had another wellintentioned, hard working family irreparably damaged by the process of the unfair dismissal laws. The government sought to change those laws. The Senate did not wish that to happen, despite the result of the election just 18 months ago. It seems that result is not something the Senate is familiar with. Then there is the sale of Telstra. We now find that the sale is imminent and funds are starting to be released. Many jobs are being created for small businesses by the activities involved in repairing Australia's environment-all from the sale of Telstra. That sale was needlessly delayed for more than 12 months. Sensible restrictions and changes to the immigration laws proposed by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) to prevent people who have jumped queues or who are illegal immigrants from . by the taking advantage of the goodwill of the Australian community were blocked in the Senate in the name of human rights-denying job opportunities and business opportunities to small business. Now we have the latest episode in regard to work for the dole, and we will see legislation in here no doubt sometime today in a message from the Senate. Work for the dole proposals are sensible. They are not geared to be harsh for young people, but again the Senate has sought to obstruct. Speaker: Mr KELVIN THOMSON
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: This government is comprehensively failing small business, which is why bankruptcies under this government are skyrocketing. For example, Lend Lease in the AprilMay 1996 edition of its Retailers Digest vaunts its approachability and the impending creation of an independent body, a mutually acceptable party, to act in dispute resolutions between Lend Lease and retailers. Louise Martin, the Lend Lease Retail Chief Executive, says Lend Lease 'measure our success by the success of our retailers' . How well does this claim stand up? The eatery at the Lend Lease-owned Parkmore Shopping Centre in Keysborough is a disaster. Five of the seven outlets are in such a serious situation that they have taken out Federal Court writs against Lend Lease, alleging misrepresentation. When the solicitor for one  wrote to Lend Lease on two occasions in August last year asking for the independent body, to which the Lend Lease propaganda referred, to adjudicate the question of rent, he was told, 'You talk to our centre management people and no-one else.' At Anna's Boutique, the tenant is a woman of Asian origin with limited English skills. She got into rental arrears following misrepresentation by management. She was then conned by management into signing a legal release from indemnity. She thought that in signing she was merely gaining rent relief for three months. She did not have any assistance or representation at this meeting nor was she counselled to seek independent legal advice. She was dealing with a highly trained, skilled and devious manager. By signing this release, the woman had unknowingly waived all future legal rights of redress based on the alleged misrepresentations. I have a copy of the temporary rental abatement agreement that Lend Lease uses in these sorts of cases. Clause 7 says: The rental abatement is granted on the basis that neither you, your employees, your agentsor anyone else... disclose the provisions of this letter (other as may be required by law) without the Lessor's prior written consent. If ... you ... disclose any provisions of this letter, the rental abatement will cease immediately and the Lessor will seek full refund of any concession provided. Any losses or damages incurred by the Landlord as a result of your breach in confidentiality will also be your liability. Clause 9 says: You agree to release the Lessor, its servants and agents from any liability resulting from any representations made to you at any time prior to, at the time of or after the execution of the lease. So there it is-Lend Lease has its tenants enter into secret agreements where they give away their legal rights; and they are not even allowed to tell anybody they have done it! What does Lend Lease tell the public-the rest of us-about the kind of company it is? Its code of conduct, enshrined in every annual report since 1992, says that each individual must apply the highest ethical standards using the test, 'Would I be willing to see what I am considering doing now described in detail on the front page of a national newspaper, there to be read by my family and friends?' If that is the test, why do they make their agreements with their tenants secret? Why shouldn't these agreements be out there on the front pages of our national newspapers? The Lend Lease code of conduct goes further. It says: Any proposed action failing this test should be discarded even though it involves no legal impropriety. Lend Lease wants no part of activities that pass legal tests, but which we, as members of the community find offensive. If that is true, why has Lend Lease got a provision in these rental abatement agreements signed by small businesses, such as Anna's Boutique and Nagina's Boutique, by which the tenants sign away their legal right to sue for misrepresentation? If it is behaving ethically, and is not guilty of misrepresentation, why does it need a clause like that? It is precisely because of this kind of bastardry by Lend Lease, and other large shopping centre owners which I have brought to the attention of this House in the past, that we need action urgently to better protect retail tenants and franchisees. We should have passed Kim Beazley's private member's bill, than the better business conduct bill, and the government should certainly act to implement the recommendations of the House of Representatives fair trading inquiry, which carried out extensive investigations around the nation and found dozens--even hundreds--of exampies of the kind of exploitation I have just outlined. The Liberal government has as its Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) a retail landlord: a man who owns three shopping centres; a man whose own income would be adversely affected if retail tenants and franchisees were to get improved rights and protections; a man who has already made it quite clear where he stands and who has already acted to the detriment of franchisees. In last year's budget he abolished funding for the Franchising Council which Labor set up to give franchisees an avenue for low-cost dispute resolution. At the Property Council of Australia meeting held on 25 October last year at the Hyatt Hotel in Perth, the small business minister said about complaints by retail tenants about their landlords: Many of these complaints are either unfounded or at least one-sided. Did he say, as he said after his personal vested interest was exposed, 'This is a matter for the states'? No. Did he say, 'There is an inquiry going on and its recommendations will be considered on merit'? No. Did he say, 'This is just a personal view. I don't speak for the government on these matters; they are handled by industry Minister Moore'? No. He said: It is the government's view that the landlords should be free to exercise their property rights all but the most exceptional circumstances. The Prime Minister, John Howard, self-proclaimed champion of small business, has put Dracula in charge of the blood bank, the fox in charge of the henhouse, a man who says, 'I'm in favour of voluntary codes of conduct not mandatory, legally enforceable protection for retail tenants and franchisees,' a man whose contempt for John Howard's ministerial code of conduct shows that he regards voluntary codes of conduct with contempt-as just a joke. Australia needs a new small business minister. Prime Minister Howard is a lawyer by trade, and he should understand the legal concepts of conflict of interest and bias which make Minister Prosser's position absolutely untenable. Minister Prosser's personal financial situation depends on contracts with retail tenants and franchisees, an unarguable conflict of interest which means that there can be no public confidence that he will handle retail tenancy and franchising issues dispassionately. Mr Hawker- Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. These are the sorts of issues that should be raised by a substantive motion. I believe there is a personal attack being launched here. I would ask that the member be asked to refrain from this.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: There is no point of order, but I will listen carefully to the member's comments.

Speaker: Mr KELVIN THOMSON
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: Secondly, there is the problem of bias. In law, if a judge or a tribunal makes statements which suggest that they have prejudged the issues, they can be disqualified from hearing a case or have their verdict overturned on the grounds of bias. Minister Prosser's public statements on retail tenancy and franchising show that he has prejudged the issues and is guilty of bias and there will be no confidence amongst retail tenants in any decisions he makes. I conclude with two further examples which help demonstrate the depth of the problem. The Rombotis family were induced to enter into a lease at the Greensborough Plaza on the basis of representations that a state-of-the-art in Myer department store would be a major tenant at the redeveloped shopping centre; that there would be an increase of 30 per cent in the number of customers who attended the shopping centre once this development was completed; that Myer would not have a cafeteria or similar food outlet within its department store; that the multi-level car park would attract customers to the shopping centre, and that their turnover would be some $10,000 to $12,000 per week and would increase over time. What happened was that the Myer store was not a state-of-the-art department store, there was not a substantial increase in customers attending the shopping centre, the people concerned lost substantial sums of money in the business, Myer was permitted to open a bistro food outlet, turnover was not $10,000 to $12,000 per week but only $4,000 per week, and the multi-level car park acted as a deterrent to shoppers. Similarly, the Southland newsagency at Southland Cheltenham, during protracted lease negotiations from May 1996 to March 1997, was subjected to the intolerable pressure of being forced to trade on month-to-month tenancy for some eight months. In August 1996 Mr Graeme Davies was sent a letter by Westfield management saying: This is our final offer to enter into a new lease agreement. Should this offer not be accepted we will have no alternative but to offer the premises to other interested parties. Imagine the impact of this on someone with a business which was worth $1.5 million. How absolutely disgraceful! (Time expired) Roads: Law Enforcement

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: Wannon) (6.25 p.m.)Tonight I would like to grieve about what I see as something we ought to have a growing concern about, and that is the growth of Big Brother, particularly as it relates to people who drive on roads, but also in relation to a number of other areas. My attention was drawn to an article in last week's Bulletin entitled 'Cops and Robots' which showed just how much high-tech is being brought into enforcement against drivers on our roads these days. One of the first thoughts that sprung to my mind was that there seems to be this constant drive for greater conformity and, I would suggest, also greater subservience to our law enforcement on the roads. The question then arises: is this making for a better society or is it using high-tech in a very selective way as a means of trying to reduce road fatalities and road trauma, all of which we want to see occur? But is this the only way we might tackle this problem and IS there an overemphasis on this what I see as unprecedented use of technology in trying to achieve that aim? The article not only showed that this unprecedented use of technology is continuing to grow as a means of enforcing the laws but also it made passing reference to something that I think we ought to look at a bit more closely, and that is the amount of additional revenue that this law enforcement is raising, which brings to mind a number of other questions about the whole thrust of this road safety program. Nowadays we have hidden cameras for speed, we have hidden cameras for red light running, we have more sophisticated laser guns for speeding, and we are seeing the trial of the use of satellites in hooking up to these guns so that a centralised data collection agency can mail out the bills even faster to collect the money even quicker. We see under trial things like intelligent parking meters that will be able to book you the minute you overstay on a parking metre without someone having to be there. We are seeing the trialling of black box recorders, which have long been in use in aeroplanes. There is now some suggestion that we may see the use of satellite tracking of private drivers. One wonders what that is going to mean when the question comes, 'Where were you last night, dear?' and in regard to some of the other side-effects we might see. My real concern about all this is that so much of it seems to be occurring with very little public scrutiny. The first question that comes to mind is whether this is being driven by the enforcement agencies or are the public really agreeing to what is going on. The next question that arises is this: what evidence is there for this continuing drive to employ ever more sophisticated technology to enforce laws where clearly there is a diminishing return, but not in terms of raising finance? The next question that arises is: does this cover other shortcomings in public policy, such as inadequate road funding, or insufficient driving training, or not concentrating on other bad driver habits? The question then arises: does society really accept the enormous and almost unfettered powers that are being given to enforcement agencies, far greater than they would have when it came to any other civil action in dealing with the general public? Does the concentration on booking drivers add to a negative attitude by the public towards the police, thereby leading to less effective use of their abilities when it comes to other law enforcement activities? Is there evidence that this unrelenting enforcement is leading to better drivers? Often this enforcement is done in a very hidden way, with speed cameras being hidden behind bushes and so on. Is this leading to a better driver, given that the driver is not aware of the surveiIlance at the time?

Speaker: Unknown
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to

Speaker: Mr HAWKER
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: As I was saying before the dinner suspension, there seems to be an overemphasis on enforcement. I reaIly do think that society is starting to question whether or not the enormous and almost unfettered powers given to enforcement agencies may not be the only way to attack some of the problems we face with road trauma. It is very interesting to note on this point that social researcher Hugh MCKay believes that the current approach is much more likely to lead to more frightened drivers rather than better drivers. That is a very significant point, given the enormous emphasis there has been on trying to intimidate drivers through penalties and the use of hidden cameras and new technology-I think often to the detriment of using the police force for its other duties in society and also to looking at some of the other issues that we should be concentrating on in trying to improve road safety. This brings me to the next issue: whether not the statistics actually support the ever tougher and more sophisticated enforcement of our road laws. Some statistics show that road traffic is increasing by about 30 per cent each decade. In other words, the number of cars and trucks on the road is continuing to grow. As has been shown by some earlier work, not only is Australia's road toll continuing to decline but it is continuing to decline very much in line with countries which have not enforced road laws with such ferocity as Australia has. A comparison of the figures for New South Wales and Victoria is rather revealing, particularly given that in 1993-94 Victoria booked 60 per cent more speeding drivers than New South Wales did, even though Victoria has a smaller number of drivers than New South Wales. Yet, if we look at driver fatalities, which I think is not only quite a good measure of the seriousness of the problem but also helpful in comparing what is happening in the states, we find that over the IS-year period from 1980 to 1995 the number of fatalities in Victoria fell from 233 per year to 189 but in New South Wales over the same period the number of fatalities fell from 487 8 p.m. per year to 281. In other words, Victoria saw a drop of 19 per cent while New South Wales saw a drop of 42 per cent, yet at the same time Victoria has significantly increased its enforcement and particularly has stepped up the number of cameras and other forms of enforcement, particularly for speeding. In Victoria, from 1990 until recently the number of speed cameras has increased from just four to more than 60-and that is only the number of speed cameras. The number of other enforcement methods such as radar guns and so on runs well into the hundreds. So I raise a very serious question here: is this focus on enforcement about trying to reduce the statistics or is it indeed about other things such as revenue? Given the comparison between Victoria and New South Wales, there is the very distinct possibility that revenue is playing an increasing role in this decision to step up enforcement. It is time that these questions were raised. One could go on and raise further questions. or In relation to road safety I have mentioned roads and driver education. Other questions could be raised such as: why is it equally safe to travel at 100 kilometres an hour on an open road in a FJ Holden as it is in the latest Commodore, which has radial tyres, air bags, anti-lock disk brakes, progressively crumpling body on impact, quartz-iodide lights and so on? These are all measures of a vastly superior motor car, yet far less superior ones can travel legally at the same speed. Road accidents, as I have said, are a major concern to Australia. But it is time to seriously question the emphasis on enforcement and, dare I say it, on revenue. I think we ought to be looking at other issues as weIl, such as what better roads mean. Statistics show that better roads are safer roads. For example, widening traffic lanes by just a metre reduces head-on and run-off crashes by 20 per cent, passing lanes can cut crashes by as much as 50 per cent and replacing an undivided road with a freeway reduces the incidence of crashes by 90 per cent. The second point to look at is driver education, given that 95 per cent of all accidents are due to driver error. I think when we look at all these issues a rational approach to road safety has to be a better approach. (Time expired). Felix, Mrs Ruth: Treatment by Commonwealth Bank Griffiths, Mr Terry: Hilton Hotel

Speaker: Mr MOSSFIELD
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: I rise in this grievance debate to express my concerns about the treatment by the Commonwealth Bank of a constituent of Greenway, Mrs Ruth Felix, who is 68 years old. To put Mrs Felix's case, I quote from her solicitor's letter to the Commonwealth Bank dated 22 August 1997: Our client advises that on 28 March 1990 she attended at the Commonwealth Bank and was requested to sign a document. This document was not explained to her and, although she was aware that the document referred to her property at 69 Davis Road Blacktown, she was not informed that by signing the mortgage she was placing her property at risk. She understood that she was merely signing a document that would assist her son in his business venture. Further, she was not advised to seek independent legal advice before she signed the document and she was therefore totally unaware of the consequences of signing the document. In early 1994 Mr Brian Felix's business, Harmony Felix Pty Limited, failed and the bank required the loan repaid in full. Consequently Mr Brian Felix sold his home and the full net proceeds were paid to the bank. Mr Felix was declared bankrupt and the bank turned its attention to Mrs Susan Felix Mrs Ruth Felix. Mrs Ruth Felix continued to pay as much as she could each month to the bankin total, and these are my figures, she paid an amount of $24,000but in May 1995 she was issued with a notice to vacate. Our client was very confused with the proceedings that were taking place and she placed her property on the market with a view to selling it and paying out the bank. At this time the housing market was very slow and the bank did not afford her the courtesy of permitting time for a sale to be negotiated. The locks on the house were replaced by the bank's own agent who was instructed to sell it. Our client has not been advised in relation to the sale price, adjustments made at settlement, agents' commission or legal costs that may have been incurred. She did receive a letter stating that $95,194.48 from the sale of the property was applied to various loans but this would indicate that the house at 69 Davis Road Blacktown did not realise its market potential and was sold for a minimal amount I wrote to the Commonwealth Bank on 2 May Bombing 1997, outlining Mrs Felix's problem. My office received an acknowledgment letter dated 7 May and a faxed detailed reply on 19 June which included a response to Mrs Felix's solicitor faxed the same day, 19 June. I will now quote from the bank's letter to Mrs Felix's solicitor. It said: The bank wrote to Mrs Felix on 12 March 1990 (copy enclosed for ease of reference) enclosing a mortgage document prepared for her signature in this letter and advising Mrs Felix to obtain appropriate legal advice or otherwise if she was at all uncertain of her position. Mrs Felix had on a number of occasions executed mortgages over the property. It would be difficult to concur with your claim that by signing the mortgage she was placing her property at risk. Mrs Felix-who was 61 at the time, is now 68 and continues to have to work-advised me that she did not receive this correspondence and the documents she signed on 28 March 1990 were in fact documents provided by the bank to her for the first time at the time of her signing. Mrs Felix also advised me that, contrary to the statement in the bank's letter, she has never had any previous executive mortgages over the property other and than that which she took out to buy it. Many matters still remain unresolved relating to this issue, but I raise the following points which go to the bank's ethical and professional dealings with its customers and may be issues worthy of government legislation at a later date. Firstly, there is the question of the ethical responsibility of the Commonwealth Bank accepting as a guarantor the family home of a 61-year-old widow who, in the event of an unsuccessful business venture, would be unlikely to recover financially. Secondly, there is the ethical responsibility of the Commonwealth Bank taking steps to sell Mrs Felix's home when she had returned to employment and was doing her best to repay the loan, having paid $24,000 off the loan as of 9 May 1994. Thirdly, there is the question of the ethical responsibility of accepting as guarantor two family homes-the mother's and the son's. In the event of a failed business venture, the family loses two homes. That issue raises a lot of questions and the Commonwealth Bank has to answer them, and fairly quickly. I would now like to move on to another grievance that I would like to refer to tonight. This relates to another constituent of mine, Mr Terry Griffiths. Mr Griffiths is well known as the police officer who, in the course of his duty, was severely injured when a bomb exploded outside the Hilton Hotel at 12.40 a.m. on Monday, 13 February 1978, prior to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. I am aware that a number of members, both past and present, have already spoken on this issue. They include the former Labor member for Macarthur, Mr Chris Haviland, the former member for North Sydney, Mr Ted Mack, and the present member for Warringah, Mr Tony Abbott. Mr Griffiths has recently approached me for support and I am very happy to provide that support. The facts conveyed to me by Mr Griffiths are that at about 12.40 a.m. on Monday, 13 February 1978, a massive bomb exploded in George Street outside the Hilton Hotel. As a result, two council workers were killed instantly and a police officer was mortally injured and died nine days later. Mr Griffiths was injured. A piece of shrapnel penetrated his side. He still carries that piece of shrapnel in his abdomen. Mr Griffiths also sustained a wound to the outside of his knee from a large piece of shrapnel. Mr Griffiths advises me that on the evening of 12 February 1978 he commenced duty outside the Hilton Hotel shortly after II p.m. He noticed that the garbage bin on the edge of the footpath was overflowing with rubbish and comments were made about the bin being located right at the entrance to the hotel. At about 12.40 a.m. the next morning, a council garbage truck stopped in front of the hotel. One man moved from the truck, picked up the bin and went to the rear of the vehicle. He tipped the bin upside down and a massive explosion occurred. Since this period, Mr Griffiths has campaigned vigorously for a Commonwealth-state inquiry into the Hilton bombing. On 9 December 1991 a unanimous vote was carried in the New South Wales state parliament supporting a joint federal-state inquiry into the Hilton bombing. Mr Griffiths has on many occasions sought to put his views to the appropriate federal and state authorities and so far has been unsuccessful in getting the inquiry. In 1983 he wrote to the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies, seeking permission to appear before it and put his views on the Hilton bombing. Mr Griffiths received a letter of acknowledgment, but was not called to appear. Mr Griffiths also requested the New South Wales Premier and the royal commissioner inquiring into the New South Wales police force to place the Hilton bombing matter before the commission, without success. Mr Griffiths has said that he has been advised by Mr Hatton, the ex-Independent MP for the South Coast in the state parliament, that the commission's terms of reference were framed in such a way as to include matters like the Hilton bombing. Mr Griffiths' theory is that the bomb that exploded outside the Hilton Hotel on the morning of 13 February 1978 was deliberately placed there to justify the existence of a counter-terrorist organisation in Australia. Mr Griffiths' theory is that a number of other government organisations were involved. In view of the wide ranging support Mr Griffiths has received, and to test the views held by Mr Griffiths, I believe a joint Commonwealth-state inquiry into the bombing is justified. I hope the present government will agree to this course of action. Local Government Funding

Speaker: Mr MAREK
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: Capricornia) (8.15 p.m.)For too long now, local government bodies in Queensland have been getting a raw deal over the Commonwealth government's overly simplistic distribution of general purpose funding to states. It grieves me to think that the Commonwealth Grants Commission completed a review in 1991 which clearly showed that Queensland was being severely disadvantaged under the current distribution system. Six years on, absolutely nothing has been done about it. Queensland has been fighting for a fair deal since the 1980s, when Labor was in power. It is with no great surprise that I report that they got nowhere. I have first hand knowledge of the struggle, as I campaigned strongly for a fair deal when I was a councillor on the Belyando Shire Council. I say that it is now time to correct the wrongs of the past, to balance the scales and give Queensland local governments what they deserve: a fair deal. It has been proved that the current per capita system used to calculate the distribution of funds simply does not work. This system does not recognise the different needs of each state, nor does it recognise the individuality of local governments. States like Victoria, where the population is combined to a small geographic area, have thrived on this system. States like Queensland, where the population is spread over a large geographic area, have been severely disadvantaged. With the redistribution we will have shortly, Queensland will gain a seat and the ACT will lose a seat-an indicator that people are moving up to Queensland. It just goes to prove that Queensland should be getting more money. I give you one example of this unfairness: the distribution of moneys for roads. On a per capita basis, Queensland appears to have one of the highest levels of road expenditure. But these figures are deceiving. On a per kilometre basis, Queensland's expenditure is well below that of more densely populated areas. The result is that, under the current per capita system, Queensland can only dream of building and maintaining roads of a standard similar to that in more populated states. This is not for want of trying. In 1995, Queensland local government allocated 31 per cent of its current outlays to road transport. This is well above the national average of 22 per cent. In my electorate of Capricornia, the condition and safety of roads is a major concern to the people I represent. Because of the remote nature of many of the communities in Capricornia, people have to frequently travel long distances to access services that people in metropolitan areas take for granted. Apart from roads, the remote nature of Queensland, coupled with its low population density, leaves the state severely disadvantaged in terms of receiving adequate funding to provide other basic services. Queensland has less than five persons per square kilometre, while states like Victoria have approximately 20 persons per square kilometre. This means that Queensland receives less money to provide the same services as other states over a larger geographic area. To confine these services to more densely populated areas like the state's southeast region is not a fair or viable option, especially in a decentralised state like Queensland. Take my own electorate, situated in central Queensland, as an example. This area is a thousand kilometres from Townsville, more than 600 kilometres from Brisbane, and over 2,000 kilometres from Canberra. There is no way people in my electorate can simply visit places like Brisbane and Townsville to access services people in more densely populated areas take for granted. This has resulted in a situation where Queensland's local governments are having to allocate a larger proportion of their resources to provide basic services, and of course for infrastructure. This is being done at the cost of providing human services-human services which other councils have the lUXUry of providing simply because they are better resourced to meet a wide range of community needs. Another factor which is not taken into consideration is the diverse nature of communities that local governments in Queensland service. This is an important differentiation, as Queensland recognises the need of Aboriginal communities to have their own system of local government. The Northern Territory is the only other state which recognises this need. What I find more alarming is that local go'. ernments in Queensland also have to provide a wider range of basic services compared to local governments in other states. In Queensland, local governments are responsible for providing water supplies and sewage disposal. The provision of these two essential services by local governments is not universal and does not fall under the realm of local governments in all Australian states, whereas in Queensland it does. Queensland relies heavily on receiving funding from the Commonwealth to provide these essential services and others. Our revenue raising capabilities are severely restricted, as the population has lower average earnings and land value per capita is also lower than other states. Despite this, the population is rapidly growing and with it the need for more services. As the situation is left unresolved, the needs of local governments in Queensland grow. It is time for a change and a fair deal. Distributing funds on a per capita basis is simply not working. Instead, it is severely disadvantaging states such as Queensland, while other states flourish. Let us not continue in Labor's footsteps. We need to stop treating states as though their needs and wants are identical. We need to review the current funding distribution method and make changes-changes which are long overdue. I repeat: it is time to balance the scales and offer Queensland's local governments a fair deal. Another grievance I wish to raise is the fight by the Local Government Association of Queensland to secure a commitment from the federal Treasurer (Mr Costello) that federal company and sales tax will not apply to local government owned corporations. In 1996 the Treasurer ruled it out, and I am confident he will maintain this position. After spending 15 months approaching the government from all angles, the association feels the Treasurer has procrastinated on this matter for far too long. The association has now resorted to more drastic action and plans to embark on an advertising and direct mail campaign in the hope that the public pressure will motivate the government to remedy the situation. I have already outlined the battles facing local government, especially in Queensland. So let us do something right. Let us show them that we understand their plight and grant them their simple request.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: Mr Vaile)Order! The question is: That grievances be noted. Question resolved in the affirmative. NA NA  Small Business and Consumer Affairs) (8.23 p.m.)-With your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker, this is the first opportunity since question time concluded today for me to come into the House to make this statement. Honourable members will be aware that we have had private members business up until now. Advice from the Clerk's office is that it is inappropriate to cut into private members business time in the House and the first opportunity when that concludes is right now. In the light of questions I have been asked today and in order that there is absolute clarity in this matter, and that there is no misunderstanding in relation to what I said in the House on Thursday, 19 June, in reply to a question from the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin), I reconfirm that I had one discussion with Mr Nick Greiner of Coles Myer concerning the Eaton lot. I requested a contact point for my brother relating to a proposed Target store. He told me to get my brother to write to him. He subsequently did so. I never discussed the detail. I did not discuss any other matter with Mr Greiner. I have had no further contact with Mr Greiner and there are no commercial arrangements between Coles Myer and any other company with which I am associated. This account of events is consistent with Mr Greiner's statement today. Motion of Censure

Title: AYES ACTING PRIME MINISTER
text: I move: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving forthwith that this House censures the Acting Prime Minister for: (l) his failure to ensure the Minister for Small NOES Business upheld the Prime Minister's ministerial code of conduct; and (2) his failure to ensure that the minister corrected his misleading and woefully inadequate declaration of pecuniary interests so that the parliament and the people could have a true understanding of his multiple business interests and how they conflicted with his ministerial responsibilities and his failure, when those conflicts were revealed, to seek the Prime Minister's approval to dismiss the minister particularly in light of the minister's obvious attempt to use the status of position to secure advantage for his property investments by taking the outrageous step of contacting a fellow member of the Liberal Party, the Deputy Chairman of Coles Myer, Mr Greiner, to secure a Target store as a key tenant for his Eaton development while using the flimsy pretext of saying he was merely asking for a telephone number for his brother when it was clear that he would be the 95 per cent beneficiary of such a decision to locate such a premium tenant on his properties-properties he holds while minister in charge of retail tenancy-when in fact, if he was really committed to the code of conduct, he would have told his brother to pick up the phone and dial dire.ctory assistance rather than so blatantly attempt to SIgnal to Mr Greiner that he as a minister should be treated better.' Mr Speaker, we move this motion because of the pusillanimous performance byMotion (by Mr Reith) put: That the member be not further heard. The House divided. Small Business and Consumer Affairs) (9.11 p.m.)-I move: That the amendments be agreed to. The Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) 1996 has been returned from the Senate with amendments. I am pleased to state that the bill passed through the other house on 17 June without significant amendment. The bill was amended in the Senate as a result of consultation and consideration by the government and proposals put by other parties. The government has always indicated that it would consider amending the bill when it was first introduced into this House. The bill implements the changes to the eligibility in the mining sector resulting from consultations with the mining industry. It also includes measures to improve administration and accountability. The government has decided not to proceed with defining beneficiation in an exhaustive way. Whether a process does or does not constitute beneficiation for the purpose of the diesel fuel rebate scheme will continue to be a matter decided on a case by case basis. In this connection, the government has decided that the meaning of beneficiation should be settled based on technical evidence in respect of the processes and should not involve market considerations that might affect the decision as to how the mineral or ore is processed. The bill also contains an amendment to specifically negate the issue of rebate being paid for vehicles travelling on a public road in the mining operations category. Similarly, transport of people, goods and services by rail and sea are excluded. This amendment ensures that rebate is not paid on fuel used to propel any vehicle on a public road, even if the journeys undertaken by that vehicle can otherwise be characterised as integral to one of the activities listed in the relevant definition. In so doing, the government is confirming that the diesel fuel rebate scheme is a targeted scheme that is intended to pay rebate strictly in respect of those activities that form part of the definition of mining operations. Concerns have been expressed to the government that record keeping provisions in the bill could be construed as prescriptive, requiring the keeping of logbooks and operational records. This was never the government's intention. The amendments to the diesel fuel record keeping obligation clarify the proposed requirement to keep diesel fuel records by removing any suggestion that particular types of records have to be kept. If an applicant for diesel fuel rebate has records which can substantiate the actual nature of the use of the fuel, those records will be sufficient for the purpose of the document retention obligation. The onus is on the user of the fuel to keep such records as are necessary to demonstrate that the actual use of the fuel was in an eligible category. In concluding the debate, I would like to thank all of those members who had an input into this debate-a debate which started in December of last year in this House.

Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Title: LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL
text: I will not canvass the issues that the Minister for Small Business and Consumer  the amendments to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) 1996. It is sufficient to say that these matters were exhaustively canvassed in the Senate by Senator Cook, who had the carriage of the matter for the opposition in that place. This is a customs bill but, as the policy issues go to the minerals and resources industry, I have the carriage of it in this place. So far as specifics are concerned, I think it is worthwhile putting on the record in this place that the opposition is particularly distressed about the government's decisions, which it carried in the Senate by weight of numbers, in respect of 3Y2 tonne vehicles, safety vessels for the servicing of offshore oil and petroleum rigs, limestone and the implications that has for the cement industry and also-one for the aficionados-the definition so far as place of mining is concerned. There was one victory in the Senate for the opposition and that was in respect of the rebate on the washing processes for salt. It was a victory achieved by the opposition for the salt export industry. There could not in very many respects be a better illustration as to how the policy matters that drive this area are better handled by an arm of government other than Customs. Salt is an important export industry and the rationale presented by Customs on the first occasion as to why the diesel fuel rebate ought to cease at the wet washing process was that salt put into that state was suitable for sale into the domestic swimming pool market. That ignores completely any notion of a salt export industry. Other than putting those things formally on the record and welcoming that modest little gain on behalf of the opposition, I might ask the minister: given that this bill was presented in the context of discussions with the industry, the higher level group, and understandings by the industry that the government would not subsequently impose a cap on the diesel fuel rebate scheme, what are the government's intentions in that respect and how did its meeting go with the representatives of the industry on Monday last week?
