text: There is no objection to that procedure taking place.

Speaker: Mr JULL
Title: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
text: I move: That Senate amendment No.9 be agreed to. This amendment clarifies that the declaration required from candidates that they are not candidates in any other election refers only to other state and territory elections for half of the delegates to attend the convention and not, for example, a parliamentary election. It responds to a recommendation from the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee.

Speaker: Mr MEL HAM
Title: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
text: The opposition supports this amendment. Question resolved in the affirmative.

Speaker: Mr JULL
Title: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
text: I move: That Senate amendments Nos 1 to 8 and 10 to 68 be disagreed to. Senate amendment No. 1 proposes a preamble be included which specifies the role of the enve- convention and the appointment and election of delegates to the convention. The House of Representatives does not accept the amendment as it does not reflect the purpose and scope of the bill. Amendments Nos 2 to 8 and 11 to 68 focus on the method of voting for half of the delegates to the Constitutional Convention, which will meet for 10 days in December 1997 to consider the question of whether or not Australia should become a republic. The amendments require that voting in the election be by a compulsory attendance ballot which will make Australians who choose not to vote in the election for delegates liable to prosecution and add up to $20 million to the cost. The amendments also propose that the election be conducted along the lines of a Senate election. In light of the large number of candidates who could contest this election, possibly exceeding 200 to 300 candidates in New South Wales, a pure Senate style election would make it difficult for electors to vote for someone other than a large group and would extend the time needed to count the vote. Accordingly, the House of Representatives opposes these amendments. Senate amendment No. 10 provides that a candidate's $500 nomination fee should be returned if the candidate is elected or if the candidate or candidate group receives at least four per cent of the total number of votes. Given that the government will be providing a tax deduction for election expenses up to a limit of $1,000 to candidates whether successful or not, the House of Representatives does not accept amendment No. 10.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
text: We oppose the course of action being proposed by the government and support the amendments which have been successfully carried in the Senate. These amendments involve matters of very high principle as far as the operation of our democracy is concerned. These amendments go to reinstating for this most important of ballots the Australian secret ballot. The Australian secret ballot has two essential elements to it: one is its compulsory nature-it has been that way since the early 1920s-and the other is its secrecy. It is a ballot which is conducted free of anybody's purview other than that of the person casting the vote. It is essential that this be upheld because it has been a centrepiece of the avoidance of intimidation in our political system. It is a system so famous, so comprehensively successful, that it is one of the things that we are known for around the world: the fact that we stand for total secrecy in our ballots and that an Australian exercises his or her conscience with absolute freedom. This is being jettisoned by this convention. It is being jettisoned for bad motives. Those motives became much clearer earlier in the course of this session when we had a report from the relevant parliamentary committee with a recommendation which we know emanates from the man who is basically responsible for the carriage of this inside the government and in which he calls for an end to the compulsory vote. We are confident in pursuing this against that recommendation in the knowledge that this piece of Americanisation of the Australian political system is not supported by the Australian public. Indeed, the Morgan poll out today indicates that 68 per cent of people support the retention of a compulsory ballot and 29 per cent are in favour of voluntary voting. The figures for the two political parties are much the same. There is not a weighting in favour of Labor Party voters for maintaining a compulsory vote. Labor Party voters and Liberal Party voters are ad idem on this. This they regard as central to the operation of democracy. If the government is not being secretive in putting forward a set of propositions to test them ultimately for a fundamental change in Australia's democratic processes, if that is not its motive, then the other possible interpretation of why they are doing this is to be deprecated as well. That other interpretation as to why they are doing this obviously revolves around the seriousness with which they regard this convention. They want wriggle room. They want to be able to dismiss its outcome. They want to be able to question its representivity. They will have no problem questioning its representivity should the government's position on this with the propositions that they have put forward prevail. Irrespective of the turnout, even if 100 per cent of those who receive ballot papers do indeed vote, they will be able to test the representivity of it by reference to other factors. Up to 3 million Australians may not receive their ballot papers because they have changed their address since the last election. Material on the ballot will only be available in writing and only in English, disenfranchising those who are blind, frail or aged, illiterate or whose English skills are not of a sufficiently high standard. A postal ballot provides greater opportunities for voters to be influenced by a strongwilled member of the family. This will sit for days on the kitchen table, vulnerable to anybody who decides to walk in, be it Uncle Bill or Aunt Maude or anyone with more sinister intent as they go up and down the streets trying to put pressure on them to arrive at a particular conclusion. That is why we have secret ballots. These are the reasons, and there are others, why we are taking a strong stand in favour of Australia's traditional democracy as far as voting for this matter is concerned. This House would be well advised to support the Senate in this regard to re-establish, if nothing else, the bona fides of this government as far as its preparedness to protect the essential features of Australian democracy, are concerned. Your sleight-of-hand dismissal of the entirety of Australia's political history is deprecated and condemned and was opposed by the bulk of the Australian people when invited to express an opinion on it. You are bowdlerising the debate about our constitutional arrangements. Only the Labor Party can be trusted to put a proposition to the Australian people that gives them an opportunity to declare themselves on it. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
text: The Australian Labor Party will be insisting on a compulsory election in relation to this convention. A compulsory vote is the only way to give credibility to this convention. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, Senator Minchin, is using this convention as a stalking horse to bring in non-compulsory voting. We will be insisting on a compulsory attendance ballot because we want to give credibility to the convention. The Parliamentary Secretary and the government want to tum the convention into a sham. That is why they are rejecting the amendments that the Senate, quite properly, insisted upon. A compulsory attendance ballot means that people can involve themselves-not two to three million people missing out on an important convention. We believe that there should have been an indicative plebiscite, but the government walked away from that. This is the next best thing. We want to give credibility to the convention. There is no credibility when two to three million people will miss out. I have here a sample ballot paper-and that is only the top half, not the bottom half, if you want to number every square. If you want to vote for a group vote you just put '1' in the square. It is a sham, and it is a deliberate sham. The Parliamentary Secretary is running around distorting the figures for a compulsory attendance ballot and a voluntary postal ballot. He says that the differential figure is $20 million. It is no such thing. A supplementary submission by the Australian Electoral Commission to the Senate committee showed that the difference was $131f2 million, and that was on the basis that the material would be put in an envelope this size-and this is less than half the ballot paper. So for a large envelope, the figures are doubled. You can to be add another $8 million. The difference is about $5 million between a compulsory attendance ballot and a voluntary postal ballot. It is value for money, because in a compulsory attendance ballot you will get a better turnout, you will get a scrutiny of people voting, you will have someone there present, independent, assisting. What this sham is about, this voluntary postal ballot, is discrediting any attempt to move towards a republic. Senator Minchin's views are well-known. The views of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) are well-known. They want to use this voluntary postal ballot as an excuse to discredit the convention, to discredit the push towards a republic. If the Prime Minister had any decency about him and if the Parliamentary Secretary had any decency about him, they would be facilitating the process, they would be doing everything they could to get as many people as possible in the Australian electorate participating. But barrier after barrier is being put up to, in effect, depress the number of people participating. One of the reasons this country has credibility and one of the reasons that the Australian Electoral Commission is being asked to go to other countries to show them how to do compulsory attendance ballots is the participation rate of some 96 per cent of people. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) mentioned an opinion poll. The poll-driven Prime Minister should listen to what the Morgan Gallup poll says. It says that there is little difference between Liberal and National Party voters and Labor supporters in relation to the compulsory attendance ballot. Of the coalition voters responding to the survey, 68 per cent supported the retention of the compulsory ballot and 29 per cent were in favour of voluntary voting. For Labor voters, 70 per cent supported a compulsory ballot and 29 per cent were in favour of voluntary voting. The system works. It ain't broke. You do not have to fix it. The reason you want a voluntary postal vote is that you are trying to sabotage the move towards a republic. You are trying to discredit the convention. You are not fair dinkum. You are using weasel words. The Labor Party will push this when it comes back to the Senate. We will not walk away from compulsory voting. It is what gives us credibility. It is what little credibility is left in the system. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
text: I want to further intervene in this debate and go to a discussion, firstly, of the ballot and then the purpose of the whole exercise. I really do have to ask whether the former state director of the Liberal Party, Senator Minchin in the other place, would really prepare for himself and be prepared to go to a poll with a ballot paper and a how-to-vote card that looked like this. This is absurd.

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
text: That is only half of it.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
text: It is half the paper and it has interspersed candidates in between various different groups. If they come out from underneath the line, they have to work their way through all of that to establish a preference between them. They are to do that without the assistance of any form of instruction at all. It sits there on the table. This is an absolutely absurd proposition. It is a deliberately absurd proposition. Those opposite would not for one minute contemplate themselves running under a ballot like that. This is descending into high farce. As each day goes by, the Electoral Commission informs the government of yet another problem, yet another difficulty, associated with this. We are debating this in the parliament without the Electoral Commission being able to provide us with very many answers on how this will effectively and practically be done. When we actually look at what will have to be done-with the instruction booklet, with everybody's biography in it, and all the arguments associated with it, and then the interplay of that instruction book with that gigantic ballot that is completely incomprehensible-we begin to see why they are suspicious themselves. Instead of saying confidently, as they used to, that this will cost $20 million extra to do it this way rather than by an attendance ballot, they are now saying, 'Well, up to $20 million.' Indeed, up to $20 million-it is about $16 million short of it. That is what it is about: up to $20 million but reaching about $4 million, if that, by the time this particular exercise has been gone through by them. The simple fact of the matter is this: it is perfectly legitimate to hold a view in this community that you would rather see the existing state of affairs persisted with. It is perfectly legitimate to hold a view in this community that you would rather something different. Both are entirely honourable positions and they ought to be argued sensibly and fairly. I actually happen to hold the view that the arrangements ought to change. While I do not regard this as the issue on which everybody will stand and fall in their lives, it is nevertheless important enough for Australian people to want to be able to exercise a sensible and effective choice, to have it taken out of the hands of politicians and to get an opportunity to express a view themselves. There is a simple way of doing this. It is to ask them via a plebiscite: are you in favour of an Australian head of state-yes or no? If the answer is no, then you go back to the drawing board for a substantial period. If the answer is yes, then you move on. You do not create these extraordinary artificial structures-half appointed and half not appointed; the criteria for those who go for appointment. Who really knows what all that means? Is it weighted in a way that will give the government the outcome it wants? Are they going to be genuinely independent of any particular government preferences as far as that is concerned? Then you go to the elected end of the proposition, where we find the most extraordinary distorted process that people are invited to go through. There is no doubt whatsoever that the basis on which it is conducted will probably disenfranchise, irrespective of who chooses to tum up, some 3.2 million Australians. That is a bizarre outcome-a bizarre outcome by the standards of anybody who is genuinely committed to trying to find some level of representivity of public opinion in this process. There is only one common sense way, as I said, to go that is in keeping with the dignity of this proposition, and that is the way that we suggested some considerable time ago. There ought to be no embarrassment as far as the government is concerned in putting it forward. The government will suffer when this ultimately turns up on people's doorsteps. Irrespective of the difficulty that people have with it, they will very quickly come to the conclusion that this government seeks deliberately to confuse them. They will respond to that with anger and hostility towards this government. Allow us to save you from yourselves. Allow us to put this proposition through and rescue you from the ridiculous position you have managed to get yourselves into. If the process involving your ballot paper and your postal processes goes through, it will become a major figure of fun and those who advocate it will be seen as a bunch of bumblers-at worse, insincere about what they are doing and, at best, incompetent. That will not be a very good outcome for the reputation of this government, as the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Jull), who is at the table, knows. Save Senator Minchin from himself, Minister. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
text: For the edification of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), the simple fact is this: with this legislation having been treated in the Senate as it has been, if the government has any brains at all it would scrap the whole proposition. It seems that both sides of the House have been permeated by the pernicious doctrine of Keating which said the big issues in Australia were Mabo, the republic and the flag. As I told Keating and the caucus at that time, the big issues in this country are jobs, jobs and jobs. It is about time the Labor Party realised that. This is a nonsense concept that the government has put forward anyway. It has proposed a system of electing the convention. Clearly, that system will exclude an enormous number of people. The truth is this: in this craven House today the Labor Party talks about a republic, but many of its members are frightened, because they know their voters do not want it. On the other hand, there are only three people on the Liberal front-bench that can be relied upon to hold the line for the present system. I will name them for you: the Minister for Defence (Mr MCLachlan), the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer). You could not guarantee anyone else on the Liberal front-bench to support the monarchy. What ought to be done in this case is quite simple. We ought to put the proposition in conjunction with the next election so that the people can vote on it. Having then got their result, if they decide they want to change, we can then go to a convention to decide on the form of the change and offer it to the people. That would be the logical way to do it. But the question should not be the weasel words as they are-'Do you want an Australian head of state?' - because quite clearly the Governor General is the head of state in this country and the position of Governor General has been filled by an Australian many times. I think it has been a long time since we have had a non-Australian Governor General. It is clearly a weasel way when you ask, 'Do you want an Australian head of state?' Of course people do, and that is what they have got in our governors-general. How can anyone defy the logic of the sequence of events? We should ask the people whether they want to change. If the people of Australia say that they want a change on the basis of a constitutional referendum-and it must be on that basis; not with Sydney and Melbourne carrying sway over the whole of Australia-it is then the time to have a convention to offer the people the form of the change. To do it any other way is certainly a diminution of democracy. When I hear the Leader of the Opposition talk about wanting democracy by having a vote on this, I wonder how in heaven's name are the people of Australia going to determine who is of any value in that convention-I certainly would not be able to and 95 per cent of the population would not be able to either. It is simply an absolute nonsense. I ask the government, having had the legislation treated like this in the Senate, to simply scrap the proposition altogether and run in conjunction with the next election the simple proposition, 'Do you want Australia to be a repUblic?'

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
text: The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, Senator Minchin, is a shrewd political operator. He used to be the state director of the Liberal Party in South Australia. Firstly, he is running an agenda here to, in effect, scuttle the convention, to discredit the convention. That is why he wants a non-compulsory postal ballot. Secondly, Senator Minchin has broken the convention of previous parliaments in relation to parliamentary secretaries sitting on committees of the parliament. My recollection is that, in the six years that members of the Labor government held the positions of parliamentary secretaries, the convention was that they did not sit on parliamentary committees. We know now why he is on the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. He has another agenda, and he wants to use the constitutional convention to run that agenda as well-that is, to bring in non-compulsory voting. He is on the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters not to make the electoral system any better but to manipulate the electoral system to the benefit of the tories and the conservative parties. So Senator Minchin is running two agendas here. That is what he is doing as a political operator. He is trying to use the convention as a stalking horse for non-compulsory voting, and it was inconvenient for him that the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters produced its majority recommendation last week for non-compulsory voting. Senator Minchin should be put back in his place. The Australian electorate like compulsory voting. It is their opportunity to particiin pate in the system. It gives them ownership of the system. It gives the system credibility. In recent elections the attendance has been 95 per cent or 96 per cent. It does not create disaffection in the community, like it does in Great Britain or the United States, where they resort to other activities because they do not come along and vote. He is breaking the convention in terms of sitting on committees. Why? Because he wants to use the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters to pursue his narrow political objectives. He then wants to carry out his particular view of the world and of course the view of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), because in the end he is the agent of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister is on the record as wanting, in effect, to scuttle the republic. He should not be doing that. As Prime Minister of this country, he should be showing leadership and allowing the people to be able to properly put their views. That is why the Labor Party insists on a compulsory attendance ballot-so that the system of voting, the method of voting, cannot be criticised and so that the convention cannot be brought into disrepute. The Prime Minister should show leadership on this issue. He should accept that the parliament, the other chamber, the minor parties and the Labor Party were successful in only one real thing, and that was having a compulsory attendance ballot in relation to the convention. Why? Because it gives his convention some credibility. At the moment, if the government persists with this line, that convention will have no credibility and voters will be disenfranchised. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) tells us that he wants a referendum on the GST. Is that going to be by a postal ballot that is non-compulsory as well? It is a farce. We have a system of voting. People accept it. If it ain't broke, don't fix it. We in the Labor Party believe that this is a matter that should be insisted upon to give the convention some credibility. Allow the community their voice, Prime Minister. Senator Minchin has been going around misrepresenting the facts. There is more value for money the cost of the convention vote in a compulsory attendance ballot than in a voluntary postal ballot. It is a farce. There are going to be millions of ballot papers floating around this country. As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) says, 'Who is helping them?' It brings the system into disrepute, which is what they want. The conservative Prime Minister and his prime minder, his parliamentary s-cretary, Senator Minchin, are about speanng the republic and discrediting the convention. They are about bringing in non-compulsory voting because they think that benefits the conservative forces. It is a disgrace. It is something the Labor Party will fight tooth and i1ail on and we will insist on these amendments being reinstated when the matter goes back before the Senate. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
text: I think those people are for real over there. I think, when the member for Banks (Mr Melham) had his mouth open, he was actually saying words, because what he was telling us-I see the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) sitting there-was a complete contradiction of what the unions, your masters, have been telling us in Western Australia. They just recently blockaded Western Australia, cut us off from the world, because the Western Australian Liberal Party government had the temerity to introduce secret ballots for trade unions. But that is the difference, isn't it? We know why you are worried about the integrity of postal ballots. We have a complete story about that in the postal workers union, where they went and printed a few more for themselves and then took hundreds of them around and sat there all night filling them in. You are the experts. You tell us about how to corrupt postal voting. We believe that the ordinary citizens do not behave like your mob. These are the people who have been in here defending postalMrs Crosio--Do you support compulsory voting?

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
text: 'You have to have a compulsory vote,' you say, but not in the trade union movement. Oh, no, you do not have them there! What do you want there? You want all the hands up, with one heavy standing alongside each one of them. Make up your mind. Mrs Crosio--Make up yours!

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
text: You are telling me-I know by your interjection-that you know too much about how to corrupt a postal ballot to trust the entire Australian people with it. We have a bit more faith in them when they are not a union bureaucrat, because we think the ordinary people are pretty straight. They will take this ballot in the way, of course, that it is intended. It is an indication, getting a process started. What is the main reason we are doing it? The same reason that there is criticism of the Western Australian legislation that requires secret ballots in trade unions. Why do they criticise it? Because they say that it is going to cost more money. The reality of this particular postal ballot is that it is going to cost about $30 million at a time when we have serious issues to address in all sectors of the community in terms of the financial assistance they need. Why would you knock off another $20 million and why can't it be voluntary if people have no interest whatsoever in an issue of this nature, which is not going to tum the nation on its head? After all, if we take the Keating minimalist position, we are arguing about calling Sir  'Your Excellency'. To tell you the truth, I think $30 million is too much for that, but I am going along with it, along with my party. But can anybody suggest any reason that you people can stand up in this place and say that you have to have compulsory secret ballots, when your colleagues in the trade union movement, the ACTU and all of them, have been blockading Western Australia, conducting strikes, stopping the national productivity so that the tax revenue of this parliament is less so it cannot help the poor and needy? You are doing all of that, and then you stand up in this place and give us the reverse argument. Make up your mind. Ring up Graham Kierath and say, 'Minister for Labour Relations in Western Australia, we were wrong. We've changed our mind. You were right; secret ballots are good. Compulsory voting for all trade unionists is good.' But make up your mind, because you cannot have it both ways. That is what you are trying to do tonight. You just cannot moralise on the issue when, in fact, you have been carrying on like a pork chop over in Western Australia, complaining about secret ballots being imposed by law

Speaker: Mr MELHAM
Title: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
text: I've always been a secessionist for Western Australia.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
text: So have I, but the only trouble is, Daryl, we would not give you a visa. This is the situation that you are carrying on about here. Why not just get practical? Why not get onto some of the big issues? Why not come on board with us and find some better systems to help Australians across the board, be it in taxation or all those other messes? That is what the nation wants at the moment, not the sort of silly debates we have wasted the time of the House with today-and this is just another one. Let us get on with it. Let us have the convention. Let the variety of people involved decide what the score is. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr MCMULLAN
Title: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
text: Canberra) (9.50 p.m.)I principally want to talk about the attempt by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Senator Minchin) to use this legislation as part of a series of moves to rort the Australian electoral system. But I cannot resist the opportunity to respond briefly to the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) in simply two ways. Firstly, he fundamentally misunderstands the situation in Western Australia. The objections of the trade union movement are not to secret ballots, but to the other matters that have been found by the ILO to be in breach of the freedom of association provisions of international conventions. What they are concerned about is that after 106 years of controlling the Legislative Council, because they have rorted the electoral system there every year for 106 years, the first time they lost, in the 1996 election, they dashed into ram through the parliament of Western Australia industrial laws they did not outline before the election, before the impact of the decision of the voters came into effect on 22 May. That is what people were concerned about. That is why the trade unionists responded and it is why the opposition to electoral rorting is consistent and reflected in this. The member for O'Connor quite clearly said that the postal voting system is open to misuse and abuse. We all know it is. It is one of the reasons why we do not support this proposal and why we are insisting on the amendments. The last point I want to make, before the Chief Opposition Whip breaks my leg, is that

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
text: He would never do that He's too nice a man.

Speaker: Mr MCMULLAN
Title: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
text: He's been trying for 20 years. I am trying not to get him to succeed on this occasion. Malcolm Mackerras pointed out, on the basis of some research that he had done, consistent with all the international experience, that moving from a compulsory to a voluntary voting system shifts the locus of political power two per cent to the right. It shifts the balance of electoral outcomes two per cent in favour of the right wing of a political spectrum. That is why Senator Minchin is seeking to do it. That is why it is a rort. In addition to the reasons proposed by the member for Banks (Mr Melham) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), these are the reasons we should, and will, insist on our amendments and oppose this rort.

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
text: The contribution of the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) was absolutely appalling. The member for Canberra (Mr MCMullan) is quite right, the problems in Western Australia have nothing to do with secret ballots, although I must say that I do not think unions are that keen on secret ballots because they know that they inevitably lead to more determined strikes amongst their members, strikes which they feel they can usually organise or bring to an end much quicker. The history in Britain is that where secret ballots were imposed strikes among members became far more determined. It was a fairly gratuitous contribution. I implore the Labor Party to give this some thought. They know very well that their constituency overwhelmingly does not want a republic. So why don't they just sit back and let the Liberal Party do it. I can assure the Labor Party that the Liberal Party will deliver them a republic within their next term of government. It is beyond doubt that when they win the next election they will deliver Australia a republic. You only have to talk to their craven backbenchers to know that that is the case. So if the Labor Party want to escape the wrath of their own constituents, they should just sit back and let the Liberals do it, as they have done in the past on these things. I must say again: there is absolutely no doubt that we do not want a plebiscite on this. We need a constitutional referendum on the question, 'Do we want a republic?' When we have had that question asked, it will be time for us to look at what form it should take. Question put: That Senate amendments Nos 1 to 8 and 10 to 68 be disagreed to. The House divided. Speaker: Mr JULL
Title: PAIRS
text: On behalf of the committee appointed to draw up reasons for the House disagreeing to amendments Nos 1 to 8 and 10 to 68 of the Senate, I present the reasons, which are being circulated to honourable members. The reasons read as followsSenate Amendment Number 1 The Amendment proposes a preamble be included which specifies the role of the Convention and the appointment and election of delegates to the Convention. The House of Representatives does not accept the Amendment, as it does not reflect the purpose and scope of the Bill. Senate Amendments Numbers 2-8 and 11-68 These Amendments focus on the method of voting for half of the delegates to the Constitutional Convention which will meet for 10 days in December 1997 to consider the question of whether or not Australia should become a republic. The Amendments require that voting in the election be by a compulsory attendance ballot, which will make Australians who choose not to vote in the election for delegates liable to prosecution and add up to $20 million to the cost. The Amendments also propose that the election be conducted along the lines of a Senate election. In light of the large number of candidates which could contest this election (possibly exceeding 200-300 candidates in New South Wales) a pure Senate "style" election would make it difficult for electors to vote for someone other than a group, and would extend the time needed to count the vote. Accordingly, the House of Representatives opposes these Amendments (Numbers 2-8 and 11-68). Senate Amendment Number 10 This Amendment provides that candidates' $500 nomination fee should be returned if the candidate is elected or the candidate/candidate group receives at least 4% of the total number of votes. Given the Government will be providing a tax dec'.uction for election expenses up to a limit of $1,000 to candidates, whether successful or not, the House of Representatives does not accept J,mendment Number 10. Motion (by Mr Jull) agreed to: That the committee's reasons be adopted. NA AMENDMENT (WORK FOR THE DOLE) BILL 1997 Consideration of Senate Message Bill returned from the Senate with amendments. Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration forthwith. Senate's amendments(1) Clause 3, page 2 (line 2), omit "Each", substitute "Subject to section 5, each". (2) Page 2 (after line 13), after clause 4, insert: 5 Amendments cease to have effect The amendments to the Social Security Act 1991 and the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990 made by this Act cease to have effect at the end of 24 months after commencement.

Speaker: Dr KEMP
Title: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION
text: Goldstein-Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training and Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation) (10.05 p.m.)-I move: That the amendments be disagreed to. The Senate has returned to the House of Representatives two amendments to the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Work for the Dole) Bill 1997. These amendments together insert into the legislation a sunset clause, which provides that the legislation will come to an end after two years. This initiative has been on the public agenda for some months now. It has been widely debated in the community since the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) announced it in February. It has been debated in the House and in the Senate and before a Senate references committee. I think it is fair to say that the Australian people clearly want this legislation. A two-year sunset clause can only lead to uncertainty and confusion. Amongst those mounting projects for work for the dole, it will cause confusion amongst unemployed participants in these projects and in the community. The communities have traditionally taken some time to establish the infrastructure for projects. While contracts will be signed as soon as possible, it is not at all certain when a particular project will commence. The imposition of a sunset clause removes the government's flexibility to accommodate good projects that require a longer lead time. The two-year sunset clause effectively gives the government and the communities, at most, in practice, about 18 months in which to establish projects and in which all decisions concerning participation in those projects are to be made. One of the consequences of this is that, in the last six months of any project, there could well be difficulties arising when members of a project wish to undertake employment and leave the project and have to be replaced by some other unemployed person. The short time frame will also make it difficult for communities to marshal community support for the unemployed participants. As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, the government's intention is that communities should offer continuing support for participants in the projects wherever possible beyond the conclusion of the project. The twoyear sunset clause again introduces a significant level of uncertainty into this matter. As we know, the Labor Party has consistently opposed work for the dole. It has opposed it in the House on many occasions. Senator Faulkner announced in the Senate last Friday that the Labor Party would be moving a range of amendments to the legislation. Of course, what we have now seen is that the Labor Party has not had the fortitude or the backbone to stand by its position on work for the dole and, in the Senate today, the Labor Party capitulated on virtually every major element of the legislation. The Labor Party has been consistently out of touch on this matter with young unemployed people and with the wider community.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION
text: We don't want your nonsense and political analysis.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION

Speaker: Dr KEMP
Title: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION
text: It is quite clear that the community wants work for the dole. At long last, apparently, that message has begun to get through to the Labor Party but the Labor Party has still got to face up to the fact that it supported an amendment to this legislation, the sunset clause, which calls into question acceptance of the principle of work for the dole. The Labor Party has not yet supported work for the dole. It is still in an ambiguous position on this very important principle. It a principle which ought to be in the legislation and which the Australian people believe ought to be a permanent feature of the legislation. So the challenge is now before the Labor Party. Is it going to bite the bullet on this matter? Is it going to back down on this last amendment or is it prepared to stand by its former support of the sunset clause? I think the Australian people will be waiting to see whether the Labor Party's spine has finally collapsed on this matter. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION
text: As we indicated at the outset of these propositions, at the end of the day after we had made our points to the government on this mickey mouse proposition, we would pass it. Indeed, as I said on the John Laws show about three months ago, the stuff on work for the dole is a piece of political opportunism, a charade, in which the government is trying to cloud itself and its own inadequacy on the employment front. But we will pass it. That is what I said at that point in time, and we will pass it. You are now left with, in work for the dole, a mickey mouse proposition. The public thinks it is five days a week. The public thinks that everybody who is unemployed-at least all young unemployed people-is going to be in a situation where they have to work for the dole. Anyone you go to as you go through your coffee mornings and all the rest of it assumes that there are a couple of hundred thousand places here-there are 10,000. As we have explained to the government before on this particular matter, the propositions we put in place when we were in office were a proper work for the dole scheme. It is interesting to see Tony Blair in the United its Kingdom, firstly, sending out here a Channel 4 team to look at what he thought were the Labor Party propositions in this area, only to find that they had all disappeared. Secondly, is he sat down with the Prime Minister and told the Prime Minister that it was the Labor Party's proposition that he was going to use to find 250,000 young people work in the United Kingdom. Guess what happened? If you did not actually pick up the Labor Party's scheme under Working Nation, after you had been out of work for 18 months-and it did not matter who you were-you either accepted a training opportunity or you accepted one of those programs such as the land environment and action program or you accepted, on top of that, the jobskills program which became new work opportunity. And what happened to you if you did not accept one of those multiplicity of choices-training included in it, a pathway through to work? If you did not accept it, you lost your unemployment benefits. That is what happened. What was that supposed to be? What that was, of course, was a proper project. It was a project that actually created jobs, that actually got people into work. What we have got here is mickey mouse. We have got 10,000 mickey mouse propositions in which some poor group somewhere in the bush are going to be hauled out and they are going to be told, 'You, you and you' . Nobody in Lane Cove is going to compulsorily work for the dole. Nobody is going to be singled out there. It is going to be in Wagga that those people are going to be subject to a compulsory proposition on work for the dole, and we are looking forward to watching your performance with this, minister. You thought you were going to avoid an opportunity; that you would be deprived of an opportunity, over the next few months to actually have to implement this. Now you have to implement mickey mouse. Now you are in it. You are going to be implementing mickey mouse and you are going to stand or fall on what mickey mouse creates as far as those jobs are concerned and you are going to be deprived of the facade you have been using to conceal your failure on employment, a failure that is increasingly obvious to the Australian people. Not one job! I look forward to your going to those workers in Newcastle who have been laid off as a result of your failure to deal with BHP. You are going to tell them that they are going to work for the dole. You are going to tell them that the in-principle position that you have arrived at is that they should work for the dole. So we are going to let you do it. We are going to let you do it in full. We are going to give you the opportunity to go and make those explanations

Title: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION
text: I oppose the amendments from the Senate. I think it is really quite pointless. Within two years the government is likely to be re-elected and in that case they can very easily further it. If they are not, the opposition can do what it will with the legislation anyway. So it is really quite pointless. I do want to take up this accusation of mickey mouse projects. The truth is that the labour market programs of the previous government were mickey mouse as well. Unfortunately, most of the people never got out and saw what really happened. There were many people who got jobs because the employer was highly subsidised by government money. As soon as that money ran out, despite the fact that they had worked their butts off, people were thrown back on the unemployment. It was very demoralising. The problem is that they have taken as their model the CDEP, the community development and employment project, which is used in the Aboriginal communities. I know this scheme. It is overwhelmingly corrupt. If it is not properly managed, it becomes corrupt very quickly, and it is even worse than sit-down money, straight dole money. If the government had any commitment instead of wanting to grandstand, it would have made sure that the administration of this work for the dole scheme was meaningful and was done through local government. It would have offered local government the same proposition that CDEP gets: the 15 per cent on top for administration and equipment. That is how work for the dole could do some useful work. It is local government that is the nub of this, it is local government that knows the jobs in the community that need to be done. Why didn't the government consider this? Because the government really wants to grandstand on it and wants to limit the scope of it. It is a great opportunity to get something constructi ve done in this country. It is a great opportunity to do some rebuilding of the infrastructure in the country destroyed by the years of Keating government. Mrs West-Yes.

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION
text: Don't 'yes, yes' me, because you are no better. Truly I say to the people of Australia that we have one-party government: Tweedledum and Tweedledumber. There is so much similarity between you. You argue at the edges, but the reality is that there is no commitment by either the government or the opposition to this scheme. It is quite clear that, if you want to get results from this, if you want to see something really happening with this project, if you want to see vitality return to particularly country areas, if you want to see infrastructure rebuilt, then this should be in the province of local government, because local government knows how to do it and it is beyond doubt that the minister's department hasn't got a clue. Question resolved in the affirmative. Committee of Reasons Motion (by Dr Kemp) agreed to: That Mr Ronaldson, Mr Barresi and the mover be appointed a committee to draw up reasons for the House of Representatives disagreeing to the amendments of the Senate.

Speaker: Dr KEMP
Title: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION
text: Goldstein-Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training and Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation) (10.18 p.m.)-On behalf of the committee appointed to draw up reasons for the House disagreeing to the amendments of the Senate, I present the reasons, which are being circulated to honourable members. The reasons read as followsSenate Amendment Numbers 1 and 2. The amendments would provide for a "sunset" provision to be included in the Bill. The effect of the sunset provision would be that the measures proposed by the Bill would cease to have effect at the end of 24 months after the Act's commencement. The House of Representatives considers that these Amendments should not proceed as they fail to accept the core principle underpinning the Work for the Dole initiative. The House considers that this arbitrary 2 year limit restricts the capacity of the Government to make continuing arrangements for benefit recipients to make a contribution to their communities in return for income support. The community and in particular young people have recognised the inherent fairness of this initiative and the benefits that will flow to individuals and their communities. The House remains of the view that this principle should be embodied in the legislation, without the constraint of a sunset provision. Motion (by Dr Kemp) agreed to: That the committee's reasons be adopted.
